{"uri": "8112858476", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "22:20:40", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T22:20:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T22:19:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://pantagraph.com/sports/professional/auto-racing/norris-verstappen-f1-miami-mclaren-red-bull-ricciardo-hamilton-sargeant/article_2f1f6e88-b6af-53fc-b470-a32a8c027da1.html", "title": "Norris earns 1st F1 victory, ends Verstappen's dominance", "body": "JENNA FRYER Associated Press\n\nMIAMI GARDENS, Fla. -- Lando Norris needed 110 starts and a mistake by Max Verstappen to earn his first ever Formula 1 race on Sunday and end Verstappen's dominance at the Miami Grand Prix.\n\nVerstappen, who started from the pole and won Saturday's sprint race, was out front when he hit a chicane and knocked a cone out of place on the circuit. It forced the three-time reigning F1 champion to pit and gave Norris the lead.\n\nThe 24-year-old driver for McLaren then controlled the race to give the organization its first win since a Daniel Ricciardo victory in 2021. It also made him the second British driver in F1 history to be feted on the podium by \"God Save the King.\" George Russell in 2022 is the only other British driver to win outside of Queen Elizabeth's reign; Russell's victory in Brazil came two months after Queen Elizabeth's death.\n\nWith about 10 laps to go, Norris realized the race was his to lose when his lead over Verstappen hit 5 seconds.\n\nPeople are also reading... Carnival to return to Eastland Mall this week Ex-Unit 5 teacher sentenced on reduced charges of trespassing in Decatur, assault in Nashville Dan Brady announces candidacy for Bloomington mayor Bloomington man gets 75-year prison sentence in 2023 murder at Victory Church Normal man arrested in home invasion, sexual assault investigation Normal police investigating report of home invasion, sexual assault Suspect in Heartland college carjacking granted pretrial release 7 arrested on trespassing charges at ISU following week of protests Flick Fact: The average age of a State Farm employee? WJBC mourns loss of former radio host Scott Laughlin Former Fairbury officer sentenced to 4 years in prison in sexual assault case Rivian receives $827M state incentive package to expand operations in Normal Flick Fact: The top public high school in Illinois outside of Chicago? PATH to lay off dozens in Bloomington after losing state 988 grant Man waiting murder trial accused of contacting witness from McLean County Jail\n\n\"Five seconds?\" Norris radioed his team. \"Am I alive?\"\n\nIndeed he was as an ecstatic McLaren squad celebrated a rare victory on a weekend in which it debuted significant upgrades on its two cars. McLaren now has 13 wins in races in the United States -- tying a record with Ferrari -- but it was the first on American soil since Lewis Hamilton at Circuit of the Americas in 2012.\n\nNorris' final margin of victory was 7.6-seconds over Verstappen of Red Bull.\n\n\"I love you all, thank you so much!\" Norris screamed on his radio. \"We did it! We did it!\"\n\nNorris said he knew when he entered the track he'd win at Miami.\n\n\"Finally. I am so happy. I knew it. I knew it when I came in this morning,\" Norris said. \"And I nailed it.\"\n\nMcLaren has now won an F1, Formula E and IndyCar race in the past two months. Norris is the first driver since Carlos Sainz Jr. to beat Verstappen this season -- and Verstappen was eliminated from that race in Melbourne with a mechanical failure.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\n\"You win. You lose. I think we're all a bit used to that in racing,\" Verstappen said. \"Is a bad day P2? I will take it. I am happy for Lando, it's been a long time coming and there's more to come from him.\"\n\nNorris was swarmed by the McLaren crew after the race as team members lifted him and seemed to crowd surf him until he finally got to boss Zak Brown, who wrapped Norris in a bearhug.\n\nMcLaren, before the start of the race, hosted former President Donald Trump, who chatted with F1 officials from inside the McLaren garage. When he made his way toward the starting grid, fans began chanting \"USA! USA!\" and Trump pumped his first in approval.\n\nFerrari drivers Charles Leclerc and Sainz finished third and fourth and was followed by Sergio Perez of Red Bull.\n\nHamilton was sixth for Mercedes, Yuki Tsunoda of Red Bull's junior team was seventh and Russell was eighth for Mercedes. Fernando Alonso of Aston Martin and Esteban Ocon of Alpine rounded out the top 10. Ocon did it with team investors Patrick Mahomes and Travis Kelce of the Kansas City Chiefs in attendance.\n\nAbout halfway through the race, Logan Sargeant crashed and brought out the safety car that forced the Pompano Beach native out of his car. The 23-year-old and only American driver on the F1 grid is clinging to his seat with Williams as speculation is rampant he could be replaced before the end of his second season.\n\nIt marked Sargeant's second consecutive last-place finish at his home race.\n\nThe Sargeant crash handed control of race strategy to McLaren, who held the lead with Norris at the time of the caution. Norris had taken over the lead when Verstappen was forced to pit from the lead after hitting a chicane that knocked a cone onto the racing surface.\n\nAs Red Bull was looking for any damage to Verstappen's front wing, a race marshal entered the circuit and scooped up the cone as F1 avoided having to use the safety car for the incident. But just moments later, Kevin Magnussen made contact with Williams and it gave McLaren the chance to strategize a victory over Verstappen.\n\nFor Magnussen, it marked another bad day in a long weekend in which the Haas driver was accused of unsportsmanlike conduct for his strategy in Saturday's sprint race.\n\nLove 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nTags Dcc Wire Lee-national Be the first to Wins his first-ever career F1 win after outlasting Max Verstappen at Miami GP", "body": "McLaren driver Lando Norris, of Britain, is lifted after winning the Miami Formula One Grand Prix auto race in Miami Gardens, Fla. | Image: AP\n\nThe McLaren F1 team has a big reason to party after one of their rising stars, Lando Norris, secured a massive sweep at the Miami International Autodrome in Florida. Despite Red Bull driver Max Verstappen starting from the pole and winning Saturday's sprint race, his continued dominance at the track was thwarted by the British-Belgian Motorsports driver. The Orange team was jubilant after Norris' car pipped everyone and won the Main Race in Miami and got his first career Formula 1 victory. The spectators and fans were ecstatic to finally see someone other than the dominant Red Bull driver at the number one spot on the podium.\n\nAlso Read: F1 now makes 3 stops a season in the United States; Could Miami become a victim of oversaturation?\n\nLando Norris pips Max Verstappen! Gets his first career F1 win at Miami GP\n\nEven though Max Verstappen started from the first place on the circuit, the Red Bull driver ran into a chicane and knocked a cone out of position. Lando Norris took the lead after the three-time F1 champion was forced to pit. Following that, the McLaren driver took command of the race, handing the team its first victory since Daniel Ricciardo in 2021. Lewis Hamilton, Max Verstappen, and Daniel Ricciardo were among the racers who came out to congratulate the 24-year-old for his first career win.\n\nMcLaren driver Lando Norris waves to the crowd after winning the Miami Formula One Grand Prix auto race at the Miami International Autodrome in Miami Gardens, Florida | Image: AP\n\nOn his 110th career start, Norris triumphed in his maiden Formula One race, putting an end to Verstappen's dominant reign at the Miami track. After sprinting down the pit lane, the McLaren driver leapt into the arms of his crew members, who crowd-surfed Lando until he reached CEO Zak Brown, who gave Norris an affectionate embrace.\n\nAlso Read: Red Bull chief technical officer Adrian Newey to step down from F1 team\n\nDespite losing the race due to his error, Max was still able to place second. Charles Leclerc and Carlos Sainz, the two Ferrari drivers, came in third and fourth, respectively. Red Bull Racing's Sergio Perez trailed behind them.\n\nLewis Hamilton finished sixth, Russell finished eighth for Mercedes, while Yuki Tsunoda of Visa RB finished seventh. {"uri": "8112915582", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "23:46:10", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T23:46:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T23:45:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.newshub.co.nz/home/sport/2024/05/motorsport-mclaren-s-lando-norris-claims-maiden-f1-victory-with-win-in-miami.html", "title": "Motorsport: McLaren's Lando Norris claims maiden F1 victory with win in Miami | Newshub", "body": "Lando Norris claims the chequered flag. Credits: Image - Getty Images, video - Sky Sports\n\nMcLaren's Lando Norris capitalised on a bit of good fortune to win the Miami Grand Prix on Monday (NZ time), holding off Red Bull's triple world champion Max Verstappen for his first Formula One victory.\n\nIt was a long overdue triumph for the Briton who held the record for most podiums without a win (15), having finished runner-up an agonising eight times in 110 grand prix.\n\nVerstappen had seemed well placed to claim a fifth win in six races until a midway crash allowed McLaren to cash in on a safety car period, with Norris pitting and coming out with the lead.\n\nSeeking a Miami hat-trick of wins, the Dutchman filled Norris's mirrors on the restart but his Red Bull could offer no challenge as the McLaren pulled clear.\n\nFerrari's Charles Leclerc completed the podium, coming home third ahead of team mate Carlos Sainz.\n\n\"About time! What a race. It's been a long time coming. Finally I've managed to do it,\" Norris told Sky Sports. \"I'm so happy for my whole team. I finally delivered for them.\n\n\"Long day, tough race. Finally on top, so I'm over the moon. I'm just proud. A lot of people doubted me along the way.\n\n\"I've made a lot of mistakes over my last five years in my short career but today we put it all together.\"\n\nIn a season dominated by Red Bull it was a hugely popular win by the 24-year-old Briton.\n\nPulling into the pit lane Norris was mobbed by his team, congratulated by the other drivers and cheered by a massive crowd at the Miami International Autodrome that included former U.S. president Donald Trump, who visited the McLaren garage prior to the race.\n\nUntil Sunday it had been another dominant weekend for Red Bull as Verstappen topped the timesheets in the only practice session and sprint qualifying on Friday and then won the sprint race and took pole on Saturday.\n\nHis second place in the grand prix had little impact on the drivers' standings as he continues to hold a commanding 35-point lead over his team mate Sergio Perez, who finished fifth.\n\nMercedes' seven-times world champion Lewis Hamilton was sixth and RB's Yuki Tsunoda seventh followed by George Russell in the other Mercedes.\n\nStarting from pole, Verstappen was in command through the first 20 laps but was unable to open up more than a three-second lead on Norris's McLaren team mate Oscar Piastri.\n\nAs the race reached the midway mark Verstappen made a rare unpressured mistake, going wide and hitting a bollard that broke and was left on the track, bringing out the virtual safety car.\n\nVerstappen was then quickly into the pits with Piastri, who had already pitted, assuming the lead.\n\nWith the first round of pit stops about to be completed and Verstappen about to retake the lead, McLaren got a lucky break.\n\nWilliams' Logan Sargeant spun into the wall, bringing out the safety car and allowing Norris to pit and come out still in the lead, which he never let go.\n\n\"You win, you lose,\" said Verstappen. \"I think we're all used to that in racing, right?\n\n\"Today was just a bit tricky. If a bad day is P2, I take it.\n\n\"I'm very happy for Lando. It's been a long time coming and it's not going to be his last one, so he definitely deserves it today.\"\n\nReuters", "source": {"uri": "newshub.co.nz", "dataType": "news", "title": "Newshub"}, {"uri": "8113988285", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "14:44:48", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T14:44:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T14:44:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/formula-1/verstappen-norris-onboards-miami-gp-32746392", "title": "Max Verstappen's act toward Lando Norris missed by TV at end of Miami Grand Prix", "body": "Max Verstappen gestured to Lando Norris after the chequered flag in Miami\n\nMax Verstappen showed his class as he sent an immediate message of congratulations to Lando Norris after losing to the Briton at the Miami Grand Prix.\n\nAt the 110th attempt, Norris finally became a Formula 1 race winner. And he did so by beating Verstappen in a straight fight on track - albeit with a little help from the timing of a safety car.\n\nIt allowed Norris to take the lead of the race at the mid-way point. But he still needed to hold off the Red Bull behind him when the race resumed and, not only did he do that, but he beat Verstappen by more than seven seconds in the end.\n\nThe Dutchman knew he had been beaten fair and square by Norris - his best friend in the F1 paddock. And he showed how happy he was for the McLaren racer by putting his thumb up to the 24-year-old as he pulled alongside his car on the cool down lap.\n\nThe footage was not broadcast on the TV world feed at the time. But a clip of the touching moment later emerged on social media and fans were left impressed by the way the championship leader handled the defeat.\n\nOne wrote: \"A fab gesture applauding for Lando for his first F1 race win! Great sportsmanship, Max!\" Another praised him for swallowing his pride after being \"knocked by that result\", while several others said the move was \"classy\".\n\nAnd many also pointed out that he wasn't the only one who did it. Lewis Hamilton was another driver who applauded Norris from the cockpit of his car, as did several others - showing just how popular the McLaren driver is among his peers.\n\nIn the post-race press conference, Verstappen took time to heap praise on Norris. He said: \"I'm very happy to be beaten by Lando today. He definitely deserved it. He was just miles faster at the end there. So, yeah, it's great. You know, winning your first race is always, I think, quite emotional.\n\n\"It brings you back to all the days that you worked towards Formula 1, and then you dream of being on the podium, but then being on the top step. So, yeah, of course, I'm not very happy with my day, but you can appreciate and respect what Lando has done today, and I'm very happy for him.\"\n\nAnd Hamilton also congratulated his fellow Briton, telling reporters: \"I feel really happy for Lando... {"uri": "8112885622", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "23:01:51", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T23:01:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T23:00:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://expressdigest.com/lando-norris-claims-first-f1-victory-at-star-studded-miami-grand-prix-as-max-verstappen-is-forced-to-settle-for-second-in-front-of-donald-trump/", "title": "Lando Norris claims first F1 victory at star-studded Miami Grand Prix as Max Verstappen is forced to settle for second in front of Donald Trump", "body": "Donald Trump, carrying his famous red cap, would be last man to believe he couldn't make the Formula One Championship Great Again.\n\nIt was his first known visit to the world's premier series and he was a guest of McLaren. He went in there and pumped his clenched fists and wished them luck before the 57 laps began. And tried to rub off a bit of his self-belief on his hosts.\n\nThe papaya man visiting the papaya team.\n\nAnd, as if by magic, Lando Norris won his first race on a sunlit day in Miami. A little bit of luck came into it, for sure, in the shape of a safety car. But for Norris, 24-year-old racer from Glastonbury, Somerset, a whole heap of relief lifted from his slender shoulders, becoming the 21st British winner.\n\nHe carried with him the unwanted tag of 14 podiums without a victory, more than anyone else in history, and one sensed it weighed him down. He is more introspective than his bubbly, made-for-Netflix public demeanour suggests.\n\nLando Norris claimed his first victory in Formula One at the Miami Grand Prix\n\nThe British driver is congratulated by former president Donald Trump following his win\n\nThe McLaren driver kept his composure to best favorite Max Verstappen (left)\n\nHis big chance came on lap 28, almost the exact half-point of the race.\n\nThis was brought about by Haas' Kevin Magnussen punting Williams' Logan Sargeant into the wall. Sargeant, from up the road in Fort Lauderdale, was unlucky. Anyway, the cessation in racing allowed Norris a free stop. It gifted him the chance to hold on to hitherto deceptive 'lead', for he hadn't yet stopped and everyone else had.\n\nNice one. But who was in the car directly behind him? No less than his best mate on the grid, Max Verstappen, the world champion, the machine who can't be beaten (not unless his engine blows).\n\nPrivately, Norris rates Verstappen the best driver the sport has known. He believes he has every attribute to succeed at the top, so to have the Dutchman in a sizzling Red Bull in his rear-view mirror when the safety car pulled in was hardly akin to a quiet Sunday drive.\n\nIt must have put the wind right up him. Now all he had hoped for before and after his debut in Melbourne in 2021 - a spotty teenager who pulled at his finger joints nervously as he spoke - ran through his mind.\n\nCould he keep his calm? The early evidence was 'yes'. He was shod on younger rubber, obviously, but the same hard compounds. He immediately set a fastest lap and continued to edge ahead, while Verstappen was struggling. He made his complaints known over the radio. Thirteen laps to go and he had opened up a four second lead.\n\nNorris is psrayed with champagne by Verstappen and Ferrari's Charles Leclerc (right)\n\nWith his victory in sunlit Miami, the 24-year-old became the 21st British F1 winner\n\nIt was perhaps written in the stars. Verstappen, usually as dominant as imaginable, had managed to run into a bollard early on.\n\nThe triple world champion veered off track at Turn 15 a third of the way and collected the red-and-white cone. But at this point you would be thinking that nothing - plastic, human or extra-terrestrial - could stop the Dutchman as he dominates all he comes up against routinely.\n\nThat Norris won was testament to his talents, and built on his impressive performance, perhaps his most rounded in China a fortnight ago, when he was runner-up.\n\nAll this Norris joy had seemed a distant fantasy in the early stages. Verstappen had sat on the lead, no problems at all, keeping McLaren's Oscar Piastri at a distance behind him of three seconds in the searing Floridian heat. But Verstappen was not romping away, actually, a sign of what was to come.\n\nI don't know that you'd call this race swanky. It's too brash for that. Which was a perfect place for the politician who may be elected the next leader of the free world while inside a prison cell.\n\nOn Monday the great new Norris fan will be in a New York courtroom fighting charges that he falsified documents to cover up hush money he gave to a former adult-film actress and a Playboy model. Yet Sunday he was the main attraction even amid the A-listers who came (and those who stayed away perhaps because of him).\n\nWith his race, Norris claimed McLaren's first victory in nearly three years\n\nVerstappen, usually as dominant as imaginable, had managed to run into a bollard early on\n\nDonald Trump has arrived at the Miami Grand Prix and was flanked by heavy security\n\nIn a surreal scene some two hours before lights out, his security men called for a channel to be made taking him from the central paddock building to the McLaren garage. Someone shouted: 'Hope you win, Donald!' He turned and said: 'I have to.'\n\nHe went into the garage for 10 minutes or so. He spoke to the sport's top brass, including Formula One chief executive Stefano Domenicali and FIA president Mohammed ben Sulayem. He was in the McLaren stable at the request of the team's majority owners, the Bahrain sovereign wealth fund led by the Crown Prince of the kingdom, Salman.\n\nThe conversation over, Trump then went through the same routine through the throng. An OnlyFans model, whose skimpy attire left little to the imagination, took a selfie with the Republican candidate presumptive. He jutted his jaw and off he stalked followed by his security detail.\n\nHe had not entirely got his own way this week. A billionaire friend, Steven Witkoff, had tried to organise a fundraiser at the track. The idea was to charge attendees $250,000 to attend the function on a Paddock Club rooftop suite.\n\nThe organisers stamped that out.\n\nBut Trump watched from the same spot as Norris took the win, a massive 7.6 seconds from Verstappen, with Ferrari's Charles Leclerc third. Norris put both hands in the air in celebration after crossing the line.\n\nColleagues at McLaren, who felt they had to underline they are non-political in a statement after the Trump visit, were overwhelmed. They danced in the pit lane.\n\nTrump gestured to his supporters in the crowd as he prepared to watch the racing begin\n\nTrump speaks with McLaren CEO Zak Brown as he visits the McLaren garage before the race\n\nLewis Hamilton, a McLaren world champion back in the day, gave Norris a thumbs up from the cockpit.\n\nNorris hollered a noise beyond description. 'We did it, Will,' he said to his engineer Will Joseph. Zak Brown, the McLaren chief executive who had entertained Trump in the garage, hugged everyone he could find.\n\n'I guess that's how it's done,' chimed a clearly emotional Norris, dedicating the triumph to his grandmother. 'I knew when I came in today it was a day of opportunities.'\n\nYes, he made himself great.", "source": {"uri": "expressdigest.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "expressdigest.com"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8113198265", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "05:40:06", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T05:40:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T05:39:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.businesslive.co.za/bd/life/motoring/2024-05-06-even-trump-and-verstappen-celebrate-norris-win-in-miami/", "title": "Even Trump and Verstappen celebrate Norris win in Miami", "body": "Norris held the record for most podiums without a win (15). Picture: REUTERS\n\nIt is doubtful there has been a more popular winner of a Formula One race in recent years than McLaren's Lando Norris, who was celebrated by everyone from Max Verstappen to Donald Trump after his victory at the Miami Grand Prix on Sunday.\n\nIt was a long overdue triumph for Norris, who held the record for most podiums without a win (15), including an agonising eight runner-up finishes, in 110 grands prix, making the likable Briton easy to root for.\n\nEven Verstappen, Red Bull's triple world champion who hates to lose and was denied a hat-trick of Miami wins by the McLaren driver, was among the first to congratulate Norris, who was mobbed by his team, crowd surfed along pit land and drenched in a shower of champagne.\n\n\"It was a long time coming, and I'm very happy to be beaten by Lando today,\" smiled a genuinely pleased Verstappen. \"He definitely deserved it.\n\n\"It's great winning your first race. It's always quite emotional. It brings you back to all the days that you worked towards your dream of being on the podium.\"\n\nFormer US president Donald Trump, who visited the McLaren garage before the race, was delighted to back a winner, telling Norris later he was his lucky charm.\n\n\"He saw me after, and he came to congratulate me,\" said Norris, who had told his grandmother before coming to Miami that he was going to win a race. \"He [Trump] said he was my lucky charm because it was my win, but I don't know if he's going to come to more races.\"\n\nNorris' mother and father were ecstatic, though they were not in Miami to witness the moment.\n\n\"The cider's flowing in Somerset! A big celebration,\" Adam Norris told Sky Sports. \"I was working out, it's probably about 900 races I've been to over the last 16 years.\n\n\"It's interesting knowing as a parent how many hours you put in, supporting them.\n\n\"I counted out 350 weekends away and all the races on different weekends.\n\n\"It's brilliant. So happy for him.\"\n\nAnthony Hamilton, another father instrumental in the success of his son -- seven-times world champion Lewis -- also texted Norris with congratulations.\n\nWhile Norris was long overdue for a maiden win his wait was not the longest.\n\nWorld champions Jenson Button needed 113 races before his first win and Nico Rosberg 111.\n\nRed Bull's Sergio Perez holds the record of 190 races before his visit to the top of the podium and it took Ferrari's Carlos Sainz 150 and Mark Webber 130.\n\nNorris was still finalising plans on how he was going to celebrate his maiden victory, but he was already thinking about a second win.\n\n\"This only happens once when you take your first win. Tonight is going to be a good night,\" said Norris, confirming team boss Zak Brown had delayed the flight home until Monday so there would be a proper celebration. \"I would like to say it's the start, and now we're really hungry for more. Depailler, Jean Alesi, Mika Hakkinen and Eddie Irvine for the most podium finishes before a first win (15 before today).\n\nREPORT: Norris beats Verstappen for breakthrough maiden F1 victory in action-packed Miami Grand Prix\n\n* Today was Norris' 110th start for McLaren, which coincidentally tied Lewis Hamilton's total with the team from 2007-2012.\n\n* Norris is the first driver to take a maiden win in the United States since Michele Alboreto at Caesars Palace in 1982.\n\n* Norris finished 17th in the 2023 Miami Grand Prix, 1m 27s behind Max Verstappen.\n\n* Courtesy of Norris, today was the first time the British national anthem was heard on the podium since Sao Paulo 2022.\n\nREAD MORE: 'I finally delivered for them' - Norris pays tribute to McLaren after 'about time' debut F1 {"uri": "8113020273", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "02:24:19", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T02:24:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T02:23:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://sportstar.thehindu.com/motorsport/f1/mclaren-lando-norris-wins-miami-grand-prix-first-formula-one-win-report-result-news/article68144497.ece", "title": "McLaren's Norris wins Miami Grand Prix for first F1 win", "body": "McLaren's Lando Norris capitalised on a bit of good fortune to win the Miami Grand Prix on Sunday, holding off Red Bull's triple world champion Max Verstappen for his first Formula One victory.\n\nIt was a long overdue triumph for the Briton who held the record for most podiums without a win (15), having finished runner-up an agonising eight times in 110 grand prix.\n\nVerstappen had seemed well placed to claim a fifth win in six races until a midway crash allowed McLaren to cash in on a safety car period, with Norris pitting and coming out with the lead.\n\nSeeking a Miami hat-trick of wins, the Dutchman filled Norris's mirrors on the restart but his Red Bull could offer no challenge as the McLaren pulled clear.\n\nFerrari's Charles Leclerc completed the podium, coming home third ahead of team mate Carlos Sainz.\n\nREAD | Miami Grand Prix: Max Verstappen ties Alain Prost's record with 6th pole-winning run to open an F1 season\n\n\"About time! What a race. It's been a long time coming. Finally I've managed to do it,\" Norris told Sky Sports. \"I'm so happy for my whole team. I finally delivered for them.\n\n\"Long day, tough race. Finally on top, so I'm over the moon. I'm just proud. A lot of people doubted me along the way.\n\n\"I've made a lot of mistakes over my last five years in my short career but today we put it all together.\"\n\nIn a season dominated by Red Bull it was a hugely popular win by the 24-year-old Briton.\n\nPulling into the pit lane Norris was mobbed by his team, congratulated by the other drivers and cheered by a massive crowd at the Miami International Autodrome that included former U.S. president Donald Trump, who visited the McLaren garage prior to the race.\n\nUntil Sunday it had been another dominant weekend for Red Bull as Verstappen topped the timesheets in the only practice session and sprint qualifying on Friday and then won the sprint race and took pole on Saturday.\n\nThe results had little impact on the drivers' standings with Verstappen holding a commanding 35-point lead over his team mate Sergio Perez.\n\nStarting from pole, Verstappen was in command through the first 20 laps but was unable to open up more than a three-second lead on Norris's McLaren team mate Oscar Piastri.\n\nAs the race reached the midway mark Verstappen made a rare unpressured mistake, going wide and hitting a bollard that broke and was left on the track, bringing out the virtual safety car.\n\nVerstappen was then quickly into the pits with Piastri, who had already pitted, assuming the lead.\n\nWith the first round of pit stops about to be completed and Verstappen about to retake the lead, McLaren got a lucky break.\n\nWilliams' Logan Sargeant spun into the wall, bringing out the safety car and allowing Norris to pit and come out still in the lead, which he never let go.\n\n\"You win, you lose,\" said Verstappen. \"I think we're all used to that in racing, right?\n\n\"Today was just a bit tricky. If a bad day is P2, I take it.\n\n\"I'm very happy for Lando. It's been a long time coming and it's not going to be his last one, so he definitely deserves it today.\"\n\nLatest on SportstarMcLaren's Norris wins Miami Grand Prix for first F1 win ReutersLa Liga {"uri": "8113456426", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "08:56:36", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T08:56:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T08:56:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://www.givemesport.com/lando-norris-team-radio-after-winning-miami-gp/", "title": "Lando Norris' team radio after winning his first-ever Formula 1 Grand Prix is beautiful", "body": "Lando Norris won his first-ever Formula 1 race in Miami, and he was absolutely delighted, as shown by his reaction on the team radio.\n\nHighlights Lando Norris finally won his first-ever Formula 1 Grand Prix in Miami, at the 110th time of asking, much to the delight and emotion of the McLaren driver. Norris finished ahead of Drivers' Championship leader Max Verstappen, which led to the Dutchman giving his fellow driver a round of applause during the cool-down lap. Norris had been questioned over his ability to win a race, but he's finally put those doubts to bed.\n\nAs Lando Norris finally overcame his winning duck, securing his first-ever race victory at the Miami Grand Prix, it was not only to the delight of McLaren fans, or the drivers on the track, who serenaded him with rounds of applause as they came over the finish line, it was to the obvious delight of himself and his team, as visor cam footage paired with the audio of the team radio makes for some very wholesome listening as Lando \"No-wins\" is no more.\n\nDriving in his 110th race of his career, Lando Norris decided that the Miami GP was the time and place to put in the performance fans knew he had in him. Having come close at the Russian GP in 2021, it was a change in conditions that ultimately led to him not getting his first victory, but with the Miami sun glaring down on him, he showed up and showed out in convincing fashion, beating Max Verstappen to victory with a seven-second lead on the Dutch champion.\n\nThere had been a lot of talk regarding Norris, and if he had it in him to compete for victories, especially following the GP in China, where he topped qualifying, only for Lewis Hamilton to snatch that position off him following Turn 2 on race day. However, the \"No-wins\" moniker is no more, and the delight of the British driver and his team was palpable, with radio footage proving just how badly they had been waiting for this moment.\n\nGIVEMESPORT's Key Statistic: The Miami GP was Lando Norris' 110th start in a Formula 1 race.\n\nLando Norris' Team Radio Footage After Miami GP\n\n\"Woooo, about f****** time! I love you all, I love you all, thank you so much, we did it!\"\n\nHaving taken the time to relish in the fact that he was an F1 race winner, the McLaren driver delivered a lovely speech to his team over the radio, saying: \"Everyone in McLaren, I've finally delivered for you, thank you so much, I'm so proud of everyone, of our work, let's keep it up, let's keep fighting. This is just the beginning. Love you all.\"\n\nHe was then jokingly asked if he was crying over the radio, something he denied, but whether he was crying or not, the emotion and pride was evident on the audio, and it is obvious just how badly he wanted to dispel the myth that he couldn't win, or that he couldn't handle the pressure.\n\nMiami Grand Prix 2024 Top 5\n\nPosition\n\nDriver\n\nCar\n\nPoints\n\n1.\n\nLando Norris\n\nMcLaren\n\n25\n\n2.\n\nMax Verstappen\n\nRed Bull\n\n18\n\n3.\n\nCharles Leclerc\n\nFerrari\n\n15\n\n4.\n\nCarlos Sainz Jr\n\nFerrari\n\n12\n\n5.\n\nSergio Perez\n\nRed Bull\n\n10\n\nLando Norris Reacts to First GP Win\n\nClearly with a point to prove, Norris took to the press conference after his win to speak about the critics who doubted him: \"... a lot of people doubted that I could go out and win races and perform under the pressure of leading the race, especially with Max behind you and those types of things. But really, this year, I felt more confident than ever that I wasn't thinking of these things.\"\n\nClose\n\nThe response of a true winner. It is clear Norris has had a shift in mindset in recent times, with this confidence and energy not being observed way back in 2021 at the Russian GP. This is the evolution of a driver who is ready to handle the pressure. {"uri": "8112975792", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "01:18:41", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T01:18:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T01:18:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/formulaone/article-13385865/History-making-Brit-driver-Lando-Norris-24-nails-F1-win-abandoning-horse-riding-child-motorsport-gave-80million-contract-model-girlfriend-stunning-20m-Surrey-mansion.html", "title": "History-making Brit driver Lando Norris, 24, nails his first F1 win", "body": "He has quickly become the poster boy for F1 and now Lando Norris has reached new heights bagging his first Grand Prix win in Miami pushing reigning world champion Max Verstappen off the podium.\n\nThe Bristol-born 24-year-old stormed ahead of the Red Bull star in the final moments of the race on Sunday securing a narrow win for the McLaren team.\n\nNorris has perhaps always been destined for F1 greatness after becoming the youngster-ever British driver when he made his debut at 19-years-old in the Australian Grand Prix.\n\nYet if it had not been for his love of horse riding as a child, the young star may never have made his way to motorsports.\n\n'I started on horse riding, so I started on four legs,' he recalled previously. 'But then I moved to quad biking. I was a big fan. Then I really got into motorcross.'\n\nNow he is one of the most successful F1 drivers both on and off the racetrack.\n\nNot only does he have a four-year contract estimated to be worth a whopping \u00a380 million, the racing pro has a series of luxury brand deals and has starred in a number of glam photoshoots.\n\nClutching onto a series of supercars, designer watches and a stunning \u00a320million mansion in Surrey. As well as career success, his personal life has also been blossoming.\n\nLando Norris reached new heights as he entered the Formula One history books with a first Grand Prix win\n\nNorris is amongst Formula One's most-popular drivers and promotes a luxury lifestyle on his social media accounts\n\nLando Norris was recently spotted with Margarida Corceiro at the Monte-Carlo Masters final\n\nLando and his millionaire businessman father Adam Norris arrive at the Bahrain Grand Prix in March\n\nOver the past year, he has ben regularly spotted alongside the ex-girlfriend of Barcelona footballer Joao Felix, Portuguese model and actress Margarida Corceiro, only add to speculation and discussion about his romantic life.\n\nThe pair were recently spotted at the Monte-Carlo Masters final amid her split from Felix last year. Norris and Corceiro were first spotted together last May in a video on social media showing the 24-year-old driving his Fiat Jolly with her in the back of the classic car.\n\nNorris had previously been dating Luisinha Oliveira, with the McLaren driver beginning a relationship with the Portuguese model at the start of 2022.\n\nThe relationship ended in September that year, with Norris confirming the split on social media.\n\nHow Red Bull's departing mastermind can reignite Lewis Hamilton's career at Ferrari... PLUS why a Grand Prix in 'woke' Los Angeles is off the agenda, writes JONATHAN MCEVOY\n\nFact-box text\n\nAdvertisement\n\nLike many of the F1 elite, Norris grew up in an affluent family, living in the rural town of Glastonbury, Somerset.\n\nHe is the second son of multi-millionaire businessman Adam Norris - who has amassed a \u00a3205 million fortune - and his mother Cisca, from Belgium.\n\nNorris is one of four children - having an elder brother called Oli, and two younger sisters Flo and Cisca.\n\nHe attended school in Somerset but ultimately left without any GCSEs in pursuit of a career in support, later studying physics and maths with the help of a personal tutor.\n\nNorris became the youngest go-karting world champion at just age 14 - a title previously held by Lewis Hamilton.\n\nIt was during his time on the go-karting scene that he was talent-spotted by McLaren who were impressed by the record breaking youngster.\n\nNorris became the youngest-ever British Formula One driver when he made his debut in the competition in 2019 at just 19-years-old at the Australian GP after coming through the ranks of the garage as an FP2 star.\n\nTeam principal Zak Brown once called an even-more youthful Norris to his office in 2019 to tell him the news that he was being given a contract and full-time seat in Formula One, telling him at the time: 'Welcome to Formula One.'\n\nNorris was drencehd in champagne atop the podium by Red Bull's Max Verstappen (left) and Ferrari's Charles Leclerc (right)\n\nPhotography appears to be one of Norris' favourite hobbies during his spare time\n\nBarcelona forward Felix had been dating Portuguese model and actress Corceiro since 2019\n\nThe Englishman took the news calmly at the time and has taken to the on and off-track demands that being one of the world's biggest sporting celebrities brings with it.\n\nFormula One's media moguls have wrangled their product as being the glitzy and most glamorous event as their recent success in Miami showed and Norris is central to their image - and McLaren's.\n\nThe energetic and motor-obsessed babyface of the sport has never looked unnerved by driving for McLaren and settled quickly in the sport, making podiums along the way but always falling short until passing the chequered flag first on Sunday.\n\n110 starts for McLaren finally came to their best moment yet in the season's seventh race of the calendar and Norris can now look to soaking in the American sunshine while toasting a first glorious GP victory.\n\nHis age and combined millionaire status make celebrations a grander affair with Norris renowned for occasions where even recently he got injured accidentally while playing around partying.\n\nA night out in Amsterdam, Holland ahead of the Miami event saw Norris sustain a gruesome facial injury and was pictured sporting a cut on his face while on board a boat in the Dutch capital, having seemingly revelled in the King's Day celebrations.\n\nImages quickly circulated on social media showing Norris, 24, with a bloodied bandage stretched across his face - although he appeared in good spirits.\n\nAny signs of pain born from that injury were quickly doused in champagne by Red Bull's, Verstappen and Ferrari driver Charles LeClerc on the podium as the three celebrate and toasted to their success.\n\nNorris is an avid sports lover away from the racetrack and indulges in a busy lifestyle\n\nLando Norris was first spotted with Corceiro in Monaco in May 2023 via social media\n\nNorris shares a close friendship with Red Bull's F1 reigning world champion Max Verstappen (left)\n\nMarks of Norris' face injury suffered while partying in Amsterdam in the build-up to race weekend could be seen while he celebrated\n\nNorris ended his 110-race wait for a first Grand Prix victory by winning in America on Sunday\n\nNorris' popularity amongst his fellow competitors was evident more than ever to see at the end of the race as he embraced several drivers with whom he has become close-friends with over the years of lining up on the track alongside one another.\n\nMercedes driver George Russell - who finished eighth overall in Miami - put his arm around Norris as the pair enjoyed a brief moment of friendly conversation together amidst the chaos of post-race procedures and celebrations.\n\nFormer McLaren team-mate and now-RB Formula One Team driver - Daniel Ricciardo - was also pictured looking delighted while sharing a lengthy hug with Norris in the pits.\n\nMcLaren chief, Brown, looked like a father full of pride when he roughly grabbed Norris and hugged his star driver who has finally delivered grand prix success for the team with a stunning win against the odds.\n\nAway from the track and once he has had time to revel in celebrations Stateside, Norris will likely return to Monaco and try to settle back in his usual routine where he leads a sports-obsessed lifestyle aimed at bearing success.\n\nNorris' social media channels shows he is a lover of fast-growing sport Paddel and golf, where he strikes a unique fashion sense as he takes time away from racing.\n\nNorris and McLaren team principal Zak Brown (left) shared an emotional hug after his win\n\nNorris has quickly become a figurehead for McLaren to put their faith into as his Miami victory proves\n\nNorris met with former United States president Donald Trump who is currently trying to rally support ahead of this year's election\n\nNorris starred for McLaren as he passed the chequered flag first at an eventful race in Miami\n\nNorris and his close-friend and Mercedes star George Russell shared a warm brief interaction after his win\n\nThe riches of his McLaren contract reward him with up to \u00a320million-a-year, while his ever-growing profile as a rising social media star - where he often collaborates in videos with celebrity YouTubers - brings further endorsements give him the luxuries you'd expect from a F1 superstar.\n\nSpeaking to Jenson Button after the race yesterday he said: 'About time. F***! Sorry! What a race! It's been a long time coming. Finally, I've managed to do it.\n\n'I'm so happy for my whole team. I finally delivered for them. Long day, tough race. Finally on top, so I'm over the moon. The whole weekend has been good. I've had some little setbacks along the way but I knew on Friday we had the pace.\n\n'Thanks to, everyone. I'll give a shout-out to my mum and dad of course.' Sky quickly apologised after the interview for Norris' hilarious x-rated outburst.\n\nHis time in Formula One is still relatively only at it's beginning and while much has been discussed about Norris' It was a cool moment.\"\n\nNorris had started to earn the reputation as F1's nearly man prior to his victory in the Sunshine State.\n\nA fan heckled Norris in Australia in March after the McLaren man became the first driver in the sport's history to stand on the podium as many as 14 times without taking to the top step.\n\n\"When are you going to win a race Lando?\" yelled the punter. Norris replied with the middle finger and the unsavoury exchange was splattered all over social media.\n\nNorris said after his Miami success: \"I never lost the faith. I never lost the belief that I could go out there and do it.\n\n\"I go on Instagram and I like all the comments of people abusing me. I love it. More than anything, it makes me smile - especially (the meme) 'Lando No-wins'.\n\n\"So to prove those people wrong and to prove to people that didn't think I could go out and do it, and then go out and do it, has put an even bigger smile on my face. I thank all of them.\"\n\nNorris was propelled on to the road to glory when Kevin Magnussen punted Logan Sargeant off the track and a safety car was deployed, allowing the British driver to stop for new tyres.\n\nAnd Norris - boosted by a significant McLaren upgrade - held his nerve at the restart to keep title favourite Max Verstappen behind before finishing nearly eight seconds clear to provide hope that he could yet offer a challenge to the Dutchman in his all-conquering Red Bull machine.\n\n\"I said at the beginning of the year we could win a race and lot of people doubted that,\" added Norris, who will be back in action at the Emilia Romagna Grand Prix in Imola on May 19.\n\n\"I am not sure I would have won today without the upgrades and without the hard work that the team has been putting in. But I would like to say it's the start.\n\n\"Now I'm already hungry for more. We'll keep our heads down, we'll keep pushing, and I'm sure we can be here a lot more often.\"", "source": {"uri": "thenorthernecho.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Northern Echo"}, {"uri": "8112998373", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "01:54:23", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T01:54:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T01:53:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/sports-games/2928537-motor-racing-from-trump-to-verstappen-everyone-celebrates-norris-win", "title": "Motor racing-From Trump to Verstappen everyone celebrates Norris win | Sports-Games", "body": "It is doubtful there has been a more popular winner of a Formula One race in recent years than McLaren's Lando Norris, who was celebrated by everyone for Max Verstappen to Donald Trump following his victory at the Miami Grand Prix on Sunday. It was a long overdue triumph for Norris, who held the record for most podiums without a win (15), including an agonising eight runner-up finishes, in 110 grand prix making the likeable Briton easy to root for.\n\nIt is doubtful there has been a more popular winner of a Formula One race in recent years than McLaren's Lando Norris, who was celebrated by everyone for Max Verstappen to Donald Trump following his victory at the Miami Grand Prix on Sunday.\n\nIt was a long overdue triumph for Norris, who held the record for most podiums without a win (15), including an agonising eight runner-up finishes, in 110 grand prix making the likeable Briton easy to root for. Even Verstappen, Red Bull's triple world champion who hates to lose and was denied a hat-trick of Miami wins by the McLaren driver, was among the first to congratulate Norris, who was mobbed by his team, crowd surfed along pit land and drenched in a shower of champagne.\n\n\"It was a long time coming, and I'm very happy to be beaten by Lando today,\" smiled a genuinely pleased Verstappen. \"He definitely deserved it. \"It's great winning your first race. It's always quite emotional. It brings you back to all the days that you worked towards your dream of being on the podium.\"\n\nFormer U.S. president Donald Trump, who visited the McLaren garage prior to the race, was delighted to back a winner, telling Norris later he was his lucky charm. \"He saw me after and he came to congratulate me,\" said Norris, who had told his grandmother before coming to Miami that he was going to win a race. \"He (Trump) said he was my lucky charm because it was my win, but I don't know if he's going to come to more races.\"\n\nNorris's mother and father were ecstatic, though they weren't in Miami to witness the moment. \"The cider's flowing in Somerset! A big celebration,\" Adam Norris told Sky Sports. \"I was working out it's probably about 900 races I've been to over the last 16 years.\n\n\"It's interesting knowing as a parent how many hours you put in, supporting them. \"I counted out 350 weekends away and all the races on different weekends.\n\n\"It's brilliant. So happy for him.\" Anthony Hamilton, another father instrumental in the success of his son - seven-times world champion Lewis - also texted Norris with congratulations.\n\nWhile Norris was long overdue for a maiden win his wait was not the longest. World champions Jenson Button needed 113 races before his first win and Nico Rosberg 111.\n\nRed Bull's Sergio Perez holds the record of 190 races before his visit to the top of the podium and it took Ferrari's Carlos Sainz 150 and Mark Webber 130. Norris was still finalising plans on how he was going to celebrate his maiden victory, but he was already thinking about a second win.\n\n\"This only happens once when you take your first win. Tonight is going to be a good night,\" said Norris, confirming team boss Zak Brown had delayed the flight home until Monday so there would be a proper celebration. \"I would like to say it's the start, and now we're really hungry for more. {"uri": "8113227407", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "06:09:33", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T06:09:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T06:06:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.irishmirror.ie/sport/other-sport/formula-one/breaking-miami-gp-result-lando-32742323", "title": "Lando Norris beats Max Verstappen at Miami GP to finally win first F1 race", "body": "Lando Norris finally tasted victory in Formula 1 at the 110th attempt as he proved at the Miami Grand Prix that Max Verstappen is not invincible.\n\nYes, he got a huge slice of luck from the safety car as it came out after Verstappen had pitted for fresh tyres. But he took full advantage and beat the Red Bull for pace in his upgraded McLaren.\n\nIt is the first time Verstappen has been beaten in a race he has finished since last year's Singapore Grand Prix, won by Carlos Sainz. And Norris ' success will give everyone on the grid, not just himself, the confidence of knowing that Red Bull can be beaten in a straight fight.\n\nMcLaren were showing good pace but Verstappen led the race fairly comfortably for the first half. Norris inherited the lead temporarily after the Dutchman, along with Norris' team-mate Oscar Piastri and Ferrari's Charles Leclerc, pitted for new tyres.\n\nBut he was able to grab a cheap pitstop when Kevin Magnussen took out home hero Logan Sargeant at half distance. The Williams was buried into the barrier which required work from the marshals and so the race was neutralised, presenting the Briton with his chance.\n\nHe would have been worried when the safety car picked up Verstappen instead of him - the whole pack had to be let through so that Norris could be the lead car before the race could get going again. And that presented everyone behind him with the chance to light up their tyres.\n\nBut he still had the grip to hold off Verstappen when the green flags were waved. And once he had made sure of the lead he never looked back, breaking the DRS barrier in time to make sure the Red Bull wasn't able to open its rear wing.\n\nPrevious experience left everyone feeling it may be inevitable that Verstappen would close in. But as each lap ticked by the gap between them grew rather than shrunk - Norris was in the groove and the championship leader was getting flustered.\n\nHe hasn't been happy with the grip he was getting from the rear end of his car all weekend. And he was again on the radio complaining about the balance of his car, as it dawned on him that he was going to be beaten.\n\nWith 10 laps left, Norris' had stretched out his advantage to five seconds. And with each completed trip around the Miami track he was making it more and more comfortable, before letting out a cheer of equal parts elation and relief as he finally achieved his boyhood dream and became a Formula 1 race winner.", "source": {"uri": "irishmirror.ie", "dataType": "news", "title": "Irish mirror"}, "authors": [{"uri": "daniel_moxon@irishmirror.ie", "name": "Daniel Moxon", {"uri": "8112919303", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "23:52:22", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T23:52:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T23:51:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.crash.net/f1/news/1047990/1/max-verstappen-flying-lando-norris-definitely-deserves-miami-f1-win", "title": "Max Verstappen: \"Flying\" Lando Norris \"definitely deserves\" Miami F1", "body": "Max Verstappen has conceded that Lando Norris simply \"had more pace\" and deserved to take his maiden F1 victory at the Miami Grand Prix.\n\nVerstappen controlled the race from pole position in the early stages of the race in Miami, building a three-second lead over McLaren's Oscar Piastri.\n\nAfter clattering the bollard, Red Bull called Verstappen into the pit lane shortly after to switch him onto the hards.\n\nAt that point in the race, Norris had yet to stop but showed great speed as he set numerous fastest laps.\n\nThe Safety Car then played into Norris' hands, allowing him to jump Verstappen and the two Ferraris through the pit stops.\n\nNorris dominated the race following the Safety Car to take his first F1 victory.\n\nReflecting on the race, Verstappen felt Norris was simply the quicker driver out on track.\n\n\"You win, you lose. I think we're all used to that in racing, right? Today was just a bit tricky,\" he said. \"I think already on the mediums, it didn't feel fantastic. We were pulling away but not like it should be and once we made the pit stop and I heard the lap times the McLarens were doing, I was like, 'wow, that's pretty quick.\n\n\"Once they switched onto the hard tyre, they just had more pace, and especially Lando, he was flying. It was incredibly difficult for us on that stint, but if a bad day is P2, I take it.\n\n\"I'm very happy for Lando. It's been a long time coming and it's not going to be his last one, so he definitely deserves it today.\n\n\"I mean understeer, oversteer, just very low grip on four wheels, and that's something that we have to understand.\"\n\nMcLaren had introduced a significant upgrade for the race in Miami which was on Norris' car.\n\nVerstappen acknowledged that Red Bull has \"work to do\" to ensure they're more competitive at Imola in two weeks' time.\n\n\"They came with an upgrade,\" he added. \"For sure it looks like it works, right? So we have a bit of work to do from our side. I think definitely it wasn't our strongest weekend in terms of race pace, but we'll analyse it all and we'll try to come back stronger from it.\"", "source": {"uri": "crash.net", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8113602248", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "10:30:57", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T10:30:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T10:29:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/lando-norris-donald-trump-told-102615826.html", "title": "Lando Norris: Donald Trump told me he was my 'lucky charm' after first F1 win", "body": "Donald Trump told Lando Norris that he was his \"lucky charm\" following the British driver's maiden victory at the Miami Grand Prix.\n\nIn his 110th attempt, Norris captured the Formula One win that had so far proved elusive until Sunday's star-studded race at the Hard Rock Stadium in Florida.\n\nThe 24-year-old Bristolian rearranged his travel plans to stay in Miami an extra night and celebrate becoming the 21st British driver to enter the F1 winner's circle.\n\nNorris' triumph came three-and-a-half hours after former United States president Trump was given a guided tour of the car which would carry him to glory by McLaren's chief executive Zak Brown.\n\n\"I didn't see him (Trump) in the garage ahead of the race because I was busy preparing, but he came and saw me after to congratulate me,\" said Norris.\n\n\"He said he was my lucky charm because it was my first win so I don't know if he's going to come to more races now.\n\n\"Donald is someone you have to have respect for in many ways, and I guess it was an honour for him to come up to me and to take the time out of his life to acknowledge what I've done. It was a cool moment.\"\n\nNorris had started to earn the reputation as F1's nearly man prior to his victory in the Sunshine State.\n\nA fan heckled Norris in Australia in March after the McLaren man became the first driver in the sport's history to stand on the podium as many as 14 times without taking to the top step.\n\n\"When are you going to win a race Lando?\" yelled the punter. Norris replied with the middle finger and the unsavoury exchange was splattered all over social media.\n\nNorris said after his Miami success: \"I never lost the faith. I never lost the belief that I could go out there and do it.\n\n\"I go on Instagram and I like all the comments of people abusing me. I love it. More than anything, it makes me smile - especially (the meme) 'Lando No-wins'.\n\n\"So to prove those people wrong and to prove to people that didn't think I could go out and do it, and then go out and do it, has put an even bigger smile on my face. I thank all of them.\"\n\nNorris was propelled on to the road to glory when Kevin Magnussen punted Logan Sargeant off the track and a safety car was deployed, allowing the British driver to stop for new tyres.\n\nAnd Norris - boosted by a significant McLaren upgrade - held his nerve at the restart to keep title favourite Max Verstappen behind before finishing nearly eight seconds clear to provide hope that he could yet offer a challenge to the Dutchman in his all-conquering Red Bull machine.\n\n\"I said at the beginning of the year we could win a race and lot of people doubted that,\" added Norris, who will be back in action at the Emilia Romagna Grand Prix in Imola on May 19.\n\n\"I am not sure I would have won today without the upgrades and without the hard work that the team has been putting in. But I would like to say it's the start.\n\n\"Now I'm already hungry for more. We'll keep our heads down, we'll keep pushing, and I'm sure we can be here a lot more often.\"", "source": {"uri": "sports.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo Sports"}, "authors": [], But he took full advantage and beat the Red Bull for pace in his upgraded McLaren.\n\nIt is the first time Verstappen has been beaten in a race he has finished since last year's Singapore Grand Prix, won by Carlos Sainz. And Norris' success will give everyone on the grid, not just himself, the confidence of knowing that Red Bull can be beaten in a straight fight.\n\nMcLaren were showing good pace but Verstappen led the race fairly comfortably for the first half. Norris inherited the lead temporarily after the Dutchman, along with Norris' team-mate Oscar Piastri and Ferrari's Charles Leclerc, pitted for new tyres.\n\nBut he was able to grab a cheap pitstop when Kevin Magnussen took out home hero Logan Sargeant at half distance. The Williams was buried into the barrier which required work from the marshals and so the race was neutralised, presenting the Briton with his chance.\n\nHe would have been worried when the safety car picked up Verstappen instead of him - the whole pack had to be let through so that Norris could be the lead car before the race could get going again. And that presented everyone behind him with the chance to light up their tyres.\n\nBut he still had the grip to hold off Verstappen when the green flags were waved. And once he had made sure of the lead he never looked back, breaking the DRS barrier in time to make sure the Red Bull wasn't able to open its rear wing.\n\nThis article contains affiliate links, we will receive a commission on any sales we generate from it. Charles Leclerc crossed the line in third, while a grid penalty for Carlos Sainz has dropped him to fifth with Sergio Perez moving up to fourth.\n\nNorris was congratulated by a succession of his peers as McLaren celebrated jubilantly after the race. The appreciation continued into the post-race interviews, with Hamilton, who finished inside the top-six for the first time this season, lavishing praise on Norris and urging him to stay in Miami.\n\n\"Honestly I am so happy for Lando,\" Hamilton said. \"I just told him he needs to stay tonight and he is going to try and change his flight. He has got to [stay], he has just won a race.\n\n\"It's such a special moment to win your first grand prix and obviously I started at McLaren so I am happy to see them back at the top, it has been a long time.\"\n\nNorris was due to fly back to England after the race, but confirmed himself that his flight had been changed to Monday so that he can toast his maiden victory.\n\n\"I was meant to fly [tonight], but Zak [Brown] just told me we fly tomorrow,\" Norris revealed. \"I'm not going to sleep - I'm going all the way! I might have just a scratch on my nose tomorrow, but I don't care. This only happens once, when you're taking your first win.\n\nLando Norris celebrates winning the Miami Grand Prix\n\n\"It's nice that it was here at Miami - I was kind of hoping it would be at Silverstone but I'll try to do it there as well. Tonight is going to be a good night.\"\n\nVerstappen, who was beaten by the speed of Norris over the 57 laps, was gracious in defeat and admitted he was pleased for the Brit to finally get over the line and win his first grand prix.\n\n\"If I get beaten, it's great that it has been done by Lando,\" said Verstappen. \"He deserves it. It's been a long time coming and it's going to be the first of many.\n\n\"Maybe it's also a bit of relief for him that he has that win now, who knows what's going to happen next? But for sure they had a strong weekend. Maybe it was a little bit messy still [on Saturday] but today they were flying - and especially Lando was flying. So definitely very happy for him.\"\n\nThis article contains affiliate links, we will receive a commission on any sales we generate from it. {"uri": "8112863826", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "22:28:40", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T22:28:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T22:27:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://lacrossetribune.com/sports/professional/auto-racing/norris-verstappen-f1-miami-mclaren-red-bull-ricciardo-hamilton-sargeant/article_39400784-0f65-57ce-8d0c-ae13a309410b.html", "title": "Norris earns 1st F1 victory, ends Verstappen's dominance", "body": "JENNA FRYER Associated Press\n\nMIAMI GARDENS, Fla. -- Lando Norris needed 110 starts and a mistake by Max Verstappen to earn his first ever Formula 1 race on Sunday and end Verstappen's dominance at the Miami Grand Prix.\n\nVerstappen, who started from the pole and won Saturday's sprint race, was out front when he hit a chicane and knocked a cone out of place on the circuit. It forced the three-time reigning F1 champion to pit and gave Norris the lead.\n\nThe 24-year-old driver for McLaren then controlled the race to give the organization its first win since a Daniel Ricciardo victory in 2021. It also made him the second British driver in F1 history to be feted on the podium by \"God Save the King.\" George Russell in 2022 is the only other British driver to win outside of Queen Elizabeth's reign; Russell's victory in Brazil came two months after Queen Elizabeth's death.\n\nWith about 10 laps to go, Norris realized the race was his to lose when his lead over Verstappen hit 5 seconds.\n\nPeople are also reading... La Crosse orders City Brewery to stop the smells; daily fines begin Monday Bellin Gundersen Health System files trademark application for Emplify Health name, logo Steve Cahalan: Sparta gets a new boutique, while downtown La Crosse will see a new cafe Steve Cahalan: NOM Sips & Eats cafe to open in downtown La Crosse Amtrak adds second train between Twin Cities, Chicago; Borealis service will stop in La Crosse, Tomah, Winona Steve Cahalan: Valley View Mall to add more tenants, 7 Brew Coffee drive-thrus coming to La Crosse Toad's Cove ready to reopen as Centerville's only convenience store 1 year after devastating fire La Crosse man arrested for possession of fentanyl during traffic stop Onalaska teen faces charges for uploading child pornography Steve Cahalan: Burlington Store to open in October in Onalaska 'Slow, thoughtful process': Emplify Health to become new name of Gundersen, Bellin group DOJ: Mount Horeb shooter brought pellet gun to school Mount Horeb shooting: Students 'saw something' as teen approached school, notified staff La Crosse County home prices skyrocket 21% over last year; fewer sales than year prior Melrose man faces charges of stalking and vandalism in jealous rage\n\n\"Five seconds?\" Norris radioed his team. \"Am I alive?\"\n\nIndeed he was as an ecstatic McLaren squad celebrated a rare victory on a weekend in which it debuted significant upgrades on its two cars. McLaren now has 13 wins in races in the United States -- tying a record with Ferrari -- but it was the first on American soil since Lewis Hamilton at Circuit of the Americas in 2012.\n\nNorris' final margin of victory was 7.6-seconds over Verstappen of Red Bull.\n\n\"I love you all, thank you so much!\" Norris screamed on his radio. \"We did it! We did it!\"\n\nNorris said he knew when he entered the track he'd win at Miami.\n\n\"Finally. I am so happy. I knew it. I knew it when I came in this morning,\" Norris said. \"And I nailed it.\"\n\nMcLaren has now won an F1, Formula E and IndyCar race in the past two months. Norris is the first driver since Carlos Sainz Jr. to beat Verstappen this season -- and Verstappen was eliminated from that race in Melbourne with a mechanical failure.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\n\"You win. You lose. I think we're all a bit used to that in racing,\" Verstappen said. \"Is a bad day P2? I will take it. I am happy for Lando, it's been a long time coming and there's more to come from him.\"\n\nNorris was swarmed by the McLaren crew after the race as team members lifted him and seemed to crowd surf him until he finally got to boss Zak Brown, who wrapped Norris in a bearhug.\n\nMcLaren, before the start of the race, hosted former President Donald Trump, who chatted with F1 officials from inside the McLaren garage. When he made his way toward the starting grid, fans began chanting \"USA! USA!\" and Trump pumped his first in approval.\n\nFerrari drivers Charles Leclerc and Sainz finished third and fourth and was followed by Sergio Perez of Red Bull.\n\nHamilton was sixth for Mercedes, Yuki Tsunoda of Red Bull's junior team was seventh and Russell was eighth for Mercedes. Fernando Alonso of Aston Martin and Esteban Ocon of Alpine rounded out the top 10. Ocon did it with team investors Patrick Mahomes and Travis Kelce of the Kansas City Chiefs in attendance.\n\nAbout halfway through the race, Logan Sargeant crashed and brought out the safety car that forced the Pompano Beach native out of his car. The 23-year-old and only American driver on the F1 grid is clinging to his seat with Williams as speculation is rampant he could be replaced before the end of his second season.\n\nIt marked Sargeant's second consecutive last-place finish at his home race.\n\nThe Sargeant crash handed control of race strategy to McLaren, who held the lead with Norris at the time of the caution. Norris had taken over the lead when Verstappen was forced to pit from the lead after hitting a chicane that knocked a cone onto the racing surface.\n\nAs Red Bull was looking for any damage to Verstappen's front wing, a race marshal entered the circuit and scooped up the cone as F1 avoided having to use the safety car for the incident. But just moments later, Kevin Magnussen made contact with Williams and it gave McLaren the chance to strategize a victory over Verstappen.\n\nFor Magnussen, it marked another bad day in a long weekend in which the Haas driver was accused of unsportsmanlike conduct for his strategy in Saturday's sprint race.\n\nLove 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nTags Dcc Wire Lee-national Be the first to {"uri": "8113202508", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "05:44:01", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T05:44:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T05:43:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://www.rediff.com/sports/report/who-is-lando-norris-f1/20240506.htm", "title": "Who is Lando Norris?", "body": "IMAGE: McLaren's Lando Norris celebrates winning the Miami Grand Prix on the podium with the trophy. Photograph: Marco Bello/Reuters\n\nIt is doubtful there has been a more popular winner of a Formula One race in recent years than McLaren's Lando Norris, who was celebrated by everyone for Max Verstappen to Donald Trump following his victory at the Miami Grand Prix on Sunday.\n\nIMAGE: Red Bull Racing driver Max Verstappen (left) and Ferrari driver Charles Leclerc (right) spray champagne on race winner McLaren driver Lando Norris. Photograph: John David Mercer-USA TODAY Sports via Reuters\n\nIt was a long overdue triumph for Norris, who held the record for most podiums without a win (15), including an agonising eight runner-up finishes, in 110 grand prix making the likeable Briton easy to root for.\n\nIMAGE: Republican Presidential candidate and former U.S. President Donald Trump ahead of the Miami Grand. Photograph: Brian Snyder/Reuters\n\nEven Verstappen, Red Bull's triple world champion who hates to lose and was denied a hat-trick of Miami wins by the McLaren driver, was among the first to congratulate Norris, who was mobbed by his team, crowd surfed along pit land and drenched in a shower of champagne.\n\nIMAGE: McLaren driver Lando Norris (4) celebrates with his team after winning the F1 Miami Grand Prix at Miami International Autodrome. Photograph: Peter Casey-USA TODAY Sports via Reuters\n\n\"It was a long time coming, and I'm very happy to be beaten by Lando today,\" smiled a genuinely pleased Verstappen. \"He definitely deserved it.\n\n\"It's great winning your first race. It's always quite emotional. It brings you back to all the days that you worked towards your dream of being on the podium.\"\n\nFormer U.S. president Donald Trump, who visited the McLaren garage prior to the race, was delighted to back a winner, telling Norris later he was his lucky charm.\n\n\"He saw me after and he came to congratulate me,\" said Norris, who had told his grandmother before coming to Miami that he was going to win a race. \"He (Trump) said he was my lucky charm because it was my win, but I don't know if he's going to come to more races.\"\n\nNorris's mother and father were ecstatic, though they weren't in Miami to witness the moment.\n\n\"The cider's flowing in Somerset! A big celebration,\" Adam Norris told Sky Sports. \"I was working out it's probably about 900 races I've been to over the last 16 years.\n\n\"It's interesting knowing as a parent how many hours you put in, supporting them.\n\n\"I counted out 350 weekends away and all the races on different weekends.\n\n\"It's brilliant. So happy for him.\"\n\nAnthony Hamilton, another father instrumental in the success of his son - seven-times world champion Lewis - also texted Norris with congratulations.\n\nWhile Norris was long overdue for a maiden win his wait was not the longest.\n\nWorld champions Jenson Button needed 113 races before his first win and Nico Rosberg 111.\n\nRed Bull's Sergio Perez holds the record of 190 races before his visit to the top of the podium and it took Ferrari's Carlos Sainz 150 and Mark Webber 130.\n\nNorris was still finalising plans on how he was going to celebrate his maiden victory, but he was already thinking about a second win.\n\n\"This only happens once when you take your first win. Tonight is going to be a good night,\" said Norris, confirming team boss Zak Brown had delayed the flight home until Monday so there would be a proper celebration. \"I would like to say it's the start, and now we're really hungry for more. We'll keep our heads down and keep pushing.\"\n\nIMAGE: Donald Trump alongside FIA president Mohammed Ben Sulayem. Photograph: Brian Snyder/Reuters\n\nIMAGE: Singer, Marc Anthony sings the National Anthem before the Miami Grand Prix. Photograph: John David Mercer-USA TODAY Sports via Reuters\n\nMore about Lando Norris\n\nLando Norris, although not necessarily named after the famed Star Wars character Lando Calrissian, embodies a blend of flair and tenacity that defines his racing persona.\n\nMcLaren nurtured this British talent for two years before thrusting him into Formula 1's elite ranks in 2019.\n\nKnown for his electrifying performances in lower categories, Norris seamlessly transitioned into the pinnacle of motorsport, showcasing a knack for pole positions and thrilling wheel-to-wheel battles.\n\nDespite being paired with the seasoned campaigner Carlos Sainz in his debut season, Norris held his ground admirably, outperforming the Spaniard in qualifying and consistently scoring points, narrowly missing out on a top-10 championship finish. His breakthrough came in 2020 with a maiden podium, followed by more podiums in subsequent seasons, including a near-victory in Russia 2021.\n\nHe outshone his more experienced teammate, Daniel Ricciardo, consolidating his position as a force to be reckoned with in Formula 1.\n\nBeyond the racetrack, Norris exudes a humble charm and displays his artistic flair by designing and painting his own racing gear as a personal hobby.\n\nPhotographs curated by Manisha Kotian/Rediff.com", "source": {"uri": "rediff.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Rediff.com India Ltd."}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8113017923", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "02:26:11", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T02:26:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T02:19:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://www.onmanorama.com/sports/motor-sports/2024/05/06/mclaren-norris-wins-miami-grand-prix-f1-win.html", "title": "McLaren's Norris wins Miami Grand Prix for first F1 win", "body": "Miami: McLaren's Lando Norris capitalised on a bit of good fortune to win the Miami Grand Prix on Sunday, holding off Red Bull's triple world champion Max Verstappen for his first Formula One victory.\n\nIt was a long overdue triumph for the Briton who held the record for most podiums without a win (15), having finished runner-up an agonising eight times in 110 grand prix.\n\nVerstappen had seemed well placed to claim a fifth win in six races until a midway crash allowed McLaren to cash in on a safety car period, with Norris pitting and coming out with the lead.\n\nSeeking a Miami hat-trick of wins, the Dutchman filled Norris's mirrors on the restart but his Red Bull could offer no challenge as the McLaren pulled clear.\n\nFerrari's Charles Leclerc completed the podium, coming home third ahead of teammate Carlos Sainz, who was later penalised five seconds for his involvement in a collision with McLaren's Oscar Piastri dropping the Spaniard to fifth.\n\nThe penalty moved Verstappen's Red Bull teammate Sergio Perez up one spot to fourth.\n\n\"About time! What a race. It's been a long time coming. Finally, I've managed to do it,\" Norris told Sky Sports. \"I'm so happy for my whole team. I finally delivered for them.\n\n\"Long day, tough race. Finally on top, so I'm over the moon. I'm just proud. A lot of people doubted me along the way.\n\n\"I've made a lot of mistakes over my last five years in my short career but today we put it all together.\"\n\nIn a season dominated by Red Bull, it was a hugely popular win by the 24-year-old Briton.\n\nPulling into the pit lane Norris was mobbed by his team, congratulated by the other drivers and cheered by a massive crowd at the Miami International Autodrome that included former US president Donald Trump, who visited the McLaren garage prior to the race.\n\nUntil Sunday it had been another dominant weekend for Red Bull as Verstappen topped the timesheets in the only practice session and sprint qualifying on Friday and then won the sprint race and took pole on Saturday.\n\nHis second place in the Grand Prix had little impact on the drivers' standings as he continues to hold a commanding 35-point lead over his Perez.\n\nMercedes' seven-times world champion Lewis Hamilton was sixth and RB's Yuki Tsunoda seventh followed by George Russell in the other Mercedes.\n\nAston Martin's double world champion Fernando Alonso grabbed the ninth while Esteban Ocon earned struggling Alpine their first point of the season crossing 10th.\n\nStarting from pole, Verstappen was in command through the first 20 laps but was unable to open up more than a three-second lead on Piastri.\n\nAs the race reached the midway mark Verstappen made a rare unpressured mistake, going wide and hitting a bollard that broke and was left on the track, bringing out the virtual safety car.\n\nVerstappen was then quickly into the pits with Piastri, who had already pitted, assuming the lead. With the first round of pit stops about to be completed and Verstappen about to retake the lead, McLaren got a lucky break.\n\nWilliams' Logan Sargeant spun into the wall, bringing out the safety car and allowing Norris to pit and come out still in the lead, which he never let go.\n\n\"You win, you lose,\" said Verstappen. \"I think we're all used to that in racing, right?\n\n\"Today was just a bit tricky. If a bad day is P2, I take it.\n\n\"I'm very happy for Lando. It's been a long time coming and it's not going to be his last one, so he definitely deserves it today.\"", "source": {"uri": "onmanorama.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "OnManorama"}, "authors":
