It was a cool moment.\"\n\nI never lost the faith. I never lost the belief that I could go out there and do it.\n\nNorris had started to earn the reputation as F1's nearly man prior to his victory in the Sunshine State.\n\nA fan heckled Norris in Australia in March after the McLaren man became the first driver in the sport's history to stand on the podium as many as 14 times without taking to the top step.\n\n\"When are you going to win a race Lando?\" yelled the punter. Norris replied with the middle finger and the unsavoury exchange was splattered all over social media.\n\nNorris said after his Miami success: \"I never lost the faith. I never lost the belief that I could go out there and do it.\n\n\"I go on Instagram and I like all the comments of people abusing me. I love it. More than anything, it makes me smile - especially (the meme) 'Lando No-wins'.\n\n\"So to prove those people wrong and to prove to people that didn't think I could go out and do it, and then go out and do it, has put an even bigger smile on my face. I thank all of them.\"\n\nNorris was propelled on to the road to glory when Kevin Magnussen punted Logan Sargeant off the track and a safety car was deployed, allowing the British driver to stop for new tyres.\n\nAnd Norris - boosted by a significant McLaren upgrade - held his nerve at the restart to keep title favourite Max Verstappen behind before finishing nearly eight seconds clear to provide hope that he could yet offer a challenge to the Dutchman in his all-conquering Red Bull machine.\n\n\"I said at the beginning of the year we could win a race and lot of people doubted that,\" added Norris, who will be back in action at the Emilia Romagna Grand Prix in Imola on May 19.\n\n\"I am not sure I would have won today without the upgrades and without the hard work that the team has been putting in. But I would like to say it's the start.\n\n\"Now I'm already hungry for more. it allowed him to make a \"free\" pit stop and return to the track as a leader without losing any time.\n\nThe drama started when the safety car was placed incorrectly in front of Max Verstappen rather than race leader Norris.\n\nThis enabled Norris not to lose time at the pit stop.\n\nNotwithstanding the chaos, the 24-year-old never lost his nerve, kept the raging Verstappen at bay once the safety car eventually went in, and pushed with impressive speed, setting his fastest lap multiple times, to finish ahead of Verstappen.\n\nRelated: NASCAR standings, latest Cup Series playoff picture\n\nNorris's win was a defining moment. \"I don't know what I'm feeling! I'm just happy, proud. It feels like it's been a long time coming.\" Norris told Sky Sports F1.\n\n\" I feel like we've had many opportunities. We've been getting closer and closer. We've never been able to put it all together, and today was that day.\"\n\nFinishing in second place, Verstappen complained about how his car had been performing all weekend despite winning the sprint race and being the pole sitter.\n\nThe Dutchman struggled to keep pace with Norris and had to settle for second place, crossing the line 8 seconds after the McLaren driver.\n\nFerrari driver Charles Leclerc finished on the podium as he claimed third place, narrowing Red Bull's advantage and being a mere two seconds behind Verstappen.\n\nAlpine earned their first point of the season, with Esteban Ocon finishing 10th, while Pierre Gasly ended up 12th.\n\nThe team had a very challenging start to the season, but their performance in Miami showed signs of recovery.\n\nAlso Read: NASCAR TV ratings\n\nCarlos Sainz finished in fourth but was downgraded to fifth after a 5-second penalty for an accident with Oscar Piastri, Norris's teammate.\n\nThe Australian's car had front-wing damage, which led him to pit and return at the tail end of the field, finishing in 13th place.\n\nKevin Magnussen was given many penalties during the race. Following the 35-second penalty in the sprint, he was given a further 10-second penalty for an incident with Logan Sargeant.\n\nThen, he was awarded another 20-second penalty for the bad pit stop. {"uri": "8114075754", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "15:45:45", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T15:45:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T15:45:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.autoevolution.com/news/lando-norris-wins-first-ever-f1-grand-prix-and-red-bull-have-a-right-to-be-concerned-233492.html", "title": "Lando Norris Wins First Ever F1 Grand Prix and Red Bull Have a Right To Be Concerned", "body": "9 photosPhoto: McLaren Racing/autoevolutionWhen Lando Norris crossed the finish line at the 2024 Miami Grand Prix, cementing his first-ever win in Formula 1, among the many congratulatory voices there were some who remained skeptical, believing that it was nothing more than a lucky victory, owed entirely to a Safety Car situation. While it's true that Norris took full advantage of the Safety Car, coming into the pits at just the right time, that one incident alone doesn't tell the full story.\n\nMax Verstappen, the man who everyone believed (and rightfully so) would go on to win the race, had every chance to attack Norris after racing resumed, yet the British driver was having none of that, pulling away from the reigning F1 World Champion with surprising ease. Sure, Verstappen spoke about his struggles during the race, but hey, all is fair in love and war, and that McLaren was a genuine rocketship.\n\nYesterday's result also goes to show that Max Verstappen is indeed beatable. Like Agent Smith one said about Neo in The Matrix: \"You see? He's just a man.\"\n\nWhen the checkered flag dropped, Norris crossed the line no fewer than 7.61 seconds ahead of Verstappen, which is a monumental gap. It's usually the type of gap that you'd see between the champ's Red Bull and whoever it is that comes second. This is why Red Bull should be concerned - not because they lost, but rather because they lost by 7.61 seconds. Oh, and because Adrian Newey is leaving. That too.\n\n\"Today was a bit tricky. I think already on the medium [tires] it didn't feel fantastic, we were pulling away but not like it should be. Then once we made a pit stop, I heard what the lap times McLaren were doing and I was like, 'Well, that's pretty quick!\", said Verstappen during his post-race interview.\n\n\"Once they also switched onto the hard tire, they just had more pace, especially Lando he was flying. It was incredibly difficult for us on that stint but if a bad day is P2, I take it,\" he added, before stating how happy he is to see Norris win his first-ever Formula 1 race.\n\nPhoto: McLaren Racing Maybe a little less happy was Ferrari's Carlos Sainz, who started P3 on the grid and was brought into the pits one lap before the Safety Car was called - talk about rotten luck. The Scuderia did get one of their drivers on the podium, but it was Leclerc and not Sainz who finished third.\n\nAs for what Norris had to say following his maiden F1 victory - it was pretty much what you'd expect (happy, grateful, motivated). However, what really surprised me was him stating that he had known since Friday's sessions that they had the pace to compete with Red Bull.\n\nFollowing yesterday's result, Norris moves into fourth place in the 2024 Driver Standings with 83 points. Leclerc is third with 98 points, while Perez and Verstappen have 103, and 136 points, respectively.\n\nNext up on the calendar is the Emilia Romagna Grand Prix at Imola, set to take place on May 19.", However, he is yet to be the best from his own nation, as Lewis Hamilton is still active. This opinion was given by none other than the McLaren star himself, even though he hesitated for a few seconds before making this admission.\n\n\"Are you the best British on the current Formula 1 grid,\" asked Craig Slater in a SkySports lie detector test on Norris. \"Yes,\" replied Norris, which turned out to be a lie on the test machine. Seeing his lie being caught, Norris changed his answer to \"Lewis.\"\n\nStatistically speaking, Hamilton has a mighty lead over Norris, with the former already having 103 wins in his kitty. Meanwhile, Norris is yet to bag an F1 win. Moreover, Hamilton is rated among the greatest ever and is yet to lose his prowess.\n\nOn the other hand, Norris is still trying to find his peak, even though he is also heavily touted as a future F1 champion. But before he is labeled better than Hamilton even in the current space of time, he needs to back himself with results.\n\nAnd that's what Norris would be aiming to get with McLaren this year. If not, then he might start looking to give his services elsewhere even though he has a contract with the Papaya team 'beyond 2025'.\n\nDue to his exploits over the recent years, Lando Norris is one of the most sought-after drivers on the grid. Therefore, to further establish his merit, he needs to win. But under the current Red Bull dominance, picking up wins is far harder than before.\n\nOnly Ferrari's Carlos Sainz has been the non-Red Bull driver to win a race since the start of last season. Thus, showcasing the gap between Red Bull and the rest of the grid. However, McLaren claims to have a better understanding of the regulations this year.\n\nThus, in the development race, they shall be nearer to their rivals as the season progresses. With that level of advancement, Norris can aim to bag a few wins. But for that, they also need to overcome the pace of Ferrari, who also seem to be on an equal footing, if not better.\n\nIn the ongoing Miami GP, McLaren came to Florida with new upgrades. With those, Norris can aim to have a strong result. {"uri": "8114014584", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "15:03:29", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T15:03:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T15:03:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.businesslive.co.za/bd/sport/other-sport/2024-05-06-from-verstappen-to-trump-everyone-celebrates-norris-win/", "title": "From Verstappen to Trump, everyone celebrates Norris win", "body": "Miami -- It is doubtful there has been a more popular winner of a Formula One race in recent years than McLaren's Lando Norris, who was celebrated by everyone from Max Verstappen to Donald Trump after his victory at the Miami Grand Prix on Sunday.\n\nIt was a long overdue triumph for Norris, who held the record for most podiums without a win (15), including an agonising eight runner-up finishes, in 110 grands prix making the likable Briton easy to root for.\n\nEven Verstappen, Red Bull's triple world champion who hates to lose and was denied a hat-trick of Miami wins by the McLaren driver, was among the first to congratulate Norris, who was mobbed by his team, crowd-surfed along pit land and drenched in a shower of champagne.\n\n\"It was a long time coming, and I'm very happy to be beaten by Lando today,\" Verstappen said. \"He definitely deserved it. It's great winning your first race. It's always quite emotional. It brings you back to all the days that you worked towards your dream of being on the podium.\"\n\nFormer US president Donald Trump, who visited the McLaren garage before the race, was delighted to back a winner, telling Norris later he was his lucky charm.\n\n\"He saw me after and he came to congratulate me,\" Norris, who had told his grandmother before coming to Miami that he was going to win a race, said. \"He [Trump] said he was my lucky charm because it was my win, but I don't know if he's going to come to more races.\"\n\nNorris's mother and father were ecstatic, though they weren't in Miami to witness the moment.", "source": {"uri": "businesslive.co.za", "dataType": "news", "title": "BusinessLIVE"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/McLaren", "type": {"uri": "8113889466", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "13:39:01", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T13:39:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T13:38:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://theathletic.com/5473873/2024/05/06/f1-miami-gp-takeaways-lando-norris-max-verstappen/", "title": "F1's Miami GP vibes deliver results as Lando triumphs: Race takeaways", "body": "The 2024 Miami Grand Prix arrived with all the beach vibes pomp and celebrity circumstance you'd expect from one of F1's glitziest race locales. Then, the racing and result lived up to the hype as a sell-out crowd watched Lando Norris secure his first F1 win.\n\nWe rarely get a race that features good overtaking, intriguing strategy and a new winner all in one sitting. The Miami GP turned on a dime when a mid-race safety car caught out Max Verstappen after he'd already pitted for new tires. Norris pitted from the front, defended well off the restart and rode his fresher tires to the most monumental moment of his young career.\n\nThe racing behind him wasn't half bad, either. Tire degradation, pit strategy and a tricky circuit conspired to make for (by far) the best Miami GP we've seen in its three years of running.\n\nIn hindsight, Norris should've yelled, \"In 43 days!\" as he flipped that fan the bird (per Norris, it was a friendly exchange). Just to be accurate.\n\nObviously, nobody expected Norris to get his first F1 win at Miami on Sunday. Sure, some signs were there - McLaren brought a whole host of upgrades to Norris's car, and he was fast enough on Friday that he should've taken sprint pole. But he started P5 in the grand prix on a track that Verstappen has dominated for the past two seasons.\n\nJust like Carlos Sainz's win in Australia, which relied on a rare brake failure on Verstappen's car, Norris' win on Sunday depended on some luck. He needed the pit strategy to work in his favor and Kevin Magnussen to make an overly ambitious move on Logan Sargeant, bringing out the safety car in time for Norris to lead Verstappen with fresher tires.\n\nWith those two strokes of luck bouncing his way, Norris made the most of it with an excellent defensive move on the restart. And then that upgraded McLaren kicked in.\n\n\"Once we made a pit stop and I heard with the lap times the McLarens were doing, I said, well, (laughs) you know, it's pretty quick,\" Verstappen said. \"They just had more pace and especially Lando, he was flying.\"\n\nIt was years of patience and hard work colliding with talent and opportunity. Norris, who holds the record for most podiums before clinching the top spot, is a Formula One race winner.\n\n\"I mean, the whole weekend's been good,\" Norris said. \"You know, I just had some little setbacks along the way. But I knew on Friday we had the pace. (Had) just a couple mistakes, here and there. But today, we managed to put it together. We found the perfect strategy. It all paid off.\"\n\nIf his car doesn't break or he doesn't make a big mistake he can't be overcome, it's essentially become a given that Verstappen will end up on the top step of the podium. That's just how it's gone in F1 over the past two-plus years. It's Verstappen, then everyone else.\n\nNot so on Sunday. For the first time in what feels like an eternity, Verstappen was beaten, and soundly, by a competitor. Sure, you could argue that it all came down to an ill-timed (or well-timed, depending on your perspective). But untimely cautions are part of racing, and when Verstappen had his opportunity to pass Norris once the safety car came off, he couldn't do it. Norris outran him at the end, cruising to a nearly eight-second victory.\n\nSuch defeat is not something Verstappen is used to experiencing.\n\nFor a minute, it looked like Piastri would be the McLaren driver most benefiting from good luck. Sergio P\u00e9rez's Turn 1 lockup didn't just almost take out Verstappen, but it bunched up the field and gave Piastri an opening to zip into P3. After pit stops and the safety car sorted out, Piastri rode in P4 - and with Norris running away from Verstappen out front, McLaren was on tap for its best finish since Silverstone last year.\n\nAlas, a hard fight with Carlos Sainz undid Piastri's strong outing. Late in the race, Sainz poked and prodded at Piastri for P4, putting the move on the McLaren with a deep lunge into Turn 17. The Aussie turned in and clipped his front wing on Sainz's right rear tire. Piastri had to box and finish outside the points in P13.\n\nPiastri said after the race that he hadn't seen a replay of the incident but implied he wasn't thrilled with Sainz's move. He said the two drivers \"weren't particularly close to the apex\" when the contact was made. The stewards investigated after the session and served Sainz a five-second penalty and a penalty point.\n\nStill, iPiastri's race was very strong, even though his McLaren didn't have the same upgrades as Norris's. He has finished in the points in 13 of the last 19 races -- not bad for a 23-year-old in his second F1 season.\n\n\"I think definitely a lot of positives to come from today,\" Piastri said. \"I think, for both of us, the car was really strong. And I think for Lando to win the race on pace and to pull away from Max after the safety car, I think that's a very, very encouraging sign. So, very happy for him and for the whole team.\n\n\"And I think we deserve it. Our trajectory in the last 12 months has been towards this moment.\"\n\nWhat Sargeant needed was a clean race. To make it to the finish without incident. And if all went well, maybe leave his home race having scored his first point(s) on the season. Doing so would've gone a long way to ease some of the pressure on Sargeant at the moment, particularly during a weekend when it emerged a request had been submitted for Mercedes junior Andrea Kimi Antonelli, a possible option for Williams in the future, to get dispensation for a super license before he turns 18 in August.\n\nInstead, Sargeant leaves the Miami GP with another disappointing result (though through no fault of his own). While he may have been the victim of an overly ambitious move by Magnusson that sent him into the tire barriers, it doesn't change the fact that Sargeant departs Miami with both a damaged car and no points -- something that's occurred too frequently during his 27-race tenure with the team.\n\nWilliams F1 boss James Vowles said on F1TV this weekend that there was no plan to put Antonelli in the car for the next race at Imola and that the team was evaluating options for drivers to race for both 2025 and 2026, not wanting a one-year deal for whoever gets the seat. Whether Sargeant will get the chance to drive a Williams car through the end of the year remains to be seen.\n\nAfter the race, George Russell offered a brutally honest assessment of Mercedes' pace at this point in the season.\n\n\"We do have a few (upgrades) coming in in the short term, but nothing that's going to transform us into race winners right now,\" said Russell, who finished P8. \"I think we have to accept that we are the fourth fastest team at the moment. And the lap times don't lie, the championship doesn't lie. This is where we are. And as I said, I think we're fighting for the P5 to P8 region, week in, week out.\"\n\nCan't argue with that. Russell finished P8, Lewis Hamilton finished P6. After Norris' win on Sunday, Mercedes is fourth in the championship, 60 points behind McLaren. But we're all about optimism here, so it's fair to point out that Mercedes extracted some hard-earned points from a tough weekend.\n\nHamilton lacked straight-line speed in every Miami session. That led to extended tangles with the midfield Haas cars in the sprint race and the grand prix. (Something you wouldn't have bet on pre-2022.) But he ultimately won both of those battles. Hamilton also couldn't get around P\u00e9rez in the last half of the race on older mediums - but the fact that he breathed down a Red Bull's neck on old tires for that long is a positive sign.\n\nMercedes (and its fans) don't want to hear how a P6 and P8 finish could be a positive. And it's not. Neither driver will be happy with the results. But you can't say the drivers aren't full of fight and extracting everything they can out of those machines.\n\nThe Miami Grand Prix has crafted a well-deserved reputation for being all about the vibes, celebrity sightings and producing an electric atmosphere.\n\nThis was again the case on Sunday. A-listers on site included Kansas City Chiefs teammates Patrick Mahomes and Travis Kelce, famed Hollywood producer Jerry Bruckheimer and singer Camila Cabello. It was particularly festive on the grid pre-race, where thumping music and a lively, sold-out crowd contributed to giving the race a \"big fight feel.\"\n\nAs it has for the past two years, the Miami Grand Prix checked all the boxes that have become synonymous with F1's annual visit to South Florida.", "source": {"uri": "theathletic.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Athletic"}, "authors": {"uri": "8113820767", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "12:55:40", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T12:55:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T12:53:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/formula-1/ferrari-boss-fred-vasseur-gatecrashes-32744954", "title": "Ferrari boss gatecrashes Norris celebrations to cover McLaren star in champagne", "body": "Ferrari boss Fred Vasseur gatecrashed the McLaren celebrations with a bottle of champagne after Lando Norris stormed to a monumental victory at the Miami Grand Prix.\n\nAt the 110th attempt of his five-year career, Norris capitalised on the chance presented to him by a fortuitously timed safety car to beat second-placed Max Verstappen and win his first ever Grand Prix. Charles Leclerc finished third, while a grid penalty for Carlos Sainz dropped him to fifth with Sergio Perez moving to fourth.\n\nDespite failing to win, Verstappen led the congratulations from his rival as, one after another, they gave him a huge hug to celebrate his success. Verstappen heaped praise on the Brit and claimed he \"deserved it\" in his post-race interview, while Lewis Hamilton admitted he was \"so happy for Lando\".\n\nThe McLaren team celebrated their success\n\nAfter receiving his winners' trophy and medal on the podium, Norris and McLaren celebrated with a team photo in front of the garage. Over 50 members of staff were present, including team principal Andrea Stella as McLaren toasted a first Grand Prix win of their own since Monza in 2021.\n\nHowever, after a number of different team photos were taken, bottles of champagne were popped and sprayed in the direction of Norris. Among those joining in the party were Ferrari boss Vasseur, who appeared from behind a photographer with a McLaren cap on his head before darting towards the celebrations.\n\nEven Fred Vasseur was getting involved with the McLaren celebrations\n\nOnce he sprayed his bottle, Vasseur then walked over to pour any remaining last drop of alcohol near Norris and the McLaren media team. Despite both members of his team finishing third and fifth, Vasseur appeared to cut a delighted figure - like most of the circuit - for Norris.\n\nReacting to his success, Norris said: \"About time, huh? What a race. It's been a long time coming but finally I've managed to do it. I'm so happy for my whole team - I've finally delivered for them. It was a long day, a tough race, but I'm finally on top and over the moon.\"\n\nNorris was due to fly back to England after the race, but following advice from Hamilton, he confirmed himself that his flight had been changed to Monday so that he can toast his maiden victory.\n\n\"I was meant to fly [tonight], but Zak [Brown] just told me we fly tomorrow,\" Norris revealed. \"I'm not going to sleep - I'm going all the way! I might have just a scratch on my nose tomorrow, but I don't care. This only happens once, when you're taking your first win.\n\n\"It's nice that it was here at Miami - I was kind of hoping it would be at Silverstone but I'll try to do it there as well. Tonight is going to be a good night.\"\n\nVerstappen, who was beaten by the speed of Norris over the 57 laps, was gracious in defeat. \"If I get beaten, it's great that it has been done by Lando,\" the Dutchman said. \"He deserves it. It's been a long time coming and it's going to be the first of many.\n\n\"Maybe it's also a bit of relief for him that he has that win now, who knows what's going to happen next? But for sure they had a strong weekend. Maybe it was a little bit messy still [on Saturday] but today they were flying - and especially Lando was flying. So definitely very happy for him.\"\n\nThis article contains affiliate links, we will receive a commission on any sales we generate from it. I'm just happy, proud. It feels like it's been a long time coming. I feel like we've had many opportunities. We've been getting closer and closer.\n\n\"We've never been able to put it all together and today was that day. We've been good all weekend. As much as we had some setbacks - Friday Qualifying, the Sprint, not the best Qualifying on Saturday, I stayed positive. And that's rare!\"\n\nHe added: \"It all just came together. We were quick all day. I had a good strategy, a good plan. I stayed out of the way of trouble in Turn One because it was very close. Subscribe now\n\n\"Oscar, reminder Lando is leading the race here, we do not want a safety car here,\" McLaren engineers told Piastri over team radio.\n\nIt capped a nightmare race for Piastri, who was in second place for the opening half of the race before pit strategies and then front wing damage saw him tumble out of contention and out of the top 10.\n\nPiastri ended up finishing 13th, while Ricciardo was two places behind in 15th.\n\nNorris benefited from a stunning restart after a collision between Logan Sargeant and Kevin Magnussen before defending well against Verstappen and holding on for his first career F1 win.\n\n\"About time,\" a delighted Norris said. \"What a race. It's been a long time coming, at last I've been able to do it for my team and deliver for them.\"\n\nVerstappen had to settle for an unusual second place, while Charles Leclerc of Ferrari completed the podium in third.\n\n\"You win, you lose, we are all used to that in racing. Today was just tricky,\" Verstappen said.\n\n\"I'm happy for Lando, it's been a long time coming and it's not going to be his last one. He deserves it today.\"\n\nIt was McLaren's first win since Monza 2021, when Ricciardo hit the top step.\n\n\"I knew on Friday we had the pace,\" Norris said.\n\n\"Today we managed to put it together. {"uri": "8112941780", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "00:25:07", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T00:25:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T00:24:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://thesportsrush.com/f1-news-lando-norris-offers-to-share-his-maiden-f1-win-trophy-with-logan-sargeant-and-kevin-magnussen-for-the-favor-they-did-on-him/", "title": "Lando Norris Offers to Share His Maiden F1 Win Trophy With Logan Sargeant and Kevin Magnussen for the Favor They Did on Him - The SportsRush", "body": "Lando Norris finally bagged his first F1 Grand Prix win. However, his maiden victory in the apex motorsport series might have been influenced by a slight stroke of good fortune. The Briton himself admitted that and is ready to share his trophy and champagne with Logan Sargeant and Kevin Magnussen for granting him his first success.\n\nWhen Max Verstappen had to pit after he knocked a cone, he damaged his front wing and Norris managed to take the race lead from him. The situation got much better when Magnussen knocked Sargeant out of the race. Hence, forcing a safety car that gave a cheap pitstop to the 24-year-old race driver.\n\nAnd for this series of events, Norris, albeit jokingly, offered his trophy to both drivers. \"Today was my day. Today was the day when someone was like 'I'm gonna throw a safety car now.' And it all worked out perfectly. So whoever that person was, I thank them and I share my trophy and champagne with them.\" said Norris to Lawrence Barreto after the race.\n\nSeeing the series of events, there is no doubt Norris should thank Magnussen and Sargeant. However, when all the jokes were done, Norris, in the end, thanked his team for their brilliant work and strategy throughout the race.\n\nMeanwhile, Norris' interview showed that this remarkable event has brought immense joy to him. So much so that he claims he will party hard once again and \"might have more than just a scratch on my nose tomorrow.\"\n\nRight until the middle of the 2023 season, McLaren was failing to match the standards of its rivals under the new regulations. that indeed frustrated the Briton until the Papaya team made a turnaround last season.\n\nSince then, Norris has kept faith in his team, and even last year talked about McLaren's win being around the corner. While that success didn't land last year, it surely did in Miami this year. And with that, there is no doubt that McLaren is in the mix this season.\n\nWith Norris' rapid pace gain on Verstappen, it surely displayed that with the new upgrades, McLaren is a force to reckon with. Therefore, the tracks with higher suitability to McLaren might become an irritant to Red Bull.\n\nWith this odd result, it has also been highlighted that Red Bull might not have yet another seamless stroll to the championship. {"uri": "8112983579", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "01:32:02", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T01:32:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T01:30:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/sports-games/2928531-motor-racing-mclarens-norris-wins-miami-grand-prix-for-first-f1-win", "title": "Motor racing-McLaren's Norris wins Miami Grand Prix for first F1 win | Sports-Games", "body": "It was a long overdue triumph for the Briton who held the record for most podiums without a win (15), having finished runner-up an agonising eight times in 110 grand prix. Verstappen had seemed well placed to claim a fifth win in six races until a midway crash allowed McLaren to cash in on a safety car period, with Norris pitting and coming out with the lead.\n\nMcLaren's Lando Norris capitalised on a bit of good fortune to win the Miami Grand Prix on Sunday, holding off Red Bull's triple world champion Max Verstappen for his first Formula One victory. It was a long overdue triumph for the Briton who held the record for most podiums without a win (15), having finished runner-up an agonising eight times in 110 grand prix.\n\nVerstappen had seemed well placed to claim a fifth win in six races until a midway crash allowed McLaren to cash in on a safety car period, with Norris pitting and coming out with the lead. Seeking a Miami hat-trick of wins, the Dutchman filled Norris's mirrors on the restart but his Red Bull could offer no challenge as the McLaren pulled clear.\n\nFerrari's Charles Leclerc completed the podium, coming home third ahead of team mate Carlos Sainz, who was later penalised five seconds for his involvement in a collision with McLaren's Oscar Piastri dropping the Spaniard to fifth. The penalty moved Verstappen's Red Bull team mate Sergio Perez up one spot to fourth.\n\n\"About time! What a race. It's been a long time coming. Finally I've managed to do it,\" Norris told Sky Sports. \"I'm so happy for my whole team. I finally delivered for them. \"Long day, tough race. Finally on top, so I'm over the moon. I'm just proud. A lot of people doubted me along the way.\n\n\"I've made a lot of mistakes over my last five years in my short career but today we put it all together.\" In a season dominated by Red Bull it was a hugely popular win by the 24-year-old Briton.\n\nPulling into the pit lane Norris was mobbed by his team, congratulated by the other drivers and cheered by a massive crowd at the Miami International Autodrome that included former U.S. president Donald Trump, who visited the McLaren garage prior to the race. Until Sunday it had been another dominant weekend for Red Bull as Verstappen topped the timesheets in the only practice session and sprint qualifying on Friday and then won the sprint race and took pole on Saturday.\n\nHis second place in the grand prix had little impact on the drivers' standings as he continues to hold a commanding 35-point lead over his Perez. Mercedes' seven-times world champion Lewis Hamilton was sixth and RB's Yuki Tsunoda seventh followed by George Russell in the other Mercedes.\n\nAston Martin's double world champion Fernando Alonso grabbed ninth while Esteban Ocon earned struggling Alpine their first point of the season crossing 10th. Starting from pole, Verstappen was in command through the first 20 laps but was unable to open up more than a three-second lead on Piastri.\n\nAs the race reached the midway mark Verstappen made a rare unpressured mistake, going wide and hitting a bollard that broke and was left on the track, bringing out the virtual safety car. Verstappen was then quickly into the pits with Piastri, who had already pitted, assuming the lead.\n\nWith the first round of pit stops about to be completed and Verstappen about to retake the lead, McLaren got a lucky break. Williams' Logan Sargeant spun into the wall, bringing out the safety car and allowing Norris to pit and come out still in the lead, which he never let go.\n\n\"You win, you lose,\" said Verstappen. \"I think we're all used to that in racing, right? \"Today was just a bit tricky. If a bad day is P2, I take it.\n\n\"I'm very happy for Lando. It's been a long time coming and it's not going to be his last one, so he definitely deserves it today.\"\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a {"uri": "2024-05-346063708", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "07:15:28", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T07:15:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T22:44:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://clutchpoints.com/formula-1-news-lando-norris-miami-grand-prix-win-fans-going-crazy", "title": "Lando Norris' Miami Grand Prix win has Formula 1 fans going crazy", "body": "It has finally happened for Lando Norris after a little over five years.\n\nIt was a tough road but Lando Norris has finally done it. The McLaren Formula 1 driver can finally call himself a race winner after competing in the pinnacle of motorsport for a little over five years. It was not the best weekend after qualifying fifth behind Sergio Perez, Carlos Sainz, Charles Leclerc and Max Verstappen. But, the good in-race calls made by Andrea Stella and insanely fast pit stops by the McLaren team allowed the British driver to take over in the late stages of the Miami Grand Prix.\n\nLando Norris is now the 21st British driver ever to become a Formula 1 race winner. The last Brit to do so is his fellow 2019 debutant, George Russell. That happened way back in the 2022 Sao Paulo Grand Prix. This triumphant moment in the Miami Grand Prix also gets McLaren its first win in nearly three years. The last Papaya driver to do it? His former teammate Daniel Ricciardo during the 2021 Italian Grand Prix.\n\nThis moment had Formula 1 fans going all sorts of insane. The fact that he also joins Carlos Sainz as the only two drivers to get a win in the era of Red Bull and Max Verstappen's dominance made it all the sweeter to hear the British National Anthem at the Miami Grand Prix.\n\n\"And @LandoNorris SO F***ING PROUD OF YOU!! You did it! Your first win race!! Amazing race and an amazing result. Let's prepare for your next win races!\" a user wrote.\n\nSome of the McLaren faithful were just glad that the new star of their team finally got over the hump, \"It took 5 years for Lando to win, but it felt SO SO GOOD, srsly, the wait made it more special, my god, I'm so proud of you, @LandoNorris. #MiamiGP.\"\n\nOthers were more hyped about how the McLaren Formula 1 driver kept his cool despite Max Verstappen chasing him down the whole time, \"After racking up a record 15 winless podiums, Lando Norris has finally won his first Formula 1 race! Incredible pace & didn't make a single mistake when leading ahead of Max Verstappen. What a drive.\"\n\nLando Norris, McLaren's astounding strategy to notch a first Formula 1 win\n\nQualifying fifth at the start of the Miami Grand Prix weekend is not ideal. Often, the foregone conclusion is that Max Verstappen is likely going to run away with the race win after notching pole position. But, it was just not fate after the race had to slow down for a while due to a safety car.\n\nMcLaren took advantage after the current Formula 1 World Drivers' Champion got picked up by the safety car. Instead of following the Dutch driver outside, Norris and McLaren decided to pit for new tires. This closed the gap between the two. Verstappen eventually had to give up the lead such that he could head to the pit lane anyway. Eventually, the British Formula 1 driver was able to hold the lead and secure his maiden win.\n\nIn the words of Charles Leclerc, \"Lando, we can be a world champion, I said.\"\n\nThose words might {"uri": "8112950459", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "00:39:17", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T00:39:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T00:38:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://thesportsrush.com/f1-news-against-all-odds-ex-mclaren-mechanic-reveals-he-wagered-money-on-lando-norris-win-for-miami-grand-prix/", "title": "Against All Odds, Ex-McLaren Mechanic Reveals He Wagered Money on Lando Norris Win for Miami Grand Prix - The SportsRush", "body": "Lando Norris has long been due a win in Formula 1, and the day finally arrived for the McLaren star as he claimed the top step in the Miami GP. Starting from fifth, the Briton had everything to be able to win, and former McLaren mechanic Marc Priestly luckily placed a bet on it.\n\nPriestly revealed the same thing to X (formerly Twitter). \"I promise this is true....I never bet on #F1, but yesterday I put a bet on @LandoNorris to win the #MiamiGP\", wrote Priestly. The 47-year-old also revealed 18/1 odds to express how happy he was with his bet. Although the odds were against Norris, he undoubtedly deserved his win.\n\nNorris was running sixth in the early stages of the race when the safety car incident allowed him to take matters into his own hands. On lap 29, when a safety car was released after Kevin Magnussen and Logan Sargeant crashed, McLaren and Norris played a beautiful strategy to take the lead and grab the win.\n\nRunning at P6, after everyone in front of him had made the pitstop, Norris boxed in normal racing conditions and emerged in the lead with Max Verstappen demoted to second. From there on, Norris defended his lead, and with a cool, calm, and collected performance, he booted the torments of his near miss at the 2021 Russian GP.\n\nAt his 110th Grand Prix, Norris finally got to spray the champagne on his crew with the winning trophy at the exceptional Miami GP circuit.\n\n\"Finally, I've managed to do it,\" said Lando Norris as he claimed his maiden victory in F1. It had indeed been a long time coming for him, as he had previously won several podiums but never finished on the top step.\n\nInterestingly, Norris also registered an unwanted record in the process. After his podium finish in Australia, he became the first driver to register 14 podiums but never a win. Norris then extended that run in China by finishing second.\n\nHowever, with Norris finally breaking his curse, he was unsurprisingly nothing short of ecstatic. The 24-year-old had a gleaming smile as he jumped into the hands of his McLaren team to celebrate his maiden win.\n\nThis victory is also a testament to McLaren's improvement since the start of the 2022 season when F1 first introduced the new ground-effect regulations. It was only in midseason last year that McLaren seemed to have come to terms with the rules, and since then, they have been on an upward slope.", "source": {"uri": "thesportsrush.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The SportsRush"}, "authors": [{"uri": "vidit_dhawan@thesportsrush.com", "name": "Vidit Dhawan", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8112959998", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "00:55:51", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T00:55:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T00:55:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://thesportsrush.com/f1-news-carlos-sainz-makes-fortune-favors-the-brave-argument-for-lando-norris-who-was-assisted-by-safety-car-to-the-win/", "title": "Carlos Sainz Makes Fortune Favors the Brave Argument for Lando Norris Who Was Assisted by Safety Car to the Win - The SportsRush", "body": "Lando Norris is finally an F1 Grand Prix winner after 110 race starts. It needed an error by Max Verstappen and safety car luck for the McLaren driver to finish P1 in Miami on Saturday. But Norris' best friend on the grid, Carlos Sainz, puts forward the 'fortune favors the brave' argument to validate the credibility of his first success.\n\n\"He deserves it for such a long time to win a race. He's a driver that will win many races in F1. \"He's been driving at an exceptional level. Today he was on the lucky side but luck comes to people who deserve it and today he definitely deserves it,\" said Sainz to Sky Sports.\n\nVerstappen knocked down a cone on one of the chicanes, which forced him to pit to repair his damaged front wing. This gave the 24-year-old the lead. Then, Logan Sargeant's crash around the same brought out the safety car, giving Norris a virtually free pit stop.\n\nThis series of unusual events gave Norris an edge during the safety car restart and he capitalized on it, giving no room for Verstappen reo recover. The Briton maintained his composure for the next 25 laps, and his maiden Grand Prix win was in sight.\n\nOn the final lap, making no unforced errors, Norris crossed the chequered flag and roared on his radio with pure ecstasy. It finally marked the end of him being on the receiving end of 'he hasn't won a race' jokes on social media.\n\nAhead of the Miami GP, McLaren boss Andrea Stella declared that his team will be coming with a new set of upgrades. And surely, they worked. Starting from P5, Norris backed an impressive win, thus exhibiting the actual potential of McLaren's 2024 car.\n\nWith Red Bull initially expected to coast to another Championship victory, Ferrari and now McLaren's respective race wins this season indicate that things may not be as easy for the Milton-Keynes-based outfit.\n\nNorris' win would have also reaffirmed his belief in the Papaya team, which was on the verge of breaking down during the first half of the 2023 season. Now, it is on McLaren to maintain this upward trajectory and become an actual Championship contender in 2025 (if not this year).\n\nOn the other hand, Ferrari is also reported to bring a new set of upgrades to the next race -- the Emilia Romagna GP. The Maranello-based outfit wants another victory on home soil. But whether they manage to do so, remains to be seen.", "source": {"uri": "thesportsrush.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The SportsRush"}, "authors": [{"uri": "tanish_chachra@thesportsrush.com", {"uri": "2024-05-346753201", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "16:50:17", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T16:50:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T11:23:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.the-race.com/formula-1/lando-norris-first-f1-win-emphatic-takedown-critics/", "title": "Norris's emphatic takedown of F1 critics is entirely justified", "body": "Lando Norris's first Formula 1 win, at the 110th attempt, brings an end to the 'Lando No-wins' mockery the McLaren driver has been acutely aware of.\n\nNorris recently assumed the unwelcome record of the most podiums in F1 without a victory. That is no longer the case after his Miami Grand Prix triumph, although really it should never have been reality.\n\nHis first win should have come way back in the 2021 Russian Grand Prix, a race Norris says \"a lot of people talk crap about\". A late downpour cost Norris victory that day and started a strange narrative that he is a choker who cannot deliver a big result on a big occasion.\n\nAfter finally breaking his duck in Miami, though, Norris gave an emphatic takedown of the criticism he has been following for some time.\n\nPROVING CRITICS WRONG\n\nNorris joked after the Miami GP that he enjoys 'liking' the negative comments he received on Instagram about his (previously) winless F1 career.\n\n\"I freaking love it,\" he says. \"It makes me smile more than anything, especially 'Lando No-wins'. That's become the thing.\n\n\"To finally prove those people wrong, and prove to people that didn't think I could go out and do it, it's put an even bigger smile on my face. So, I thank all of them.\"\n\nWhen Norris looks back on the time between Russia 2021 and now, he says he sees missed pole positions, missed podiums and a missed sprint race win in Qatar. He admits that, and he's often extremely critical of himself for making errors in qualifying in particular.\n\nBut he really doesn't believe he's blown a golden opportunity to win a grand prix, which is hard to argue with. There have been many occasions where he has driven exceptionally well and been rewarded with a podium but nothing more.\n\n\"There was one opportunity, and this was Qatar [the sprint race] last year,\" he says. \"I don't know if there was a main race that I've missed out on, to be honest.\n\n\"I've thrown away maybe a podium or a P2, but I think every opportunity where I've been there to try and take a win, I've been there.\n\n\"As much as people want to say there was this and that and Russia [2021] and whatever, there wasn't a Sunday I've missed out on a win because of something I've done wrong.\n\n\"There were pole positions. There was a sprint race win. But nothing more than that.\n\n\"And I think that's why I never lost faith. I never didn't believe in what I could go out and do.\"\n\nHAUNTING SOCHI A TURNING POINT\n\nNorris's critics remember Sochi 2021 for him wrongly staying out on slicks in the wet while Lewis Hamilton changed tyres, and throwing away victory as the rain poured down even harder soon after.\n\nBut it was McLaren that misjudged the situation. It didn't anticipate a second, more aggressive downpour, which meant Norris did not have the same information Hamilton had. Expecting the conditions to remain the same, Norris thought he could continue. Had he been informed there would be even more rain, he would have stopped.\n\nMcLaren took responsibility then, and still does now. Race engineer Will Joseph said after the Miami win: \"It [Sochi] haunts me every day. It haunts me in my sleep. I feel like we can put that behind us now.\"\n\nNorris says that back then \"I didn't do the best of jobs and as a team we didn't\". Stella sees it as \"a bit of a turning point for Lando and for the team\", to understand how to operate and work together in a high-pressure situation with that kind of result on the line.\n\n\"If I go back to that race, I think responsibility is on the pitwall, because we didn't enforce the call to pit enough,\" Stella reflects.\n\n\"The driver on track, he doesn't see if it's raining somewhere else. We could see it. So it was our limitation in not enforcing Lando to pit.\n\n\"Even in that case, he was delivering the job. But we were not ready as a team to achieve the victory.\"\n\nThat has since changed. Norris has finished second to Verstappen seven times in the past 12 months. All he needed on those days was for anything to trip up the Red Bull, and he'd have won.\n\nBut that slice of fortune never arrived - until Sunday in Miami.\n\nMORE CONFIDENT THAN EVER\n\nBoth Norris and Stella admit this was a weight off some shoulders. For Norris, because it has been such a long time coming. And for McLaren because the pressure to produce a car capable of winning, especially for Norris, has grown over time.\n\n\"We were totally convinced that the gap to victory for Lando, it wasn't in Lando, it was in the team,\" says Stella.\n\n\"We needed to provide him with winning material. And as soon as we did it, he achieved it.\n\n\"That's for me testament to how ready he was.\"\n\nBoth also feel this was on the cards once the stars finally aligned. And at the first realistic opportunity with a car capable of winning, they have converted the chance.\n\n\"I've been more confident than ever this year that I've got what it takes and the team have got what it takes, and I was patient with it,\" says Norris.\n\n\"I've just been doing my job and executing my races, executing my qualis, and doing what I can do best. And I knew my time was coming.\"\n\nNorris had a strange weekend until Sunday, as he underperformed in sprint qualifying then was wiped out at the first corner of the sprint race itself, before qualifying a solid if slightly disappointing fifth for the grand prix.\n\nHowever, as he did for the previous race in China - another weekend to feature a disappointing sprint race - Norris gathered things together and produced an excellent grand prix performance when it counted.\n\nAnd while it was not a perfect weekend from start to finish, Stella believes Norris is reaping rewards this year from a better approach.\n\n\"Credit to Lando that he kept developing,\" Stella says. \"He developed over the winter, especially looking at improving in qualifying, delivering laps that sometimes don't have to be 100%.\n\n\"When you have a fast car, just be there. And I think he's doing that.\n\n\"I also have to say his race management is now very mature. As soon as he saw there wasn't much to do after the first lap, he started to save tyres, because he knew his race would come at some stage.\n\n\"Then the pace he was able to pull off once the cars ahead of him pitted, that was quite incredible.\n\n\"So, fast in qualifying, even sometimes pacing himself, and very mature in the race in terms of getting the most out of the material he has.\"", "source": {"uri": "the-race.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Race"}, "authors": [{"uri": "scott_mitchell_malm@the-race.com", "name": "Scott Mitchell-Malm", "type": "author", "isAgency": {"uri": "8113530266", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "09:44:23", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T09:44:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T09:44:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://www.irishmirror.ie/sport/other-sport/formula-one/norris-win-miami-verstappen-mclaren-32742710", "title": "F1 rivals revel in Norris win for two reasons as Verstappen left sweating", "body": "Long gone are the days of the 'every man for himself' attitude within Formula 1.\n\nThere is a camaraderie between most of the drivers these days - and you'll struggle to find a more popular man on the grid than Lando Norris. So there were emotional scenes at the end of Sunday's Miami Grand Prix as the Briton celebrated winning in F1 for the first time.\n\nFist pumps and hugs with colleagues are common after any driver wins. But even these days it is rare to see drivers congratulate a rival with as much enthusiasm as many of them produced as they spoke with Norris.\n\nTo his credit, Max Verstappen put aside his own disappointment to be the first to heap praise on his friend. He said: \"I'm very happy for Lando. It's been a long time coming. And it's not going to be his last one so yeah, he definitely deserves it today.\"\n\nNorris also got big hugs from Fernando Alonso and Daniel Ricciardo, among others. And Charles Leclerc, who finished third, explained why there is so much love and mutual respect between this new generation of F1 stars.\n\nThe Ferrari driver said: \"I'm just very happy for Lando, as we all want to beat one another. It's always nice to see the emotions. We've all come up together, and we came up through. I saw him in KF3, and from there we always want to make it to F1, and then the first race is special, and he must celebrate it.\"\n\nBut there is another key reason for everyone not of a Red Bull persuasion to be delighted with the manner of Norris' victory. The way he put McLaren 's upgrades to good use and sped away from Verstappen reminded everyone that the Dutchman is not invincible.\n\nVerstappen struggled with the balance of his car over the course of the weekend and was not at one with his car in Miami, as he so often is. And, speaking to media after the race, boss Christian Horner claimed his star driver had picked up damage when he hit a bollard.\n\nBut the reality is McLaren introduced a raft of car upgrades which improved their pace so much they could take on the Red Bulls and win. And with that success comes a flicker of optimism that it might be possible for teams to take the fight to the defending champions after all.\n\nAsked if he felt Norris' pace was indicative of McLaren being able to compete with Red Bull regularly, Verstappen simply replied: \"I hope not!\" Red Bull will want things to be business as usual at the Emilia Romagna Grand Prix next time out - the other Verstappen got a great start and built up a sizable gap over McLaren's Oscar Piastri, though not quite to the extent of previous races.\n\nThat all changed though, with a fortuitously timed safety car for McLaren's Lando Norris. Williams' Logan Sargent and Haas' Kevin Magnussen collided, with Magnussen deemed to be at fault. Sargent was sent into the wall, which ended his race and necessitated a safety car to remove the Williams from the track.\n\nThat allowed Norris to save a ton of time and grab a cheap pit stop, while Verstappen was stuck out on track after an earlier stop. After the restart, Norris used the new tires to build a big gap between him and Verstappen in second, a gap that would prove to be enough to secure Norris' first ever win in Formula 1.\n\nIt was the first race of the year in which Verstappen finished and didn't secure a win, with the World Champion complaining during the race that he couldn't get the car to turn in. In some races this season, and in previous years, the advantage for Verstappen and the Red Bull has been so big that he's been able to withstand poorly timed safety cars or underwhelming pace.\n\nNot Sunday.\n\nFor Norris, it's a remarkable win; yes he benefited from the safety car, but turned in great lap after great lap prior to the pit stop, allowing him to maintain a close enough gap to pounce when given the opportunity. And then ran away from the rest of the grid afterward.\n\nTrump congratulated Norris after the race as well.\n\nIn a season where Verstappen's felt inevitable, the Norris win provides some much needed variety. {"uri": "8114328260", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "19:10:45", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T19:10:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T19:10:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://www.espn.in/racing/story/_/id/40088581/are-lando-norris-mclaren-threat-red-bull-now", "title": "Are Lando Norris and McLaren a threat to Red Bull now?", "body": "MIAMI -- The sight of any car pulling a gap on Max Verstappen's Red Bull has been rare in F1's recent past but Lando Norris was able to canter away from the three-time world champion to secure his maiden F1 win at Sunday's Miami Grand Prix.\n\nNorris' victory margin of nearly eight seconds was, by Formula One's recent standards, a rout of Verstappen and his dominant RB20 car. On the surface it is easy to get excited about the nature of his win given the one-sided championship season we have seen to this point and the ease with which Verstappen has won the other four races he has finished in 2024.\n\n- Norris beats Verstappen in Miami GP for first F1 win\n\n- Watch Formula One on ESPN networks all season long\n\nEven more tantalizing was the fact Norris' victory -- his first in 110 F1 race starts -- came at the first attempt with the big upgrade package McLaren brought to the race, its first significant one of the year so far. Teammate Oscar Piastri will also have the new package for F1's next race, Imola's Emilia Romagna Grand Prix.\n\nWhile a new race winner will always prompt excitable statements about a new reality at the front, there were clear extenuating circumstances which helped end Norris' winless streak.\n\nThe collision between Kevin Magnussen and Logan Sargeant which prompted the Safety Car changed the course of the contest, rewarding Norris and McLaren for going long with the first stint. The Magnussen-Sargeant clash happened shortly after Norris had moved from fifth up to first as his rivals pitted. The British driver had been carefully managing his tyres in a bid to attack with fresh rubber later in the race.\n\nMcLaren felt like Norris' extended first stint would have left him with the pace to attack at the end of the race had there not been a Safety Car, although he was skeptical he could have made enough passes on track to win the race in that scenario.\n\n\"It would have been tough,\" Norris said on the hypothetical of a race without a Safety Car. \"I would have had to overtake two Ferraris, a Red Bull, Oscar [Piastri].\"\n\nThen there was the state of Red Bull's car all weekend, and notably Verstappen's during the race itself. Despite taking pole position for the sprint (which he won) and for the grand prix, Verstappen and Red Bull struggled to get their hands around the set-up of the car around the Miami circuit.\n\nVerstappen potentially complicated matters further when he went straight over the Turn 14/15 chicane, knocking over a cone in the process.\n\n\"I don't think we had a great balance all weekend,\" Red Bull boss Christian Horner said on Sunday evening. \"Obviously, he hit the bollard around Lap 20 and that has actually done quite a lot of damage to the underside of the car, so we will have to look at exactly what the effect of that was.\n\n\"It is a reasonable amount of the area around the left rear floor. There is a reasonable amount that's missing and you can see it awfully flexing as well, so it certainly wouldn't be helping.\"\n\nVerstappen himself made light of the incident -- joking \"I didn't like [the cone], so I decided to take it out and test the durability of the front wing as well!\" -- but downplayed Horner's suggestion it had a negative impact on his car's performance.\n\nRed Bull later explained Verstappen had not seen pictures of the car before going into the press conference. \"He lost two-and-a-half-tenths in Turn 1 every lap,\" Horner said. \"Whether that was because of the damage... when you actually see the pictures of what was missing, it wasn't designed like that.\"\n\nMcLaren came away from the weekend excited at the clear gains made with the upgrade and just with its pace in general. Raw lap times in the race had looked good. Even Piastri, driving in the \"old-spec\" McLaren without all the upgrades Norris had available to him, had looked competitive before a tangle with Carlos Sainz ruined his race. Team boss Andreas Stella played down the suggestion Norris' win was a sign of a new reality in F1 in the immediate future.\n\n\"I think yes, we improved the car,\" Stella said of the upgraded package. \"We know in the numbers how much we improved it. And it's material, you see it in lap time.\n\n\"But I think this race for Red Bull was a little bit of a struggle. So before we say the pace we saw today is a representative of the future, I'm not going to put my signature on this statement.\"\n\nThe race represented another feather in Stella's cap, having also orchestrated the huge turnaround McLaren achieved last year when it leaped from the back of the order to being Red Bull's closest rival on the back of one upgrade at the Austrian Grand Prix in June 2023. Another successful upgrade will only heighten the optimism and momentum which Stella has cultivated since stepping into the team boss role.\n\nIt will also serve as a reminder about just how tangible progress can be with the right development path.\n\n\"We take this positive, we take this encouragement,\" Stella added on Sunday. \"If anything it's even more energy to develop in my view, if you want to fight consistently Red Bull, we need to deliver another package like the one we have delivered here.\n\n\"In Japan we were sixth-tenths away in qualifying of Red Bull. In China we were a few tenths away. It would be completely unrealistic to think what we've seen here is the updated picture of competitiveness. I think here Red Bull didn't get the most out of their package.\"\n\nTeammate Piastri will get the same upgrade in two weeks as McLaren goes to Imola's Emilia Romagna Grand Prix at full strength. Red Bull will still expect to be the benchmark team on pace, but McLaren's competitiveness will be a major talking point going into the next race.\n\nFans who were growing bored of seeing Verstappen cruise to victories most weekends can take comfort in the fact McLaren seems to be on a strong development path and that there are big steps forward still to be found under the current regulations.", He also started his career with McLaren and won his first race with the team in 2007.\n\nHamilton's first World Championship also came with the Woking-based outfit in 2008. He parted ways with McLaren later to join Mercedes and went on to clinch six more championships.\n\nStay updated with the latest from IPL 2024, including top contenders for the IPL 2024 Orange Cap and IPL 2024 Purple Cap. Norris ended their three-year-long wait in Miami.\n\nHamilton was quite happy to see his former team back to form.\n\nHe said, \"Obviously I started at McLaren. So, really happy to see them back at the top. It's been a long time.\"\n\nThe 39-year-old was also all praises for Norris.\n\nSpeaking to Sky Sports F1, Hamilton said, \"I'm really happy for Lando. Such a special moment to win your first Grand Prix. I just told him, he needs to stay tonight.\"\n\nWith his triumph in Miami, Norris became the 21st British driver to taste success in the F1 circuit. George Russell, who registered a victory at the 2022 Sao Paolo Grand Prix, was the last Briton to claim an F1 win.\n\nKeywords: Lando Norris, Lewis Hamilton, Miami Grand Prix, F1, Max Verstappen. {"uri": "8113035989", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "02:47:02", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T02:47:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T02:46:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://www.foxsports.com.au/motorsport/formula-one/russian-demons-finally-vanquished-after-110race-drought-daniel-ricciardos-fresh-problem-miami-grand-prix-talking-points/news-story/04f5cc10ee7d142917b58c727ef1ba8b", "title": "Russian demons finally vanquished after 110-race drought; Daniel Ricciardo's fresh 'problem'  --  Miami Grand Prix Talking Points", "body": "The demons of Russia 2021 have finally been conquered.\n\nLando Norris, in his 110th race for McLaren, has finally secured his maiden Formula 1 victory, defying the odds to win the 2024 Miami Grand Prix.\n\nBefore Sunday's race, the British driver held the unwanted record for most F1 podiums without a victory, placing second or third on 15 occasions since his debut in 2019.\n\nHowever, courtesy of a fortuitous Safety Car that gifted Norris the lead in the 29th lap, the drought was finally broken in Miami.\n\n\"About time,\" Norris said after the race.\n\n\"It's been a long time coming, but finally I've been able to do it.\n\n\"I'm so happy for my whole team. I finally delivered for them.\n\n\"Finally on top, so I'm over the moon.\n\n\"A lot of people doubted me along the way, I've made a lot of mistakes over my last five years.\"\n\nEvery practice, qualifying session and race from the 2024 FIA Formula One World Championship\u2122 LIVE in 4K. New to Kayo? Start Your Free Trial Today >\n\nNorris' triumph comes three years and 58 races after the infamous Sochi blunder, where the McLaren driver refused to change to wet tyres in the latter stages of race, sliding off the track and denying himself a maiden F1 victory.\n\n\"I feel like we can put Russia 2021 behind us now,\" Will Joseph, Norris' race engineer, told Sky Sports after the race.\n\n\"Everyone at McLaren does a fantastic job. The team foundation is so strong right now, Andrea's leadership is phenomenal and we just go from strength to strength.\n\nMcLaren team principal Andrea Stella continued: \"(Lando) deserves it so much. We have always said, as soon as we give him the right material, he will make it and he made it.\n\n\"I know what kind of work is behind this. It's so deserved for the McLaren team. I hope everyone enjoys this moment.\"\n\nMeanwhile, Norris relished the opportunity to silence the social media critics that dubbed him \"Lando NoWins\".\n\n\"I am happy to put that to bed and prove a lot of these people wrong,\" he said during the post-race press conference.\n\n\"I love it to go on Instagram and like all the comments from people abusing me, I freaking love it, makes me smile more than anything, especially 'Lando NoWins', that's become the thing.\"\n\n\"For me to prove those people wrong and prove (to) the people who didn't think I could go out and do it, it's going to be an even bigger smile on my face today, so I thank all of them.\"\n\n'HE WAS FLYING': MCLAREN PACE TURNS HEADS\n\nIt can't be denied that Norris' upgraded MCL38 showed plenty of promise at the Miami Grand Prix.\n\nMcLaren added ten different upgrades to the British driver's car ahead of this weekend, with the changes paying dividends in Sunday's race.\n\nWhen the Safety Car ended on the 33rd lap, Norris successfully kept Red Bull's Max Verstappen out of DRS range and crossed the finish seven seconds ahead of the three-time world champion.\n\n\"Once we made a pit stop I heard what the lap times McLaren were doing and I was like, 'Well, that's pretty quick,'\" Verstappen confessed after the race.\n\n\"Once they switched onto the hard tyre, they just had more pace, and especially Lando, he was flying.\n\n\"It was incredibly difficult for us on that stint.\"\n\nHowever, Red Bull later revealed that Verstappen had sustained some minor damage to the underside of his car after hitting a bollard on the 23rd lap.\n\nWhen asked whether McLaren was showing its true pace following the raft of car updates, Verstappen responded: \"I hope not!\n\n\"They came with an upgrade, for sure it looks like it works so we have a bit of work to do from our side.\n\n\"I think definitely it wasn't our strongest weekend in terms of race pace, but we'll analyse it all and we'll try to come back stronger.\"\n\nIt's impossible to predict where Norris would have finished if not for the collision between Haas' Kevin Magnussen and Williams' Logan Sargeant, but early signs suggest McLaren might continue fighting with Ferrari for podiums over the coming months, and has closed the gap to the top.\n\nThe Woking-based team still won't be rivalling the mighty Red Bulls on a regulary basis anytime soon, but the champions and Mercedes will be wary of the papaya car's improvement.\n\nThe gap between Ferrari and McLaren has closed to 63 points on the constructors' standings, with a potential battle for second looming on the horizon.\n\n\"I stuck with McLaren because I believed in them,\" Norris continued.\n\n\"Today proved exactly that.\"\n\nPiastri, who was on track for a podium finish in Miami before the Safety Car, also stands to benefit once the full suite of upgrades filters to his car in Imola.\n\nThere wasn't much that Daniel Ricciardo could have achieved during Sunday's race having started in last place on the grid.\n\nThe Australian, who was knocked out in Q1 during Saturday's qualifying session, had already copped a three-place grid penalty for a Safety Car breach during last month's Chinese Grand Prix.\n\nAfter getting stuck in traffic, Ricciardo crossed the line in 15th, while RB teammate Yuki Tsunoda finished seventh in front of Mercedes' George Russell.\n\n\"Entering the race you always have some optimism, but yesterday's quali hurt,\" Ricciardo explained after the race.\n\n\"We were stuck in traffic in the race and were simply not quick enough to come through the field.\n\n\"We struggled a lot to use our pace compared to what we did yesterday in the Sprint with the clean air.\n\n\"We'll definitely be looking into it in our debrief, but generally, we know that we have to qualify better, like I did on Friday.\n\n\"Taking the positives, the team leaves Miami very happy; I had a good Sprint Qualifying and Sprint in the previous days, and Yuki also got some points today.\"\n\nAfter a difficult start to his 2024 campaign, Ricciardo bounced back during Saturday's Sprint by finishing fourth to secure five valuable points. However, according to former world champion Jenson Button, the Perth driver's impressive Sprint has been overshadowed by another disappointing race, where he was once again outperformed by his teammate.\n\n\"The problem for him is that he'll be looking at where his teammate finished,\" Button said on Sky Sports.\n\n\"That's the battle at the moment, between him and his teammate.\n\n\"People forget that, they'll remember the results, and that's the problem.\n\n\"It's about him picking himself up after this and getting a great result.\n\n\"That's the battle that's important for him right now, for his future in the sport.\"\n\nFormer IndyCar driver Danica Patrick continued: \"You're only as good as your last race.\n\n\"He's going to be down and he's going to wish it could have been different.\n\n\"I hope he remembers that he had an incredible Saturday.\"\n\nNorris has revealed that Donald Trump joked he was the British driver's \"lucky charm\" after the former US President visited the McLaren team before Sunday's race.\n\nTrump, the Republican 2024 presidential candidate, arrived at Hard Rock Stadium before the race and visited the McLaren garage where he met with chief executive Zak Brown and then sought out Norris after the race.\n\n\"I didn't see him in the garage to be honest, I was busy prepping for the race, but he saw me after, and he came up to congratulate me,\" Norris explained.\n\n\"I guess it's an honour, because whenever you have someone like this, it has to be an honour for them to come up to you, to take time out of their life, to pay their respect for what you've done.\n\n\"He said he was my lucky charm, because it's my win, so I don't know if he's going to come to more races now.\"\n\nNorris said he appreciated Trump's words from their post-race exchange.\n\n\"There's a lot of special people, or cool people that have been here this weekend,\" Norris continued.\n\n\"Donald is someone that you've got to have a lot of respect for in many ways, and for anyone like that, who acknowledges what you can go out and do, and acknowledges the work ethic that goes into things, you've got to be thankful for that, and I was.\n\nAfter Trump's visit to the McLaren's garage, which drew a large crowd of onlookers, the team issued a statement.\n\n\"McLaren is a non-political organisation however we recognise and respect the office of President of the United States so when the request was made to visit our garage on race day we accepted alongside the president of the FIA and the CEOs of Liberty Media and Formula 1,\" the team said.\n\n\"We were honoured that McLaren Racing was chosen as the representative of F1 which gave us the opportunity to showcase the world class engineering that we bring to motorsport.\"", "source": {"uri":
