{"uri": "8111742978", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "01:32:34", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T01:32:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T01:31:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://thesportsrush.com/f1-news-lando-norris-takes-a-53800-hit-after-repeating-the-dangerous-lewis-hamilton-mistake/", "title": "Lando Norris Takes a $53,800 Hit After Repeating the 'Dangerous' Lewis Hamilton Mistake - The SportsRush", "body": "During the Sprint Race in Miami this weekend, Lando Norris took a hit that stalled his car. Unable to continue, the McLaren driver got out and without permission, crossed the track. This could have turned out to be a fatal mistake had another car been around.\n\nIn response, the FIA levied a $53,800 fine on him, out of which half of it will remain suspended until the end of the season. According to Chris Medland, Norris has accepted his mistake and said, \"The situation could have been very dangerous for him.\"\n\nHowever, this wasn't the first time FIA had to deal with such recklessness. During the 2023 Qatar GP weekend, Lewis Hamilton did something similar when he collided with his Mercedes teammate George Russell, and he ended up receiving a similar penalty.\n\nCoincidently, Hamilton was involved in the event that kicked Norris off track in Miami in the first place. The former was charging from behind when he touched Fernando Alonso's right rear. This ultimately propelled Alonso to push his own teammate Lance Stroll, leading to the Canadian making contact with Norris.\n\nHamilton was not punished for the incident which was something Alonso found unacceptable. He even taunted the FIA for not penalizing the 39-year-old 'because he isn't Spanish'. Unfortunately for Norris, he took the final hit.\n\nIn Miami, McLaren came with new upgrades hoping to have a quality weekend. However, Norris' DNF in the Sprint made him lose out on crucial points. His teammate Oscar Piastri, however, finished P6, bringing home three points in consolation.\n\nLuckily for the Woking-based outfit, the final act still awaits, and for that Norris has done a decent job. In Qualifying ahead of the Grand Prix, Norris secured a P5 starting position. It gives the Brit a realistic chance for a podium. But McLaren's main aim would be to score as many points as possible to close the gap to Ferrari in the Constructors' Championship standings.\n\nPiastri will start the Miami GP right behind Norris in P6. Together, McLaren can make a formidable strategy to punch above its weight on Sunday. Meanwhile, Mercedes is also right behind the papaya outfit, and they could be an irritant to the team's plans.\n\nMercedes, however, certainly dealt with grip concerns in Q3. It forced them to resort to using medium tires. ExBulletin", "body": "Lando Norris said former US President Donald Trump called himself a \"lucky charm\" after securing his first victory on Sunday.\n\nNorris took his first Formula 1 victory in style after moving from sixth to first at Sunday's Miami Grand Prix, capitalizing on a safety car to stop at just the right moment before pulling away from Max Verstappen in the second half of the race.\n\nLando Norris: Donald Trump called himself a 'lucky charm' after his first F1 victory\n\nNorris admitted his relief after taking his first Formula 1 victory in the 110th attempt on Sunday, and his 16th time on the podium was his first on the top step.\n\nBut the McLaren garage received a high-profile visitor when the former president was introduced to its surroundings ahead of the race, with McLaren chosen to represent Formula 1 for his visit to the Miami paddock.\n\nTrump is vying to win back the presidency this year, but he is also currently in court fighting 34 criminal charges in New York, all of which he denies.\n\nPlanetF1.com recommends\n\nF1 Calendar: When is the next F1 race and where will it take place?\n\nF1 2024: head-to-head race statistics between teammates\n\nWhen asked after the race what he thought of Trump's presence in the McLaren garage, Norris told reporters in Miami: I didn't see him in the garage to be honest, I was busy to prepare for the race.\n\nBut he saw me afterwards and he came over to congratulate me, so I guess it's an honor, because any time you have someone like that, it must be an honor for you - for him to come to you, take time for him. life to pay tribute to you for what you have done.\n\nHe said he was my lucky charm because it was my victory, so I don't know if he's going to come to other races now. {"uri": "8113479721", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "09:12:19", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T09:12:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T09:11:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://www.ktbs.com/sports/national/lando-norris-claims-first-win-of-f1-career-storming-to-victory-at-miami-grand-prix/article_9cd3b4f5-a872-5282-8a70-1e985f4398f3.html", "title": "Lando Norris claims first win of F1 career, storming to victory at Miami Grand Prix in front of star-studded crowd", "body": "(CNN) -- Lando Norris won the first race of his Formula One career, storming to victory at the Miami Grand Prix on Sunday in front of a crowd flooded with celebrities.\n\nThe McLaren driver began the race fifth on the grid, but after claiming the lead, took advantage of a safety car delay midway through the race to pit as leader and re-emerge ahead of his competitors.\n\nAfter the restart, the 24-year-old produced a perfect drive to close out the rest of the race, finishing 7.612 seconds ahead of Red Bull's Max Verstappen in second.\n\nFerrari's Charles Leclerc rounded off the podium with a third-place finish.\n\nIt was a momentous race for the British driver, who was able to banish previous demons from his long-list of near-misses - Norris jointly holds the record for most podium finishes before a debut win with 15 - and stand proudly as race winner at the 110th time of asking.\n\n\"I'm just proud. A lot of people doubted me along the way. I've made a lot of mistakes over my last five years in my short career but today we put it altogether,\" Norris told Sky Sports afterwards.\n\n\"This is all for the team. I stuck with McLaren because I could believe in them and do believe in them. Today, we proved exactly that.\"\n\nNorris is the 21st driver from the UK to win an F1 race. Sunday's victory was also McLaren's first grand prix victory since 2021 - and second in the last 12 years.\n\nMcLaren CEO Zak Brown was full of praise for Norris after the race, saying the victory was \"long overdue.\"\n\n\"I think this is a very popular win amongst the fans, amongst the drivers... [with] how many drivers went up to him and congratulated him,\" Brown told Sky Sports. \"He drove perfectly, the car was really fast.\"\n\nNorris moves up to fourth in the 2024 driver's championship standings, 53 points behind Verstappen in first place, and the three-time defending drivers' champion was happy to praise the Brit for his maiden race victory.\n\n\"I'm very happy for Lando. It's been a long time coming, and it's not going to be his last one,\" Verstappen said.\n\nThe F1 season next heads to Italy for the Emilia Romagna Grand Prix with the race weekend starting on May 17.\n\nA star-studded affair\n\nThe Miami Grand Prix has quickly become one of the most popular events on the F1 calendar and is now equally as entertaining for the celeb-spotting off the track than the racing on it.\n\nFormer NFL superstar and seven-time Super Bowl champion Tom Brady, Blackpink's Lisa, Camila Cabello, Ed Sheeran and actor Anthony Mackie were some of the celebrities in attendance at the Miami International Autodrome over race week.\n\nThere were a host of current athletes in attendance too. The Kansas City Chiefs' star duo of Patrick Mahomes and Travis Kelce, NFL star Odell Beckham Jr. and US Olympian Fred Kerley were also there.\n\nFormer US President Donald Trump was also among those at the track on race day.\n\nThis year's attendance at the Miami Grand Prix was a sold out 275,000 across the race weekend, according to Formula One. In 2022, the attendance was 230,000.\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. Discovery Company. {"uri": "8113284170", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "06:52:31", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T06:52:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T06:52:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://www.autocarindia.com/motor-sports-news/miami-gp-norris-beats-verstappen-to-score-first-f1-win-431483", "title": "Miami GP: Norris beats Verstappen to score first F1 win | Autocar India", "body": "After 110 Grand Prix starts, Lando Norris has secured his first-ever F1 race win. The McLaren driver defeated Max Verstappen in an action-packed Miami GP, while Charles Leclerc completed the podium in third place.\n\nIt was initially Norris' McLaren teammate Oscar Piastri who looked primed to fight Verstappen for the win. An earlier error by Sergio Perez opened the door for Piastri to climb from P6 to P3 off the line, and he later passed Leclerc to moved up to P2. Norris, on the other hand, had a slow start and was running P6 in the early stages.\n\nOut at front, while Verstappen settled into the lead, he didn't pull off his characteristic early gap. The race played into Norris' hands when the Safety Car was brought out on Lap 28, following an incident involving Logan Sargeant and Kevin Magnussen.\n\nThe Safety Car was deployed just as Norris crossed the line, allowing him to pit for fresh tyres and rejoin the race in the lead. He fended off Verstappen at the re-start and starting pulling away at front as the Red Bull driver encountered balance problems. At the end, Norris crossed the chequered flag with a 7.612 secs advantage over Verstappen.\n\n\"About time! It's been a long time coming, but we've finally managed to do it. I'm so happy for the whole team, and what we've achieved together,\" said Norris, who has scored McLaren's first win since the 2021 Italian GP.\n\n\"We've had a few little setbacks across the weekend, but today we managed to put it all together. The car was great, the strategy was perfect, and I'm over the moon. I'm proud of everyone in this team today. I've always believed in them, and they've always had faith in me, and today we've really justified that.\"\n\nLeclerc finished third ahead of his Ferrari teammate Carlos Sainz. However, Sainz was later handed a five-second time penalty for causing a collision with Piastri. This dropped him to P5 and promoted Perez to fourth place.\n\nLewis Hamilton and George Russell salvaged some points for Mercedes, finishing P6 and P8, respectively. RB's Yuki Tsunoda split the two Mercedes drivers in P7, while Aston Martin's Fernando Alonso finished ninth. Alpine's Esteban Ocon rounded out the top 10, collecting his first point this season.\n\nVerstappen continues to lead the championship, 33 points ahead of his teammate Perez. Leclerc this third overall, just five points behind Perez.\n\nF1 will now head to Italy's Imola circuit for the Emilia Romagna GP on May 17-19.", "source": {"uri": "autocarindia.com", "dataType": And he squandered the chance of victory in Qatar last year.\n\nMiami was his 110th race and he struck a little fortunate in the sunshine state as he was able to pit while a safety car was deployed, meaning he was able to hold onto his lead.\n\nNorris, 24, was still tasked with fending off the dangerous Max Verstappen, who was struggling with his car having hit a bollard earlier in the race.\n\nBut Norris' victory was well deserved and will be a popular one, with the McLaren star one of the most well-liked drivers in the sport.\n\nIt is also a welcome return to the top step of the podium for his team, who last tasted victory in Monza in 2020 and presented Norris with a new deal earlier this season.\n\nNorris joined McLaren's young driver programme in February 2017 after a successful junior career, and has now reached the pinnacle of motorsport.\n\nHere we take a look inside his amazing lifestyle and his rise to the pinnacle of F1.\n\nDriving career\n\nNorris was a successful kart racer in his youth, winning three competitions alone in 2013 including CIK-FIA European Championship -- KFJ.\n\nCASINO SPECIAL - BEST CASINO WELCOME OFFERS\n\nHe made the move away from karting the following year and continued to impress with several first-place finishes.\n\nNorris first began to grab headlines with success in Formula 2, finishing second overall in 2018 when part of Carlin.\n\nHe then joined McLaren and made his F1 debut in 2019, featuring in 21 races that year.\n\nThe Bristol-born driver achieved his first podium a year later, before making pole for the first and only time in 2021.\n\nHe is on course to record his best season to date, with the 2023 campaign his best so far after picking up 205 points to finish in sixth place overall.\n\nHomes\n\nLike his compatriot Lewis Hamilton and many other F1 drivers, Norris lives in Monaco after moving to the French Riveira last year.\n\nExplaining the decision to move to the tax haven, he said: \"I'm moving to Monaco after [the final race in] Abu Dhabi for the reasons you probably expect.\n\n\"It's something that obviously a lot of drivers go to do.\n\n\"And especially with how racing is - I think you've seen it with a lot of the drivers, how quickly things can also go downhill.\"\n\nHe previously lived in Surrey near McLaren's base in Woking, and is understood to still own a stunning \u00a320m mansion in the area.\n\nSalary\n\nNorris is one of the highest earners in the paddock after penning a deal to extend his stay to 2026.\n\nThe pay rise is believed to have increased his earnings to an eye-watering \u00a320million a year, with the contract worth \u00a380m in total.\n\nOnly Verstappen, Hamilton and Charles Leclerc are paid more.\n\nGirlfriends\n\nAs well as fame and fortune, F1 can offer its stars opportunities to meet glamorous girlfriends, and that is exactly what Norris has been able to do.\n\nHe is rumoured to be dating Margarida Corceiro, having first been spotted with the Portuguese model and actress in public last year.\n\nHowever neither have posted photos with one another on social media with their apparent relationship taking place in private.\n\nNorris previously dated model Luisinha Oliveira between August 2021 and September 2022, but the pair were subject to abuse and death threats from trolls.\n\nFamily\n\nNorris' father Adam, 51, is one of the wealthiest Brits with an estimated fortune of \u00a3200m.\n\nHe is a retired pensions manager and is often seen in the paddock supporting his son.\n\nHis mother Cisca is from the Flanders region of Belgium, and Norris has two younger sisters, one also named Cisca and the other Flo, as well as an older brother called Oliver.\n\nSupercars\n\nIt is no surprise a keen petrolhead has the garage to match his love for driving.\n\nNorris has plenty of cars in his collection and was gifted a \u00a3300,000 765LT Spider supercar when he signed his new McLaren contract.\n\nHe was also seen at Silverstone last year in his \u00a31million McLaren Senna, while he's understood to have a \u00a3350,000 Rolls Royce Wraith and a \u00a328,000 Fiat Jolly.\n\nHe also owns a McLaren 720S which is capable of reaching 212mph and can reach 0-60 mph in just 2.8 seconds.\n\nWatches\n\nNorris also has a love for watches and boasts big brands like Rolex and Audemars.\n\nHe is also brand loyal and owns two Richard Mille McLaren timepieces, one of which was stolen from Norris when he attended the Euro 2020 final at Wembley in July 2021.\n\nThe \u00a3144,000 designer watch - a Richard Mille RM11-03 Automated Flyback - has been {"uri": "8113227405", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "06:07:58", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T06:07:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T06:06:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://www.irishmirror.ie/sport/other-sport/formula-one/lando-norris-interview-miami-verstappen-32742455", "title": "Norris gives X-rated interview after beating Verstappen to his first F1 win", "body": "As he crossed the finish line, Lando Norris let out a scream of equal parts delight and relief.\n\nFor the first time in his F1 career, at the 110th time of asking, the Briton became a race-winner. And his first words were for his race engineer Will Joseph, who confirmed to the 24-year-old that his boyhood dream had finally become a reality.\n\n\"We did it, Will!\" Norris screamed, his delighted expression obvious even underneath his helmet. He stepped out of his McLaren to a roar of approval from the Miami crowd and got a big hug from his great friend Max Verstappen.\n\nNorris benefitted from a well-timed safety car which came out after the Dutchman had pitted for fresh tyres. Previous experience suggested the Red Bull would roar past from the moment the race resumed.\n\nBut he held Verstappen off heading into the first corner and never looked back from there. McLaren gave him a massive upgrade package for this weekend and the timing was perfect as Norris had the car he needed to not only match the race pace of the Red Bull, but better it.\n\n\"About time, huh?\" He began in his post-race interview. He then dropped an F-bomb before apologising, aware he was speaking on live TV to millions around the globe.\n\nNorris then said: \"What a race. It's been a long time coming but finally I've managed to do it. \"I'm so happy for my whole team - I've finally delivered for them. It was a long day, a tough race, but I'm finally on top and over the moon.\"\n\nVerstappen is not used to being beaten. Prior to this, he had won every race this year that he had finished. But still he managed a smile after being beaten by his best friend in the F1 paddock.\n\nThe Red Bull racer said: \"You win, you lose, we're all used to that in racing, right? \"Today was tricky... Lando was flying and it was incredibly difficult for us. But if a bad day is P2, I can't complain.\" Charles Leclerc joined them on the podium after a strong drive for Ferrari, but it was all about Norris who proved to everyone that Red Bull are beatable in a straight fight.\n\nAnd McLaren will be excited about what the next few weeks will hold. Oscar Piastri will also get the full set of upgrades when F1 returns to Imola for the Emilia Romagna Grand Prix later this month with renewed hope that Red Bull can be beaten.", "source": {"uri": "https://i2-prod.irishmirror.ie/incoming/article32742454.ece/ALTERNATES/s1200/1_Lando-Norris-SKY-SPORTS-050524.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9538217", "eventUri": "eng-9538217", {"uri": "8114254200", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "18:05:42", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T18:05:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T18:05:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://frontstretch.com/2024/05/06/f1-review-lando-norris-breaks-through-with-first-f1-win-at-miami-grand-prix/", "title": "Lando Norris Breaks Through at Miami Grand Prix", "body": "Lando Norris finally scored his first Formula 1 win on Sunday (May 5) at the Miami Grand Prix. With 16 podium finishes and eight being for second place, as recently as the previous race in China, Norris had taken on the position of best driver not to have won. In fact, the Sky Sports prerace show even hooked Norris up to a lie detector to which he averred that he would indeed win with McLaren. How prophetic!\n\nMax Verstappen did something that must have confused him: He finished second. He has done so 29 times in his career but only four times in the last three seasons. It is hard to finish second when you are always finishing first. Still, there is no reason to feel bad for Verstappen. He still leads the championship standings 136-101 over teammate Sergio Perez.\n\nCharles Leclerc continued his steady year by taking third, and still not finishing outside the top four. He sits with 98 points and as another driver hoping for Red Bull to display a chink in their formidable armor to score his sixth win.\n\nCarlos Sainz looked like he might have the pace to pass his Ferrari teammate but never made a move and settled for fourth. Much like Leclerc, he has been consistent and has yet to finish outside the top five, but he has had a withdrawal owing to his appendectomy.\n\nPerez followed in fifth after he dive-bombed the leaders at the onset. Starting from fourth, Perez sat in a great position to gain positions but undid his race by barging toward the leaders with little control and going wide at turn 1. After he gathered up his Red Bull and fell in line, Perez fought with Norris for much of the first half of the race. His uneven performance does nothing to dispel rumors that Sainz will be taking over Perez's spot at Red Bull next year. (Ed. Note: Sainz was relegated to fifth after the stewards assessed him a five-second penalty for causing a collision with Oscar Piastri in their post-race review.)\n\nPerhaps Mercedes is starting to stabilize. Or maybe they just put together a decent weekend, but the team still does not resemble the dominant force it had been just four years ago. But credit should be given to Lewis Hamilton for starting eighth and finishing sixth while showing pace to push the cars in front of him. Neither the team nor Hamilton will be challenging for titles this year, and only with a lot of luck might the group win a race, but solid points days from here out are what should set them as the third-best team if they all remain steady.\n\nYuki Tsunoda must be even more disappointed with his DNF in China after scoring points in the Sprint race and finishing seventh in the GP in Miami. He has finished in the points in three of the last four races and is showing the form that was expected from teammate Daniel Ricciardo. Though he holds the 10th position in the standings with 14 points, Tsunoda has earned three-quarters of the team's points and is showing strong form.\n\nGeorge Russell slotted into the eighth spot in what seemed like a quiet and somewhat underperforming day. The points matter, and he brought the car home in one piece, but if he is looking to be the leader at Mercedes next year, he is going to need to show a little more chutzpah.\n\nFernando Alonso messed around in the back half of the field for most of the race before storming into the points during the last 20 laps. His battle with Esteban Ocon lasted a number of laps and provided stirring entertainment as Norris built his gap over Verstappen at the front. The question that remains with Alonso is not his talent but whether or not Aston Martin is getting better or treading water.\n\nHere's the sad stat of the day: By finishing 10th, Ocon provided Alpine with its first point of the 2024 season. That's right, the Alpine Renault works team now has just one point and sits six points behind Haas Ferrari, an organization that has developed the concept of protecting a teammate to the full. See: Magnussen, Kevin; penalties.\n\nThe Race\n\nThe Miami GP looked to have all the hallmarks of another Max Verstappen cruise-and-snooze fest. He sped off into the lead, and with Perez shaking up the front with his enthusiastic start that outdid his talent, the eventual falling in line looked normal.\n\nVerstappen was followed by Leclerc, Piastri, and Sainz. The two Ferraris, donned in their mess of an accented blue livery, seemed to have equal pace, but Piastri soon left the two to go after Verstappen.\n\nPiastri maintained a steady gap to Verstappen, an indication that McLaren was able to bring the fight, leaving the main issue to strategy.\n\nFerrari got in its own way back in the field by not encouraging Leclerc to let Sainz pass to challenge Piastri, while Perez and Norris hounded each other, much like Hamilton and Nico Hulkenberg.\n\nTwo things brought the usual race pattern to an end. First, some teams employed pit strategies that brought in their drivers in on laps in the midteens. This shuffling of the order helped to alleviate what had been a standard processional.\n\nThen came Magnussen on lap 29. If any driver has proven to be a bull in a china shop, it has been Magnussen. Racing at the rear of the field, Magnussen pushed to pass Logan Sargeant, who had been keeping to himself and looking to finish his home GP. Magnussen felt the need to disrupt this notion, pushed his Haas alongside Sargeant at the apex of turn two. Off sailed Sargeant into the barriers, his race over while Magnussen carried on. The incident brought Bert Mylander and his safety car to the track and changed the second half of the race.\n\nNorris, having yet to pit, found himself able to grab fresh tires and rejoin the field at the front - with Verstappen in tow. While normally, this would be the time for Verstappen to, uh, um, Verstompen (?), instead Norris made a clean get away and opened up a gap of over a second two laps after the restart.\n\nFrom there, Norris did what had been expected of him for some time: raced home for the win with a gap of over seven seconds at the finish.\n\nThe Good\n\nThis one is easy. Hat's off to Lando Norris on the win.\n\nNot only did he earn his first victory, but he also showed evidence that McLaren might be able to provide a fight for Red Bull, something the latter has not seen for the last two years.\n\nThe focus, however, should be on Norris and McLaren and for their continued fight. Having given away a race win at Russia a couple of years ago, a Norris win looked inevitable and then unobtainable as the team struggled at various points. This win is the culmination of the two working together and finally finding their moment. Whether or not this opens the proverbial floodgates on more wins will be something to speculate about but for now, they can enjoy the champagne spray.\n\nThe Bad\n\nMagnussen would be the easy target here, and maybe he is worthy of another column that really addresses the strategy of F1 racing in its current form. But for today, and not to pile on, but what is with Daniel Ricciardo?\n\nFollowing his stellar performance in the Sprint race where he finished fourth, Ricciardo could do no better than to qualify in 18th for the GP, while teammate Tsunoda locked into 10th.\n\nFor the race, Ricciardo brought his RB across the line in 15th. On the season, he has yet to finish higher than 12th and has two DNFs to his stat line. So far, this year is hardly serving as evidence that Ricciardo has what it takes to keep his seat.\n\nThe Questionable\n\nFar too often, people decry that sports and politics do not mix or that they should be uncoupled, but that is na\u00efve. Everything is political and it is impossible to separate culture from what birthed it. But that still makes McLaren's decision to host former President and current presidential candidate Donald Trump a bit mystifying.\n\nThe reason for making such a comment is that race organizers had already shut down an event planned by Trump supporters that had been tied to the race. That McLaren brought Mr. Trump to the race seemed to be a way of thumbing their noses at race management while also selling the Trump brand.\n\nWhether or not Trump fits what the sport is trying to sell is a question of perspective and optics. Such a spectacle brings attention, but for a country affected by a staunch political divide, moments like this one can be challenging and bring about the wrong talking points from what should be a celebration of Norris' breakthrough.\n\nThe Quotables\n\nGrabbing his first career F1 win, \"About time!\" beamed Lando Norris. \"What a race. It's been a long time coming, but finally I've managed to do it. I'm so happy for my whole team, I finally delivered for them. A long day, tough race, but finally on top so I'm over the moon.\"\n\nThe second-place finisher offered: \"Once then they also switched onto the hard tire, they just had more pace, especially Lando he was flying,\" said Max Verstappen. \"It was incredibly difficult for us on that stint but if a bad day is P2 I take it.\n\n\"I'm very happy for Lando, it's been a long time coming and it's not going to be his last one, so he definitely deserves it today.\"\n\nThe Results\n\nMiami Grand Prix, 2024: Miami International Autodrome, Miami, FL, USA (May 5, 2024)\n\n* Provisional results. Magnussen received a 10-second time penalty for causing a collision. Norris has been on the podium 15 times in Formula 1 without a win, which is a record.\n\nBehind Norris, defending champion and three-time world champion Max Verstappen, the Dutch driver of Red Bull, came second, while Charles Leclerc, the Ferrari driver from Monaco, took the bottom step of the podium.\n\nAmong them, the other Red Bull driver Sergio P\u00e9rez missed the first braking distance and slid off the ideal curve, allowing Oscar Piastri (McLaren) to move up to third place. {"uri": "8112829308", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "21:41:01", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T21:41:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T21:39:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/formula-1-lando-norris-gets-his-first-win-ahead-of-max-verstappen-at-the-miami-grand-prix-213456342.html", "title": "Formula 1: Lando Norris gets his first win ahead of Max Verstappen at the Miami Grand Prix", "body": "Norris benefitted from a well-timed safety car for a crash involving Kevin Magnussen and Logan Sargeant and drove away from Max Verstappen over the second half of the race to win Sunday's Miami Grand Prix.\n\nNorris found himself in sixth in the race's opening laps but his car had some serious race pace. Norris moved his way to second as the cars ahead of him made pit stops and was clicking off fast laps on his medium compound tires.\n\nHe took over the lead after Verstappen pitted just before Carlos Sainz and Norris' McLaren teammate Oscar Piastri did. Once Piastri pitted, Norris took over the race lead and was leading the race when Magnussen and Sergeant collided in the first sector.\n\nThe safety car allowed Norris to make his only pit stop of the day and stay ahead of everyone else when he left the pit lane.\n\nSimply put, Norris wouldn't have won the race if the crash hadn't happened when it did. But his win wasn't solely due to the safety car either. Norris pulled a second ahead of Verstappen a lap after the restart and then drove away from the three-time defending world champion over the final 24 laps of the 57-lap race.\n\nNorris is also the first driver not named Verstappen to win a race in Miami. Verstappen entered Sunday's Grand Prix as the winner of the first two races on the circuit around Hard Rock Stadium and won Saturday's sprint race rather easily.\n\nBut Verstappen's car simply didn't have any performance over the final stint of the race. He complained over his radio of a lack of front grip and found himself much closer to third-place finisher Charles Leclerc than Norris by the end of the race.\n\nNorris is just the third driver outside of Verstappen to win a race since the start of the 2023 season. Verstappen won 19 of 22 races a season ago, while his Red Bull teammate Sergio Perez got two wins and Ferrari's Carlos Sainz won once. Entering Sunday's race, Sainz was the only driver other than Verstappen to get a win through the first five races of 2024 after Verstappen was forced to retire early from the Australian Grand Prix because of a brake issue.\n\nThe victory is also McLaren's first since 2021 and just the team's second since 2012. {"uri": "8112859843", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "22:24:27", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T22:24:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T22:22:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://www.si.com/fannation/racing/f1briefings/news/f1-news-lando-norris-reaects-to-his-first-ever-grand-prix-win-a-long-time-coming", "title": "F1 News: Lando Norris Reacts to His First Ever Grand Prix Win - 'A Long Time Coming'", "body": "Lewis Hamilton's physiotherapist Angela Cullen has left her role.\n\nLando Norris claimed his first Formula 1 victory at the 2024 Miami Grand Prix, marking a milestone in his racing career. His triumph comes after a strategic race that saw him outpace even Max Verstappen.\n\nThe much-anticipated Miami Grand Prix culminated in a landmark victory for Lando Norris, who, for the first time in his career, topped the podium. This marked not just a personal victory but a significant milestone for the McLaren team, amplified by a brilliant strategy that steered them to the front of the pack during a perfectly timed safety car.\n\nFrom the outset, the race was fraught with tension and excitement. Norris, starting from the fifth position on the grid, demonstrated poise and precision. Key moments that defined the race included a nearly disastrous lock-up from Sergio Perez and a sturdy defense from Charles Leclerc, which initially held Norris at bay. However, strategic decisions during a pivotal safety car intervention, triggered by a crash involving Kevin Magnussen and Logan Sargeant, proved decisive. Norris's team opted for an impeccably timed pit stop that catapulted him into the lead.\n\nPost-safety car, Norris showcased his mettle, fending off early challenges from Max Verstappen and maintaining a steady pace that kept his Red Bull competition at a distance. His ability to manage race pace against the likes of Max Verstappen and Charles Leclerc underscored a maturity and race craft that have been budding over the past seasons, now fully realised by a car worth his potential.\n\n\"I've finally delivered for the team,\" Norris remarked in the aftermath. The young Brit's emotions were palpable as he addressed the media. \"About time. It's been a long time coming, but finally, I've done it. I'm over the moon.\n\n\"The whole weekend has been good. I've had little setbacks along the way. I knew on Friday I had the pace, today we managed to put it together with the perfect strategy. I'm just proud. A lot of people doubted me along the way. I've made mistakes over the last five years, but we put it together today. I stuck with McLaren because I believed in them,\" he continued.\n\nThe race was not without its dramas elsewhere. Incidents involving Carlos Sainz and Oscar Piastri added layers to an already complex narrative, with Sainz alleging that Piastri forced him off the track -- claims that heated the competitive spirit {"uri": "8114118703", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "16:15:39", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T16:15:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T16:15:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://www.aninews.in/news/sports/others/he-definitely-deserves-it-max-verstappen-heaps-praise-on-rival-lando-norris-for-maiden-f1-win20240506214356/", "title": "\"He definitely deserves it\": Max Verstappen heaps praise on rival Lando Norris for maiden F1 win", "body": "Miami [US], May 6 (ANI): Max Verstappen praised Lando Norris for a \"deserved\" Formula One victory, as the Red Bull driver conceded defeat to his McLaren adversary at the end of a thrilling Miami Grand Prix.\n\nVerstappen dominated the early portions of Sunday's race but lost the lead to Norris due to a mid-race Safety Car, with the Dutchman stopping just before it was deployed and the Briton changing tyres beneath it.\n\nWhen the race resumed, Norris was under pressure from Verstappen, but he held on to first place and performed a solid effort over the final laps to capture the checkered flag.\n\n\"You win, you lose. We're all used to that in racing, right? Today was a bit tricky. I think already on the medium [tyres] it didn't feel fantastic, we were pulling away but not like it should be. Then once we made a pit stop I heard what the lap times McLaren were doing and I was like, 'Well, that's pretty quick!'\" Verstappen said as quoted by Formula 1.\n\n\"Once then they also switched onto the hard tyre, they just had more pace, especially Lando he was flying. It was incredibly difficult for us on that stint but if a bad day is P2 I take it. I'm very happy for Lando, it's been a long time coming and it's not going to be his last one, so he definitely deserves it today,\" he added.\n\nWhen asked if McLaren is showcasing their 'real pace' after a spate of upgrades to their vehicles at the Miami International Autodrome, Verstappen said, \"I hope not! They came with an upgrade, for sure it looks like it works so we have a bit of work to do from our side.\n\n\"I think definitely it wasn't our strongest weekend in terms of race pace, but we'll analyse it all and we'll try to come back stronger,\" he added.\n\nDespite losing out on victory, Verstappen has increased his lead in the drivers' standings to 35 points, with nearest championship opponent and teammate Sergio Perez finishing fifth. {"uri": "8113170487", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "05:15:28", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T05:15:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T05:14:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://www.latestly.com/sports/f1-2024-lando-norris-takes-first-formula-one-win-in-miami-grand-prix-max-verstappen-charles-leclerc-earn-podium-finish-5943395.html", "title": "F1 2024: Lando Norris Takes First Formula One Win in Miami Grand Prix; Max Verstappen, Charles Leclerc Earn Podium Finish | \ud83c\udfc6 LatestLY", "body": "Verstappen's teammate Sergio Perez had a low-key run to fifth place, ahead of Mercedes' Lewis Hamilton in sixth. Yuki Tsunoda had a fine drive to seventh in his RB, with Hamilton's teammate George Russell following in eighth. Fernando Alonso took ninth for Aston Martin, and Esteban Ocon scored the beleaguered Alpine squad's first point of 2024 with tenth place.\n\nMcLaren's Lando Norris took advantage of a mid-race Safety Car period to beat Max Verstappen and win his first Formula One Grand Prix in Miami. Norris had been running sixth in the early stages of the race, but everything changed when the Safety Car was deployed on lap 29 after Kevin Magnussen tangled with Logan Sargeant at Turn 3, sending both into the barriers. Crucially for Norris, he was the only one of the leading runners not to have changed tyres by this point, and was thus able to pit without losing the lead he had inherited as others had pitted, reports Xinhua. BLACKPINK's Lisa Attends 2024 F1 Miami Grand Prix, Snaps Pic With Formula One Star Max Verstappen!.\n\nWhen racing resumed on lap 33, Norris had the pace to hold off the threat from Red Bull's Verstappen, and managed the gap for the rest of the race to score a fairy-tale first Grand Prix win on his 110th start.\n\n\"About time, huh?\" said Norris, who had lost a potential debut win at the 2021 Russian Grand Prix when a late rain shower had caught him out as he was leading the race. What a race, it's been a long time coming but finally I've been able to do it. I'm so happy for my whole team, I've finally been able to deliver for them. A long day, a tough race, but finally on top so I'm over the moon.\"\n\n\"The whole weekend has been good. I've had a few setbacks along the way. I knew on Friday we had the pace and just a couple of mistakes here and there but today we managed to put it together, we put the perfect strategy, it all paid off.\"\n\nMcLaren had brought upgrades to Miami, and Norris had shown genuine pace on his way to victory, crossing the line 7.6 seconds ahead of the previously dominant Verstappen. The Dutchman, who had won Saturday's Sprint event and led the early stages of the Grand Prix, also cut the chicane on lap 22 and struck a plastic bollard, with Red Bull saying the incident cost him some performance.\n\nBehind the top two, Ferrari's Charles Leclerc rounded out the top three, with teammate Carlos Sainz fourth after overtaking Norris' teammate Oscar Piastri, who subsequently needed to pit for a new front wing, ruining his chances of points.\n\nVerstappen's teammate Sergio Perez had a low-key run to fifth place, ahead of Mercedes' Lewis Hamilton in sixth. Yuki Tsunoda had a fine drive to seventh in his RB, with Hamilton's teammate George Russell following in eighth. Fernando Alonso took ninth for Aston Martin, and Esteban Ocon scored the beleaguered Alpine squad's first point of 2024 with tenth place. Max Verstappen Ties Alain Prost's Record With Sixth Pole-Winning Run To Open an F1 Season.\n\nDespite being beaten to victory, Verstappen extends his lead in the Drivers' Championship and now has 136 points. Perez remains second on 103 points, and Leclerc is third on 98. Red Bull remain top of the Constructors' Championship with 237 points. Ferrari are second with 189 points, with McLaren third with 127. The seventh round of the 2024 F1 World Championship is the Emilia Romagna Grand Prix in Imola, Italy on May 19.", "source": {"uri": "latestly.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "LatestLY"}, "authors": Hamilton expressed joy over McLaren's resurgence and Norris's significant achievement.\n\nThe streets of Miami transformed into a festive arena as Lando Norris clinched his maiden Formula 1 victory, prompted Lewis Hamilton to advise the jubilant winner to change his travel plans and bask in the celebrations. Norris, racing for McLaren, showcased exceptional skill and his team strategic acumen to take the top podium spot, marking a monumental moment in his career and a resurgence for the Woking team.\n\nStarting from fifth on the grid, Norris quickly became a focal point of the race, navigating through a field that included a near-miss collision involving Sergio Perez and a staunch defense from Ferrari's Charles Leclerc. The race's dynamics dramatically shifted following a crash between Kevin Magnussen and Logan Sargeant, which brought out the safety car. McLaren seized this opportunity, making a strategically timed pit stop that catapulted Norris into the lead.\n\nPost-safety car, Norris displayed maturity and precision, holding off a determined challenge from Max Verstappen. His ability to maintain pace and manage the race from the front was a testament to his evolving racecraft and underlined by his personal reflections after securing the win.\n\nNorris said: \"I've finally delivered for the team. About time. It's been a long time coming, but finally, I've done it. I'm over the moon.\" He added, \"The whole weekend has been good. I've had little setbacks along the way. I knew on Friday I had the pace, today we managed to put it together with the perfect strategy. I'm just proud. A lot of people doubted me along the way. I've made mistakes over the last five years, but we put it together today. I stuck with McLaren because I believed in them.\"\n\nLewis Hamilton, witnessing the young driver's success, was quick to offer both congratulations and a bit of festive advice.\n\n\"I feel really happy for Lando. I told him he needs to stay tonight. He will try to change his flight. He's got to change his flight, he's just won a race. Such a special moment to win a race. I started at McLaren, so really happy to see them back at the top. It's been a long time,\" Hamilton remarked.\n\nThe veteran driver also reflected on his team's performance, sharing: \"A really good day. I'm happy with the set-up. We finally got that sorted. And he squandered the chance of victory in Qatar last year.\n\nMiami was his 110th race and he struck a little fortunate in the sunshine state as he was able to pit while a safety car was deployed, meaning he was able to hold onto his lead.\n\nNorris, 24, was still tasked with fending off the dangerous Max Verstappen, who was finding difficulty controlling his car.\n\nBut Norris' victory was well deserved and will be a popular one, with the McLaren star one of the most well-liked drivers in the sport.\n\nIt is also a welcome return for his team, who last tasted victory in Monza in 2020 and presented Norris with a new deal earlier this season.\n\nNorris joined McLaren's young driver programme in February 2017 after a successful junior career, and has now reached the pinnacle of motorsport.\n\nHere we take a look inside his amazing lifestyle and his rise to the top of F1.\n\nNorris was a successful kart racer in his youth, winning three competitions alone in 2013 including CIK-FIA European Championship -- KFJ.\n\nCASINO SPECIAL - BEST CASINO WELCOME OFFERS\n\nHe made the move away from karting the following year and continued to impress with several first-place finishes.\n\nNorris first began to grab headlines with success in Formula 2, finishing second overall 2018 when part of Carlin.\n\nHe then joined McLaren and made his F1 debut in 2019, featuring in 21 races that year.\n\nThe Bristol-born driver achieved his first podium a year later, before making pole for the first and only time in 2021.\n\nHe is on course to record his best season to date, with the 2023 campaign his best so far after picking up 205 points to finish in sixth place overall.\n\nLike his compatriot Lewis Hamilton, Norris also lives in Monaco after moving to the French Riveira in November 2021.\n\nHe previously lived in Surrey near McLaren's base in Woking, in a home estimated to be worth \u00a316million.\n\nNorris is one of the highest earners in the paddock after penning a deal to extend his stay to 2026.\n\nThe pay rise is believed to have increased his earnings to an eye-watering \u00a320million a year, with the contract worth \u00a380m in total.\n\nOnly Verstappen, Hamilton and Charles Leclerc are paid more.\n\nAs well as fame and fortune, F1 can offer its stars opportunities to meet glamorous girlfriends, and that is exactly what Norris has been able to do.\n\nHe is rumoured to be dating Margarida Corceiro, having first been spotted with the Portuguese model and actress in public last year.\n\nHowever neither have posted photos with one another on social media with their apparent relationship taking place in private.\n\nNorris previously dated model Luisinha Oliveira between August 2021 and September 2022, but the pair were subject to abuse and death threats from trolls.\n\nNorris' father Adam, 51, is one of the wealthiest Brits with an estimated fortune of \u00a3200m.\n\nHe is a retired pensions manager and is often seen in the paddock supporting his son.\n\nHis mother Cisca is from the Flanders region of Belgium, and Norris has two younger sisters, one also named Cisca and the other Flo, as well as an older brother called Oliver.\n\nIt is no surprise a keen petrolhead has the garage to match his love for driving.\n\nNorris has plenty of cars in his collection and was gifted a \u00a3300,000 765LT Spider supercar when he signed his new McLaren contract.\n\nHe was also seen at Silverstone last year in his \u00a31million McLaren Senna, while he's understood to have a \u00a3350,000 Rolls Royce Wraith and a \u00a328,000 Fiat Jolly.\n\nHe also owns a McLaren 720S which is capable of reaching 212mph and can reach 0-60 mph in just 2.8 seconds.\n\nNorris also has a love for watches and boasts big brands like Rolex and Audemars.\n\nHe is also brand loyal and owns two Richard Mille McLaren timepieces, one of which was stolen from Norris when he attended the Euro 2020 final at Wembley in July 2021.\n\nThe Ferrari driver Charles Leclerc finished third, with a gap of 10 seconds.\n\nThe Red Bull racer while congratulating Norris, said: \"You win, you lose. Today was a bit tricky with the medium tyres. When I heard the lap times the McLarens were doing I thought, yeah that's pretty quick, Lando was flying. I'm very happy for Lando, it's been a long time coming and it's not going to be his last victory. He definitely deserves it today.\"\n\nThis season, Verstappen won four Grand Prix races in six rounds. He was victorious in Bahrain, Saudi Arabia, Japan and China, which was the previous round. {"uri": "8112882727", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "22:56:06", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T22:56:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T22:55:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://www.motorsport.com/f1/news/our-writers-rate-the-2024-f1-miami-grand-prix/10607365/", "title": "Our writers rate the 2024 F1 Miami Grand Prix", "body": "The McLaren driver made the most of a safety car period to change tyres for the only time in the race and emerge in a lead he maintained all the way to the finish line.\n\nOur writers give their verdict on the sixth round of the 2024 season.\n\nA mark up from Sainz's win in Australia simply because Verstappen was still in this contest with just over half the race remaining. The world champion was in command until the safety car boosted Norris, who has had a wild weekend here in Miami - going from sprint pole contender to eliminated in the shorter event and then having a quiet GP qualifying with the snazzily upgraded McLaren.\n\nNorris's tyre life offset seemed to make the critical difference in pulling away from Verstappen post-restart on Sunday, but his pace once released from Perez's rear much earlier hinted at what was to come, even if there was no predicting what would happen back then regarding Kevin Magnussen's latest shunt. You can never count Verstappen out, but in the end he was well beaten by a driver previously, outrageously, called overrated by some.\n\nA one-stop race in Miami doesn't sound like a humdinger on paper, but Sunday's grand prix was about as good as this track and these cars can offer us. Of course, a first-time winner in the likeable Lando Norris is a feel-good story F1 could use this year. But beyond that there was fighting throughout the field, between Oscar Piastri and Carlos Sainz, and seemingly between Lewis Hamilton and everybody else.\n\nNot only was the race interesting to follow, but the minor gaps between the top teams bode well for the rest of the year, although the track layout and hot conditions may have played some part. McLaren's upgrades seem to have allowed it to close the gap to Ferrari, which could inject some dynamism in 2024's pecking order.\n\nLando Norris is the obvious feel-good story of the day, with this maiden victory which had proven so elusive in the past through many missed opportunities. However, there never was any real battle for the win, with Verstappen comfortable at the front in the first half of the race and Norris slowly but surely edging away after he was gifted a golden opportunity by the safety car, which he did not fail to seize. Without this Magnussen-vs-Sargeant crash skewing the picture at the front, there could have been a fascinating duel with Norris potentially fast enough to bridge a 10-second gap to Verstappen.\n\nMiami was an overtaking fest compared to other races this season, and some tedious DRS moves were made up for by entertaining battles. What's more, the field seems to be bunching up - Mercedes' Hamilton finished fewer than 17 seconds off Norris in P6 - which is promising for the remainder of the season.\n\nWhat constitutes a great race? You can look at that question several ways. The quality of wheel-to-wheel battling, unpredictable action from the first minute to the last, a thrilling conclusion?\n\nTo my mind, the storylines and the degree to which it is remembered should be the defining criteria. And Lando Norris getting to celebrate his long-awaited first win means that the surprising 2024 Miami GP will ultimately live far longer in the memory than most races from the ground-effect era, even though it owed a significant amount to the timing of the safety car.\n\nEven though the result was arguably not in question once Norris had seen off Verstappen's attack at the restart to quickly pull clear of DRS range, seeing a new winner take the laurels of his former team-mates and rivals alike was a reminder that F1 can and does produce magic moments.\n\nThrough the pack too there were plenty of entertaining squabbles, with Turns 11 and 17 producing regular spikes of action. Even the cumbersome Turn 14-15 chicane was a source of drama, when Max Verstappen's snap of oversteer sent him on a collision course with a bollard that brought out a virtual safety car. And while DRS is frequently criticised for making passing too easy, I got the impression the balance was just about right this time around as defending cars could deploy their energy strategically to stay ahead as long as their tyres would let them.\n\nMiami may not be the first circuit on people's minds when it comes to producing a great race, but that is precisely what we got on Sunday - for any number of the reasons that you could wish to give.", "source": {"uri": "motorsport.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Motorsport.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8112836026", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "21:50:48", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T21:50:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T21:49:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://www.skysports.com/f1/news/12433/13129945/miami-gp-lando-norris-finally-wins-his-first-race-in-formula-1-after-mclaren-driver-beats-max-verstappen", "title": "Miami GP: Lando Norris finally wins his first race in Formula 1 after McLaren driver beats Max Verstappen", "body": "Lando Norris capitalises on a crash with a pit stop behind the Safety Car after a collision between Logan Sargeant and Kevin Magnussen\n\nLando Norris claimed the first win of his Formula 1 career in his 110th race as he took full advantage of a timely Safety Car and then emphatically pulled away from Max Verstappen to win the Miami Grand Prix.\n\nShedding the unwanted record of the most podium finishes without a win in his sixth season of F1, Norris ran only sixth in the opening stages but the decision by McLaren to extend his opening stint worked wonders when the Safety Car was called for a crash for Williams' Logan Sargeant.\n\nWith the cars ahead of him all having pitted by then - including race leader Verstappen - Norris had inherited the lead and then was crucially able to keep it by pitting under the Safety Car as his rivals all ran to a reduced speed on the track.\n\nThe job was far from over though with 24 laps still to go when the race resumed and with Verstappen, who had appeared set for another comfortable win before then, right on his tail.\n\nBut Norris impressively showed no nerves and, instead of having to defend from the world champion, consistently pulled away from the Red Bull in the laps that remained and eventually won by seven seconds.\n\nNorris, 24, takes McLaren's first win in since Daniel Ricciardo's in the 2021 Italian GP and just their second in the past 12 years.\n\nVerstappen had to settle for a distant second having topped all the other sessions in Miami's Sprint weekend.\n\nCharles Leclerc, who had been overtaken by the other McLaren of Oscar Piastri at the race start, took third ahead of Ferrari team-mate Carlos Sainz.\n\nLewis Hamilton finished in the highest position of his difficult season so far in sixth after a strong race for Mercedes, finishing within 2s of the second Red Bull of Sergio Perez.\n\nYuki Tsunoda beat the second Mercedes of George Russell to eighth, with Fernando Alonso recovering from his disappointing qualifying to take ninth for Aston Martin.\n\nAlpine finally opened their points account for 2024 with Esteban Ocon in 10th.\n\nFormula 1 heads to Europe as Imola returns to the calendar following last year's cancelled race. {"uri": "8112953994", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "00:46:21", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T00:46:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T00:45:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://www.skysports.com/f1/news/12433/13129957/lando-norris-lewis-hamilton-max-verstappen-lead-praise-for-f1s-newest-race-winner-after-miami-gp", "title": "Lando Norris: Lewis Hamilton, Max Verstappen lead praise for F1's newest race winner after Miami GP", "body": "Lando Norris celebrates in style, crowdsurfing with his McLaren team as well as being congratulated by rival drivers.\n\nLewis Hamilton and Max Verstappen led tributes to Lando Norris after the McLaren driver became Formula 1's newest race winner - and one of its most popular - in the Miami Grand Prix.\n\nIn the 110th grand prix of his five-year career at the top level, Norris seized the opportunity presented to him by a fortuitously-timed Safety Car to maintain the lead of a race he had inherited by delaying his sole pit stop, and then impressively pulling away from Verstappen when the race restarted to seal an impressive maiden triumph.\n\nNorris, one of the sport's most highly-regarded and affable drivers, was congratulated by a succession of his peers in the pit lane after the race. The appreciation shown towards the 24-year-old continued in the post-race interviews from a number of the grid's biggest names and existing race winners.\n\n\"I'm really happy for Lando,\" said seven-time champion Hamilton, the record holder for F1 race wins, to Sky Sports F1.\n\n\"Such a special moment to win your first Grand Prix.\n\n\"I started at McLaren and I'm really happy to see them back at the top. It's been a long time.\"\n\nVerstappen, who surprisingly had no answer to Norris' speed in the 24 laps to the finish after the restart, is a friend of the McLaren driver's away from the track and was pleased to see him break into the F1 winner's circle.\n\n\"If I get beaten, it's great that it has been done by Lando,\" admitted Verstappen.\n\n\"He deserves it. It's been a long time coming and it's going to be the first of many.\n\n\"Maybe it's also a bit of relief for him that he has that win now, who knows what's going to happen next.\n\n\"But for sure they had a strong weekend. Maybe it was a little bit messy still [on Saturday] but today they were flying - and especially Lando was flying. So definitely very happy for him.\"\n\nCharles Leclerc: \"I'm really happy for Lando. As much as we all want to beat each other and to come out on top, it's always emotional to see so many emotions on one of your competitors.\n\n\"We have all grown up together. Max and myself were on the same category but you always keep an eye on the younger categories.\n\n\"I remember looking at Lando, when he we all had these same dream of being a Formula 1 driver one day.\n\n\"Then once you achieve that you want obviously want the first win. I remember my first win and it is a very, very special moment.\n\n\"I told him already he needs to enjoy it as much as possible. He definitely deserves it.\"\n\nGeorge Russell: \"Obviously happy to see Lando finally get a victory. It seemed well deserved. He has done an amazing job for a long time.\"\n\nFormula 1 heads to Europe as Imola returns to the calendar following last year's cancelled race. Watch the Emilia Romagna GP on May 17-19. {"uri": "8112864175", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "22:28:59", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T22:28:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T22:28:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://heraldcourier.com/sports/professional/norris-verstappen-f1-miami-mclaren-red-bull-ricciardo-hamilton-sargeant/article_3a87e3b7-55ff-5107-b580-f5b5b5b95e62.html", "title": "Norris earns 1st F1 victory, ends Verstappen's dominance", "body": "JENNA FRYER Associated Press\n\nMIAMI GARDENS, Fla. -- Lando Norris needed 110 starts and a mistake by Max Verstappen to earn his first ever Formula 1 race on Sunday and end Verstappen's dominance at the Miami Grand Prix.\n\nVerstappen, who started from the pole and won Saturday's sprint race, was out front when he hit a chicane and knocked a cone out of place on the circuit. It forced the three-time reigning F1 champion to pit and gave Norris the lead.\n\nThe 24-year-old driver for McLaren then controlled the race to give the organization its first win since a Daniel Ricciardo victory in 2021. It also made him the second British driver in F1 history to be feted on the podium by \"God Save the King.\" George Russell in 2022 is the only other British driver to win outside of Queen Elizabeth's reign; Russell's victory in Brazil came two months after Queen Elizabeth's death.\n\nWith about 10 laps to go, Norris realized the race was his to lose when his lead over Verstappen hit 5 seconds.\n\nPeople are also reading... Hard Rock ramping up hiring efforts Former UVA Wise College Board Member Gives $1 Million to school Nominations reach 29 for Gene \"Pappy\" Thompson Award PREP BASEBALL: Falcons finish season sweep of John Battle THURSDAY'S PREP ROUNDUP: Abingdon (baseball), John Battle (softball) clinch Mountain 7 District titles; Tennessee High girls tennis team claims district crown; Lee High baseball team scores 29 runs; Trajan Cannon (Patrick Henry), Kailyn Breeding and Cooper Hurst (Richlands) also among stars TUESDAY'S PREP ROUNDUP: Brandon Edwards (J.I. Burton), Matthew Nunley (Honaker), Tyler Hash (Tazewell), Maya Owens (Holston), Reagan Evans (Rural Retreat), Erin Rasnake (Lebanon), Taylor Preston (Marion), Braelyn Scammell (Patrick Henry), Chase Wolfenbarger (Tennessee High) among notable performers MONDAY'S PREP ROUNDUP: Ashton Leonard and Carly Compton (Tennessee High), Connor Smith (Chilhowie), Jed McCoy (Eastside), Eli Hucks (Virginia High), Collyn Neff (Union), MJ Musser (Holston) , Jordan Frazier (J.I. Burton), Julia Barton (Honaker) among stars NASCAR: The Bluefield Boys have found a niche in NASCAR WEDNESDAY'S PREP ROUNDUP: Blair Rutherford and Alex Brown (Patrick Henry), Taylor Childress (John Battle), Emmaleigh Banks (Eastside), Will Rollins (Rye Cove), Ella Moss (Marion), Madyson Doss (Sullivan East), Hayden Baker (Ridgeview) among stars PREP BASEBALL: Abingdon gets 2-0 verdict over Virginia High as freshman catcher Judge Dillow, strong pitching overrule Bearcats HIGH SCHOOL BASEBALL: Chilhowie extends perfect mark in the Hogoheegee District MOTORSPORTS: Stanley is a hometown hero at Lonesome Pine PREP BASEBALL: Elizabethton stuns Tennessee High in District 1-AAA tourney LOCALS IN COLLEGE NOTES: UVa's Matthew Buchanan (Lebanon) enjoyed thrill of pitching at Fenway Park PREP SOFTBALL: Union beats rain, John Battle as Bears bash four homers in 14-1 win\n\n\"Five seconds?\" Norris radioed his team. \"Am I alive?\"\n\nIndeed he was as an ecstatic McLaren squad celebrated a rare victory on a weekend in which it debuted significant upgrades on its two cars. McLaren now has 13 wins in races in the United States -- tying a record with Ferrari -- but it was the first on American soil since Lewis Hamilton at Circuit of the Americas in 2012.\n\nNorris' final margin of victory was 7.6-seconds over Verstappen of Red Bull.\n\n\"I love you all, thank you so much!\" Norris screamed on his radio. \"We did it! We did it!\"\n\nNorris said he knew when he entered the track he'd win at Miami.\n\n\"Finally. I am so happy. I knew it. I knew it when I came in this morning,\" Norris said. \"And I nailed it.\"\n\nMcLaren has now won an F1, Formula E and IndyCar race in the past two months. Norris is the first driver since Carlos Sainz Jr. to beat Verstappen this season -- and Verstappen was eliminated from that race in Melbourne with a mechanical failure.\n\n\"You win. You lose. I think we're all a bit used to that in racing,\" Verstappen said. \"Is a bad day P2? I will take it. I am happy for Lando, it's been a long time coming and there's more to come from him.\"\n\nNorris was swarmed by the McLaren crew after the race as team members lifted him and seemed to crowd surf him until he finally got to boss Zak Brown, who wrapped Norris in a bearhug.\n\nMcLaren, before the start of the race, hosted former President Donald Trump, who chatted with F1 officials from inside the McLaren garage. When he made his way toward the starting grid, fans began chanting \"USA! USA!\" and Trump pumped his first in approval.\n\nFerrari drivers Charles Leclerc and Sainz finished third and fourth and was followed by Sergio Perez of Red Bull.\n\nHamilton was sixth for Mercedes, Yuki Tsunoda of Red Bull's junior team was seventh and Russell was eighth for Mercedes. Fernando Alonso of Aston Martin and Esteban Ocon of Alpine rounded out the top 10. Ocon did it with team investors Patrick Mahomes and Travis Kelce of the Kansas City Chiefs in attendance.\n\nAbout halfway through the race, Logan Sargeant crashed and brought out the safety car that forced the Pompano Beach native out of his car. The 23-year-old and only American driver on the F1 grid is clinging to his seat with Williams as speculation is rampant he could be replaced before the end of his second season.\n\nIt marked Sargeant's second consecutive last-place finish at his home race.\n\nThe Sargeant crash handed control of race strategy to McLaren, who held the lead with Norris at the time of the caution. Norris had taken over the lead when Verstappen was forced to pit from the lead after hitting a chicane that knocked a cone onto the racing surface.\n\nAs Red Bull was looking for any damage to Verstappen's front wing, a race marshal entered the circuit and scooped up the cone as F1 avoided having to use the safety car for the incident. But just moments later, Kevin Magnussen made contact with Williams and it gave McLaren the chance to strategize a victory over Verstappen.\n\nFor Magnussen, it marked another bad day in a long weekend in which the Haas driver was accused of unsportsmanlike conduct for his strategy in Saturday's sprint race.\n\nTags Dcc Wire Lee-national Be the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your {"uri": "8112632557", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "17:36:09", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T17:36:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T17:35:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://f1i.com/news/507138-norris-miami-not-the-track-to-judge-mclaren-upgrades.html", "title": "Norris: Miami 'not the track' to judge McLaren upgrades", "body": "Lando Norris says Miami isn't the best circuit to gauge the full impact of McLaren's MCL38 upgrade package.\n\nIn Florida, team papaya opted for a substantial overhaul of various aerodynamic components on its MCL38, aiming to increase overall downforce and boost its machine's performance.\n\nHowever, only Norris received the team's full package with teammate Oscar Piastri settling for approximately 50% of the updates.\n\nWhile glimpses of improved speed were evident throughout the weekend, Norris struggled to consistently deliver a standout performance.\n\nOn Friday, the Briton experienced a chaotic sprint qualifying session, ending up in ninth position before being eliminated in a first-corner incident in the short-form race itself on Saturday.\n\nLater on in qualifying, Norris managed to secure fifth place behind Red Bull and Ferrari's drivers, despite not fully extracting the potential from the soft tyres and even experimenting with the medium compound.\n\nFurthermore, in Miami's overheated environment, the critical role of tyre temperature management in maximizing performance made it difficult for Norris to accurately assess the true effectiveness of the upgrade package.\n\n\"It's good, it's working as expected but I think it's not the track which is going to show all of it,\" commented Norris.\n\n\"Hopefully in Imola or something, we can see a bit more of the potential of the car. But it's a step in the right direction, that team has done a very good job to get everything up and ready.\"\n\nNorris urged caution against drawing definitive conclusions after just a handful of sessions on one track. The McLaren charger suggested waiting for data gathered over multiple races to provide a more accurate evaluation of the MCL38's upgrade package.\n\n\"I think you can never judge it on one session and one track,\" he explained. \"You have to see it on high downforce, low downforce and everything. People are too quick to judge everything from one weekend or one day or whatever.\n\n\"I think everyone just needs to be a bit more patient with everything and see what it's like over two weekends, three weekends before you start to judge.\n\n\"We have our answers of it's working, but to know the true extent of it and how well it performs in all different areas, that's when you have to wait over {"uri": "8113398596", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "08:15:50", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T08:15:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T08:15:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/formulaone/article-13386557/Lando-Norris-gives-X-rated-interview-live-television-claiming-maiden-Formula-One-victory-Miami-insists-time-waiting-110-races-win.html", "title": "Lando Norris gives X-rated interview after maiden win in Miami", "body": "The McLaren driver benefitted from a safety car to cross the line first on Sunday\n\nLando Norris failed to contain his excitement during an X-rated interview after taking his first Formula One race win at the Miami Grand Prix.\n\nThe McLaren driver jumped ahead of Max Verstappen after pitting under the safety car, to beat the dominant Dutchman by 7.6 seconds on Sunday.\n\nIt was his first victory at the 110th time of asking, with only eight drivers across the sport's 74-year history waiting longer for their maiden win.\n\nNorris' boyhood dream became a reality and he was clearly overjoyed with his success during a post-race interview with Jenson Button live on television.\n\nAsked by 2009 world champion Button for his feelings, Norris responded: 'Oh, about time, huh? F***.'\n\nLando Norris could not hide his excitement during an X-rated interview after his first win\n\nThe McLaren star ended his 110-race wait to take the first victory of his Formula One career\n\nNorris jumped ahead of Max Verstappen during a safety car period to take the victory\n\nThe 24-year-old quickly apologised before continuing: 'What a race. It's been a long time coming but finally I've managed to do it.\n\n'I'm so happy for my whole team that I finally delivered for them and yeah, a long day, tough race, but I'm finally on top, so I'm over the moon.'\n\nIt's been a long-time coming for the McLaren star who has come agonosingly close on several occasions over recent years to finishing on the top step of the podium.\n\nIn 2021, he finished behind former team-mate Daniel Ricciardo to finish second at the Italian Grand Prix.\n\nThe same year he looked destined to win in Russia, only to make the wrong tyre call during a late-race shower as he slid off the track and handed the victory to Lewis Hamilton.\n\nLast year he had five second-place finishes and saw his team-mate Oscar Piastri take a sprint race victory in Qatar.\n\nHis long run without a victory saw some Formula One fans tease him with the moniker 'Lando no wins' on social media.\n\nHe added after the race: 'I never lost faith, I never didn't believe in what I could go out and do.\n\nNorris was keen to silence his critics after being called 'Lando No-wins' by some on social media\n\nOnly eight drivers in Formula One history have waited longer to take their first victory\n\n'So happy to put that to bed and prove a lot of these people wrong, because as much as I love to see it and I go on Instagram and I like all the comments of people abusing me, I freaking love it, it makes me smile more than anything, especially 'Lando No-wins'.\n\n'For me to finally prove those people wrong and prove to people that didn't think I could go out and do it, it's put an even bigger smile on my face today. Oscar Piastri, also behind the wheel of a McLaren racing car, took advantage of the situation and climbed to third place. After one lap, Verstappen, Leclerc and Piastri were the top three, fourth was Carlos Sainz Jr. (Ferrari) from Ferrari and fifth was P\u00e9rez.\n\nOn the fifth lap, Piastri overtook Leclerc, whose teammate Sainz, who was chasing him, also appeared to be faster, as the Spanish driver reported on the radio. Later, on the twentieth lap, Leclerc was the first to pit from the front to change a wheel, and four laps later Verstappen followed him from the front.\n\nOn the 28th lap, Piastri and Sainz called for new tires at the same time, then the safety car came onto the track due to the accident involving Kevin Magnussen and home driver Logan Sargeant. This was very practical for Norris, who started from fifth place and was in the lead due to his competitors changing tires. When the British driver changed his wheel, McLaren waited with confidence for a safety car phase. Taking advantage of the fact that he can change tires with less time during the safety car period, Norris drove into the pit lane for fresh tires on the 30th lap and then returned to the track in first place .\n\nAt the restart, Norris retained the top position, with Verstappen racing behind him in second place and Leclerc in third place. The reigning Dutch champion didn't have much of a chance of catching up with his leading British rival as his car struggled with balance issues that made it difficult for him in the corners.\n\nWith ten laps to go, Norris' lead over Verstappen was five seconds, which increased to almost eight seconds by the end of the race, giving the British driver a well-deserved victory for the first time in his F1 career. 24-year-old Lando Norris has been on the podium fifteen times in Formula 1 without a win, which is a record.\n\nMax Verstappen (136 points) still leads the championship points race by a large margin of 35 points, ahead of Red Bull's Sergio P\u00e9rez (101 points). Behind them are the two Ferrari drivers Charles Leclerc (98 points) and Carlos Sainz (85 points) in third and fourth place. Lando Norris (83 points) is still in fifth place, but with his victory he almost overtook Sainz. {"uri": "8113272471", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "06:43:19", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T06:43:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T06:42:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "url": "https://theprint.in/sport/motor-racing-from-trump-to-verstappen-everyone-celebrates-norris-win/2071461/", "title": "Motor racing-From Trump to Verstappen everyone celebrates Norris win", "body": "Even Verstappen, Red Bull's triple world champion who hates to lose and was denied a hat-trick of Miami wins by the McLaren driver, was among the first to congratulate Norris, who was mobbed by his team, crowd surfed along pit land and drenched in a shower of champagne.\n\n\"It was a long time coming, and I'm very happy to be beaten by Lando today,\" smiled a genuinely pleased Verstappen. \"He definitely deserved it.\n\n\"It's great winning your first race. It's always quite emotional. It brings you back to all the days that you worked towards your dream of being on the podium.\"\n\nFormer U.S. president Donald Trump, who visited the McLaren garage prior to the race, was delighted to back a winner, telling Norris later he was his lucky charm.\n\n\"He saw me after and he came to congratulate me,\" said Norris, who had told his grandmother before coming to Miami that he was going to win a race. \"He (Trump) said he was my lucky charm because it was my win, but I don't know if he's going to come to more races.\"\n\nNorris's mother and father were ecstatic, though they weren't in Miami to witness the moment.\n\n\"The cider's flowing in Somerset! A big celebration,\" Adam Norris told Sky Sports. \"I was working out it's probably about 900 races I've been to over the last 16 years.\n\n\"It's interesting knowing as a parent how many hours you put in, supporting them.\n\n\"I counted out 350 weekends away and all the races on different weekends.\n\nAnthony Hamilton, another father instrumental in the success of his son - seven-times world champion Lewis - also texted Norris with congratulations.\n\nWhile Norris was long overdue for a maiden win his wait was not the longest.\n\nWorld champions Jenson Button needed 113 races before his first win and Nico Rosberg 111.\n\nRed Bull's Sergio Perez holds the record of 190 races before his visit to the top of the podium and it took Ferrari's Carlos Sainz 150 and Mark Webber 130.\n\nNorris was still finalising plans on how he was going to celebrate his maiden victory, but he was already thinking about a second win.\n\n\"This only happens once when you take your first win. Tonight is going to be a good night,\" said Norris, confirming team boss Zak Brown had delayed the flight home until Monday so there would be a proper celebration. \"I would like to say it's the start, and now we're really hungry for more. We'll keep our heads down and keep pushing.\"\n\n(Reporting by Steve Keating in Miami; Editing by Sonali Paul)", "source": {"uri": "theprint.in", "dataType": "news", "title": "ThePrint"}, "authors": {"uri": "8113788465", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "12:32:44", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T12:32:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T12:32:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://www.motorsportweek.com/2024/05/06/if-my-mum-had-balls-shed-be-my-dad-verstappen-quips-over-lost-miami-f1-win/", "title": "'If my mum had balls she'd be my dad', Verstappen quips over lost Miami F1 win", "body": "Max Verstappen quipped \"If my mum had balls she would be my dad\" over discussions he could've beaten Lando Norris in Formula 1's Miami Grand Prix in a fair duel.\n\nVerstappen had appeared en route for a third successive triumph in Miami when he led from pole position and controlled the gap over the cars behind in the first stint.\n\nHowever, the Dutchman's race began to unravel when he inherited floor damage from hitting a cone on Lap 22 and then a Safety Car helped Norris manoeuvre ahead.\n\nThe three-time champion was unable to maintain pace with the McLaren on the restart and lagged 7.6 seconds behind the first-time race victor at the chequered flag.\n\nHowever, Verstappen admitted that he had been stunned when he was told the \"insane\" lap times that Norris was managing on old Mediums prior to the intervention.\n\nWhen asked whether he believed he would have still won without the free stop, Norris responded: \"I didn't know what the gap was, to be honest, before the Safety Car.\n\n\"It would have been tough. I would have had to overtake two Ferraris, Red Bull, Oscar [Piastri]. Oscar was doing a very good job, so hats off to him.\"\n\nVerstappen then followed up with his aforementioned one-liner, acknowledging that such mid-race interruptions will conspire to help some drivers more than others.\n\n\"I mean it's always if, if, if right? If my mum had balls she would be my dad!\" he quipped.\n\n\"Yeah, I mean it's how it goes in racing. Sometimes it works out for you, sometimes it doesn't.\"\n\nVerstappen, who still extended his championship lead as Red Bull team-mate Sergio Perez came fourth, admitted that McLaren's strong pace in the race was a shock.\n\n\"I mean, you win, you lose,\" Verstappen said post-race. \"I think we're all used to that in racing, right?\n\n\"Today was just a bit tricky. I think already on the Mediums, I didn't feel fantastic. We were pulling away but not like it should be.\n\n\"And then once we made the pit stop and I heard what lap times that McLaren were doing I thought, 'Wow, that's pretty quick.'\n\n\"Once they also switched on to the Hard tire, they just had more pace, and Lando, he was flying.\n\n\"It was incredibly difficult for us on that stint. But if a 'bad' day is P2, I'll take it.\"\n\nThe Red Bull driver expressed that he was delighted that it was long-time friend Norris who beat him to top spot in Miami as the Briton won in F1 at the 110th attempt.\n\n\"I'm very happy for Lando,\" he said. \"It's been a long time coming and it's not going to be his last one.
