{"uri": "8114190655", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "17:12:14", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T17:12:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T17:11:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4823529422283173, "url": "https://www.gpfans.com/en/f1-news/1019899/miami-victory-for-norris-capped-off-f1s-best-week-in-recent-memory/", "title": "Norris' Miami victory capped off F1's best week in recent memory", "body": "Lando Norris claiming his first Grand Prix victory will be the story everyone remembers from Formula 1's third trip to Miami.\n\nThe Briton streaking clear of Max Verstappen was not how many expected Sunday's race to end - but few can complain about Norris taking a well-overdue maiden win, and many will hope it's the beginning of a competitive season ahead.\n\nREAD MORE: F1 2024 Miami Grand Prix results: Norris STUNS Verstappen for historic victory\n\nMcLaren, understandably, will celebrate their first top-step finish since 2021 until the Imola weekend begins.\n\nYet the sport as a whole should be cheering for the entire Miami race week, of which Norris breaking his duck was just the final piece of a puzzle that should have fans filled with hope for a competitive future.\n\nREAD MORE: Verstappen MISTAKE triggers Miami safety car drama\n\nSpeculation over Adrian Newey's longevity at Red Bull Racing predicated any Miami hype as leaks from Milton Keynes filtered into the media.\n\nWas it true? Is he retiring? Has Fred Vasseur created a Ferrari Dream Team?\n\nWe only know the answer to the first question today. Newey stepping away from Red Bull after nearly two decades is a landscape-altering move akin to Lewis Hamilton leaving Mercedes.\n\nThere are many possibilities for his future, with Aston Martin and Williams joining Ferrari as potential destinations.\n\nEven if it's a move into retirement, Red Bull is a weaker outfit without his aerodynamic genius, and his decision will gravely hurt them, no matter how much they will publicly downplay his role.\n\nThat's a sizeable bonus for all other teams in an era where generating underfloor downforce is the prerequisite for competitive performance, something Red Bull has enjoyed since 2022, thanks to Newey's aerodynamic genius.\n\nEven if they continue to have an advantage once he departs in 2025, it's the end of the domination levels that have caused Grands Prix to become a foregone conclusion in recent years.\n\nREAD MORE: FIA announce HEAVY fine for F1 star after 'extremely dangerous' move\n\nAs the Newey exit announcement became official, another rumour rang through the paddock, and Williams was again in the thick of the discussions.\n\nAn FIA request to allow a super licence to the under-18 Andrea Kimi Antonelli suggested Joe Saward's post-China intel had some basis.\n\nJames Vowles, Williams' Team Principal, dampened any talk that Logan Sargeant would be out of the team in Imola, as initially suggested, but Antonelli is in his thoughts.\n\nWhile other teams, including Mercedes, Antonelli's Junior Team backers, denied they asked the FIA to bend the rules, Williams had Vowles swerving the question in the press conference.\n\nWhether you believe Antonelli is the second coming of Jesus, any mid-season driver swap is uncommon, and ones outside Red Bull's ecosystem are rare moments worthy of attention.\n\nAfter seeing Oliver Bearman, Antonelli's F2 teammate, adapt so well to F1 machinery, the possibility of another young hopeful getting their chance to shine is an enticing prospect.\n\nShould it pan out, it might be a harsh - perhaps premature - ending for Sargeant's F1 career, but there's no denying that it's always incredibly exciting to have new names racing at the top.\n\nWith Bearman and Antonelli's junior titles, either or both stepping up will see the grid continuing to strengthen and move away from weaker pay drivers, something fans have wanted for years.\n\nREAD MORE: Hamilton hit with SEVERE FIA penalty after clumsy Miami race\n\nAll this off-track action continued 2024's being a season where announcements beat racing in for entertainment.\n\nHaving Newey and Sargeant's futures to discuss must've felt like gifts for all commentators, especially considering the last Miami GP was rather dull when it became clear Verstappen would fight through the pack with relative ease.\n\nHowever, random trivia and commentary booth debates weren't necessary in either of Miami's races, as the 20 drivers put on a show that might even help on-site fans forget the eye-watering prices they paid to watch the race.\n\nAnother two-pronged Haas approach in Sprint brought the American team points after Kevin Magnussen's penalty-attracting driving kept wheel-to-wheel action going through nearly all 19 laps.\n\nPierre Gasly and Esteban Ocon's all-Alpine Lap 1 fight suggested that the Grand Prix would have more of the same battling, too, and indeed, it did.\n\nFerrari and McLaren kept pace with the Red Bulls while all remaining cars duked it out for whatever points they could in some top-tier elbows-out racing.\n\nHaving Norris lead the race after the Safety Car had almost everyone watching feel some hope that he could finally take a well-earned first victory, but also knowing Verstappen behind would most likely ease by within two laps of the restart.\n\nBut then he didn't. And Norris began extending his advantage. The impossible turned into reality. After two seasons of single-driver dominance, hopes of actual competition prevailed.\n\nIt's too soon to say whether this is the start of a revolution that sees multiple drivers and teams fighting for victory, but we can hope. {"uri": "8113571870", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "10:10:21", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T10:10:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T10:10:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4823529422283173, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/femail/article-13386497/Who-youngest-British-F1-driver-Lando-Norris-leaving-school-without-GCSEs-winning-Miami-Grand-Prix.html", "title": "Who is youngest-ever British F1 driver Lando Norris?", "body": "Read More: Lando Norris enjoys low-key romance with Margarida Corceiro\n\nLando Norris became the youngest-ever British driver when he made his debut at 19-years-old in the 2019 Australian Grand Prix.\n\nBut the young star, now 24, actually started off a career in horseriding before heading into motorsports.\n\nBorn in Bristol to businessman Adam Norris - who boasts and \u00a3205million fortune - and Belgian mother Cisca, he left school with no GCSEs before become the UK's youngest ever F1 driver.\n\nThe hotshot, who grew up in Glastonbury, Somerset, is also lucky in love and is dating Portuguese model and actress Margarida Corceiro, who is the ex-girlfriend of former Chelsea star Joao Felix.\n\nThe Bristol-born Lando Norris, 24, bagged his first Grand Prix win in Miami in May 2024 pushing reigning world champion Max Verstappen off the top of the podium when he took home the coveted title after more than 100 races\n\nOver the past year, he has been regularly spotted alongside Portuguese model and actress Margarida Corceiro, only add to speculation and discussion about his romantic life\n\nThe pair were recently spotted at the Monte-Carlo Masters final amid her split from Felix in 2023\n\nBarcelona forward Felix was previously in a relationship with Corceiro from 2019 to 2023\n\nEarly Childhood\n\nNorris is one of four children - having an elder brother called Oli, and two younger sisters Flo and Cisca.\n\nHe attended school in Somerset but ultimately left without any GCSEs in pursuit of a career in support, later studying physics and maths with the help of a personal tutor.\n\nNorris became the youngest go-karting world champion at just age 14 - a title previously held by Lewis Hamilton.\n\nIt was during his time on the go-karting scene that he was talent-spotted by McLaren who were impressed by the record breaking youngster.\n\nYet if it had not been for his love of horse riding as a child, the young star may never have made his way to motorsports.\n\n'I started on horse riding, so I started on four legs,' he recalled previously. 'But then I moved to quad biking. I was a big fan. Then I really got into motorcross.'\n\nNorris - who admitted being more interested in MotoGP motorcycle racing than F1 growing up - said: 'The racing is quite boring, sometimes. It's hard to see how it pulls in fans. The races compared to other categories are sometimes a lot worse, they should always be better.\n\n'I don't really know how to fix it; maybe have a load of power and no downforce, but I'm sure they will have a way. It's better than it was, but not where it should be as the top form of racing.'\n\nNorris holding his Lewis Hamilton hard charger award prize at the 2012 Formula Kart Stars round at Nutts Corner in Northern Ireland\n\nIt was during his time on the go-karting scene that he was talent-spotted by McLaren who were impressed by the record breaking youngster\n\nNorris became the youngest go-karting world champion at just age 14 - a title previously held by Lewis Hamilton\n\nNorris is interviewed on stage at Autosport International, the season opening motorport show in 2017\n\nCareer\n\nNorris became the youngest-ever British Formula One driver when he made his debut in the competition in 2019 at just 19-years-old at the Australian GP after coming through the ranks of the garage as an FP2 star.\n\nNot only does he have a four-year contract estimated to be worth a whopping \u00a380 million, the racing pro has a series of luxury brand deals and has starred in a number of glam photoshoots.\n\nClutching onto a series of supercars, designer watches and a stunning \u00a320 million mansion in Surrey. As well as career success, his personal life has also been blossoming.\n\nIn October 2023, Norris celebrated a big milestone. '100 races, 100 stickers. Here's to the next 100,' he wrote on Instagram, alongside a pic of him blowing out a candle on top of his helmet. His win at the Miami Grand Prix in 2024 marked his 110th race.\n\nTeam principal Zak Brown once called an even-more youthful Norris to his office in 2019 to tell him the news that he was being given a contract and full-time seat in Formula One, telling him at the time: 'Welcome to Formula One.'\n\nThe Englishman took the news calmly at the time and has taken to the on and off-track demands that being one of the world's biggest sporting celebrities brings with it.\n\nFormula One's media moguls have wrangled their product as being the glitzy and most glamorous event as their recent success in Miami showed and Norris is central to their image - and McLaren's.\n\nHis age and combined millionaire status make celebrations a grander affair with Norris renowned for occasions where even recently he got injured accidentally while playing around partying.\n\nThe riches of his McLaren contract reward him with up to \u00a320 million-a-year, while his ever-growing profile as a rising social media star - where he often collaborates in videos with celebrity YouTubers - brings further endorsements give him the luxuries you'd expect from a F1 superstar.\n\nLove Life\n\nMargarida is no stranger to back of the classic car, but they have predominantly kept their budding relationship out of the spotlight.\n\nMargarida is no stranger to flaunting her figure in a scantily-clad bikini snaps, sharing a slew of images from her trip to The Maldives back in December.\n\nHowever, she is yet to share any posts acknowledging Lando's first ever Formula One victory.\n\nHer last social media post came I wanted to go for a fast lap on the last lap,\" Norris said. \"But I was imagining Andrea on the pit wall, like, 'No, Lando, please'.\n\n\"So he was talking to me, but I just thought then, just take it home and take it easy.\n\n\"Until then, I wanted to pull away and I didn't want Max in the picture when I was over the line, and I don't think he was. That was the job. Job done, so happy with that.\"\n\nNorris has cited he was reluctant to drop his pace even once he had pulled clear from Verstappen as he wanted to minimise the chances he could make a mistake.\n\n\"I had to push fairly hard just for a lap and then I could kind of relax a little bit,\" Norris explained.\n\n\"I had fresher tyres, my pace was very good in clean air and Max was for the first time I raced not in clean air so I had the advantage and I could control things fairly well.\n\n\"I pushed for the first bit, my engineer was giving me updates on the gap and I felt like I was cruising and extending the gap and I didn't feel like I had to do anything more.\n\n\"So yeah, I didn't have to push too much for the first lap or two and then I could kind of cruise and be fairly comfortable.\n\n\"I was still pushing because I wanted to open the gap, like I said. Of course, your mind wanders a bit. My mind does, maybe not everyone's does.\n\n\"But yeah, you know, walls get close sometimes and you have those little moments where you think, 'okay, don't screw it up'.\n\n\"But I also was improving So we felt the responsibility and I have said that many times, that it is up to us, it is not up to Lando.\n\n\"But credit to Lando, he kept developing over the winter, especially looking at improving in qualifying and delivering laps that sometimes don't have to be 100% when you have a fast car, just be there. I think he is doing that.\"\n\nThe Italian added: \"That's for me a testament to how ready he was, and also if we look at what he delivered in podiums with a car that sometimes wasn't really a podium finisher on merit, for me Lando is in a very strong journey.\"\n\nStella praised Norris for keeping his powder dry in the first stint on medium tyres when stuck in traffic, only to then deliver one fastest lap after the other once he found clear air, pace that even had Red Bull's Max Verstappen rightly worried.\n\n\"I have to say that his race management is very mature,\" said Stella. \"As soon as he saw there wasn't much to do after the first lap, he started to save his tyres because he knew his race would come at some stage.\n\n\"The pace he was able to pull off when the cars ahead of him pitted, that was quite incredible. He was getting the most out of the material he has.\n\n\"We needed to provide him with winning material. {"uri": "8112871238", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "22:40:35", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T22:40:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T22:39:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4705882370471954, "url": "https://www.gpfans.com/en/f1-news/1019833/f1-lando-norris-delivers-xrated-celebration-after-amazing-win-top-three-verdict/", "title": "Norris delivers X-rated celebration after AMAZING win- top three verdict", "body": "Lando Norris has finally achieved his maiden F1 victory after a chaotic Miami Grand Prix.\n\nThe Brit experienced some good luck when an incident brought out a safety car and Max Verstappen pitted for new hard tyres.\n\nREAD MORE: Big SMASH hands huge advantage to Verstappen F1 rivals\n\nNorris inherited the lead and maintained it by pitting under the safety car whilst his rivals' speed was reduced on track.\n\nThe Brit held off Verstappen following the safety car restart extending his lead to finish +7.612 seconds ahead of the Dutch driver.\n\nMcLaren dedicated their race win to their former sporting director Gil de Ferran who passed away at the end of last year,\n\nHere is what the top three had to say after the Miami Grand Prix...\n\n\"About time! What a race. It's been a long time coming. Finally I've managed to do it.\n\n\"I'm so happy for my whole team. I finally delivered for them. Long day, tough race. Finally on top, so I'm over the moon.\n\n\"The whole weekend has been good. I've had some little setbacks along the way but I knew on Friday we had the pace.\n\n\"Just a couple mistakes here and there. Today we managed to put it together. We did the perfect strategy and it all paid off.\"\n\n\"I'm just proud. A lot of people doubted me along the way. I've made a lot of mistakes over my last five years in my short career but today we put it altogether.\n\n\"This is all for the team. I stuck with McLaren because I could believe in them and do believe in them. Today we proved exactly that.\"\n\n\"You win, you lose. I think we're all used to that in racing, right? Today was just a bit tricky. I think already on the mediums, it didn't feel fantastic. We were pulling away but not like it should be and once we made the pit stop and I heard the lap times the McLarens were doing, I was like, 'wow, that's pretty quick.\n\n\"Once they switched onto the hard tyre, they just had more pace, and especially Lando, he was flying. It was incredibly difficult for us on that stint, but if a bad day is P2, I take it.\n\n\"I'm very happy for Lando. It's been a long time coming and it's not going to be his last one, so he definitely deserves it today.\n\n\"I mean understeer, oversteer, just very low grip on four wheels, and that's something that we have to understand.\n\n\"They came with an upgrade. For sure it looks like it works, right? So we have a bit of work to do from our side. I think definitely it wasn't our strongest weekend in terms of race pace, but we'll analyse it all and we'll try to come back stronger from it.\"\n\n\"It was very tricky at the start. Checo was on my inside. I didn't get a very good start, as soon as I left, I had wheelspin.\n\n\"I saw Checo on the right but there was very little grip, so he locked up.\n\n\"I thought we would all crash but unfortunately for everybody we all got out of the first corner.\n\n\"Then it was all about trying to focus on ourselves. But today, again, we were missing a little bit of pace.\n\n\"We did our best but the timing of the Safety Car wasn't great for us and we had the oldest tyres. {"uri": "8114317368", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "19:01:19", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T19:01:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T19:00:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4705882370471954, "url": "https://f1i.com/news/507348-sainz-one-safety-car-pitstop-away-from-winning-miami-gp.html", "title": "Sainz one Safety Car pitstop away from winning Miami GP", "body": "The Miami Grand Prix unfolded with a twist of fate for Ferrari's Carlos Sainz, who believes that a pit stop under the Safety Car regime could have landed him the race victory.\n\nWhile Lando Norris capitalized on a lengthy opening stint that extended right into a lucky Safety Car period, which led to a timely pitstop for the McLaren charger, Sainz had pitted a lap earlier under normal race conditions.\n\nThis crucial difference allowed Norris to position himself ahead meant that when the crash between Haas drivers Kevin Magnussen and Logan Sargeant triggered the safety car, Norris emerged ahead of the pack to claim his maiden grand prix win.\n\nHad Ferrari delayed Sainz's pitstop by just one lap, he would have found himself in the lead with a clear shot at the victory, leaving him with a sense of what could have been.\n\n\"Frustrated, because we were ahead of him before that pitstop before the safety car,\" said Sainz of his race.\n\n\"If we would have extended one more lap, we would've caught the safety car and we could have won the race too.\"\n\nFerrari team principal Fred Vasseur acknowledged the unfortunate timing of the Safety Car intervention, saying with a touch of humor \"I forgot the crystal ball\".\n\n\"I was not aware that Sargeant and Magnussen would crash the lap after!\" commented the Frenchman.\n\n\"Of course, when you are in this situation, you are a bit unlucky - or I would say probably that Lando was a bit lucky, because he was the only one on track.\n\n\"But more than this, I think it's the fact that they put the safety car in front of Verstappen. {"uri": "8114338533", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "19:20:14", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T19:20:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T19:19:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4627451002597809, "url": "https://lawandcrime.com/high-profile/we-want-them-man-who-allegedly-vowed-to-push-through-cops-to-get-to-lawmakers-in-capitol-arrested/", "title": "'We want them': Man who allegedly vowed to 'push through' cops to get to lawmakers arrested", "body": "Clayton \"Clay\" Norris of Ohio has been arrested and charged after police say he was seen in video footage of the Jan. 6 attack on the U.S. Capitol using a megaphone to taunt police before he and other rioters muscled through metal fencing.\n\n\"We don't want you guys. We want them,\" Norris is accused of screaming at police before pushing past barricades and joining the advancing mob.\n\nAccording to a statement of facts, Norris was arrested on May 3 after an FBI agent interviewed him at his job. It is unclear if he has retained an attorney as of Monday.\n\nThe Justice Department alleges that Norris arrived on Capitol grounds around 12:45 p.m. on Jan. 6 and from that point onward, he was seen in video footage pushing past metal bike rack barriers as he chanted and yelled at police lined up to defend the Capitol building.\n\n\"We got bad news, let us drain that swamp. All we ask if you walk away. Let us bring it. Let us bring,\" he is accused of saying. \"I got bad news. We're pushing through. You better get down with us or back off because we're pushing through.\"\n\nOther footage allegedly shows Norris telling people around him to exercise discretion as he urged: \"Get ready to storm the Capitol!\"\n\n\"Hey discretion. Discretion is the word. Discretion. We're going to let it play out,\" he said.\n\nIt was clear to prosecutors based on other remarks he made that he understood why Congress was meeting that day and he could be heard making references to objections to electoral certificates.\n\nWhatever \"discretion\" he hoped to apply, police and prosecutors said that went out the window as Norris continued on to breach multiple barricades. Even after one line was briefly reestablished, prosecutors say Norris managed to get himself back behind the barricades again where he repeatedly yelled at police that \"we don't want you guys.\"\n\nHe also urged the crowd to \"make a stand, while there is still time to make a stand.\"\n\n\"How long are you going to be peaceful and selfish? Think about the kids and future children. Make a stand. {"uri": "8113115641", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "04:17:52", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T04:17:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T04:17:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4431372582912445, "url": "https://www.yakimaherald.com/morning-briefing-may-6-2024/article_a8d3c30a-0b50-11ef-a95b-4f9d800ff636.html", "title": "Morning Briefing: May 6, 2024", "body": "Motor sportsNorris earns first career F1 victory\n\nMIAMI GARDENS, Fla. -- Lando Norris should take a lesson from his last big party and perhaps tone down the celebration for his first career Formula 1 victory.\n\nHis reaction following the Sunday victory in the Miami Grand Prix showed the British driver probably doesn't plan to miss a beat.\n\n\"Tonight's going to be a great time,\" Norris promised. \"I'm just really proud. A lot of people, I guess, doubted me along the way. I've made a lot of mistakes over my last five years, my short career, but today we put it all together so this is all for the team. I started with McLaren because I believe in them and today proved exactly that.\"\n\nNorris won in his 110th career start after a mistake by Max Verstappen ended Verstappen's dominance at the circuit in the parking lot surrounding Hard Rock Stadium. The 24-year-old driver sprinted down pit lane to leap into the arms of his McLaren crew, which crowd surfed Norris until he finally got to boss Zak Brown, who wrapped Norris in a bearhug.\n\nNorris arrived in Miami with a bandage covering stitches on his nose from a cut received by broken glass while he was in Amsterdam following F1's last outing. Norris was celebrating King's Day with DJ Martin Garrix when he cut his nose.\n\nVerstappen, who started from the pole and won Saturday's sprint race, was out front when he hit a chicane and knocked a cone out of place on the circuit. It forced the three-time reigning F1 champion to pit and gave Norris the lead.\n\nNorris then controlled the race to give McLaren its first win since a Daniel Ricciardo victory in 2021.\n\nLarson edges Buescher: Kyle Larson came around Chris Buescher on the final lap and banged doors with him all the way to the finish line, where he was declared the winner of the Cup Series race by officials at Kansas Speedway in the closest finish in NASCAR history. The official margin was a thousandth of a second.\n\nGolfPendrith gets first PGA Tour victory\n\nMcKINNEY, Texas -- Taylor Pendrith took advantage of Ben Kohles' final-hole meltdown to win the CJ Cup Byron Nelson on Sunday for his first PGA Tour title.\n\nKohles overtook Pendrith with birdies on Nos. 16 and 17 for a one-shot lead, then bogeyed the 18th after hitting his second shot into greenside rough. His first chip didn't reach the green. After having to chip twice from the rough and already looking stunned, Kohles missed a 6-foot putt that would have forced a playoff.\n\nPendrith two-putted for birdie on the 18th, holing a 3-footer for a 4-under 67 and 23-under 261 total. The 32-year-old Canadian won in his 74th career PGA Tour start.\n\nKoepka wins LIV Golf Singapore: Brooks Koepka became the first player to win four times on the LIV Golf circuit when he closed with a 3-under 68 in LIV Golf Singapore. Koepka had four birdies and a bogey to finish at 15-under 198 for the three rounds.\n\nDunlap claims rain-shortened Insperity title: Scott Dunlap was declared the 36-hole winner of the Insperity Invitational when rain washed the final round, giving Dunlap his first PGA Tour Champions title in nearly 10 years.\n\nOtaegui rallies to win China Open: Adrian Otaegui overcame a five-shot deficit to win the China Open by closing with a 7-under 65 for the Spaniard's fifth European tour title.\n\nTelevisionKentucky Derby draws 16.7 million viewers\n\nSTAMFORD, Conn. -- Mystik Dan's nose victory in the 150th Kentucky Derby drew 16.7 million viewers, the biggest audience for the race since 1989.\n\nViewership peaked at 20.1 million from 4 to 4:15 p.m. on Saturday, when 18-1 shot Mystik Dan, Sierra Leone and Forever Young hit the wire together in the Derby's first three-horse photo finish since 1947. That marked the biggest peak audience ever for the Derby on NBC.\n\nThe 16.7 million viewers was up 13% from last year's 14.8 million.\n\nNBC Sports said Sunday it was the biggest Derby audience since 18.5 million watched Sunday Silence win in 1989, when the race was shown on ABC.\n\nBriefly\n\nBaseball: The Padres placed pitcher Joe Musgrove on the IL with right elbow inflammation. ... Guardians outfielder Steven Kwan is headed to the IL with a hamstring strain. ... Rays pitcher Ryan Pepiot departed his start after getting hit by a 107.5 mph line drive. ... Dodgers closer Evan Phillips was placed on the IL with a strained right hamstring.\n\nBeach volleyball: Twin sisters Nicole and Audrey Nourse won the deciding match for a second straight season and top-ranked Southern California won its fourth straight beach volleyball championship with a 3-0 sweep over No. 2 UCLA.\n\nTennis: Andrey Rublev was feeling sick all week but rallied to beat Felix Auger-Aliassime in three sets at the Madrid Open and clinch his second Masters 1000 title.\n\nCycling: Tadej Pogacar swiftly made his way back to the peloton and then attacked on his own 2.5 miles from the end to secure victory on the top-category uphill finish to Santuario di Oropa and the leader's pink jersey at the Giro d'Italia.\n\nRunning: Lemi Berhanu Hayle of Ethiopia won the Prague international marathon while his fellow countrywoman Bedatu Hirpa Badane won the women's race.\n\nSailing: Diego Botin made an aggressive move at the start and skippered Spain to a wire-to-wire victory against heavyweights Peter Burling of New Zealand and Tom Slingsby of Australia to win the Bermuda Sail Grand Prix.\n\nObituary: Cesar Luis Menotti, the charismatic coach who led Argentina to its first World Cup title in 1978, has died, the Argentine Football Association said Sunday. {"uri": "8113788140", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "12:32:37", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T12:32:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T12:32:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4313725531101227, "url": "https://thesportsrush.com/f1-news-lando-norris-used-to-have-a-poster-of-alex-albon-during-his-karting-days-he-was-a-guy-i-looked-up-to/", "title": "Lando Norris Used to Have a Poster of Alex Albon During His Karting Days - \"He Was a Guy I Looked up To\" - The SportsRush", "body": "Lando Norris grew up racing with Charles Leclerc, Alex Albon, and George Russell. However, Alex Albon had a greater impact on Norris than the other two. Their almost four-year age gap made the Thai driver the then-6-year-old Norris' idol. He revealed that in Sky Sports F1's popular lie detector YouTube edition. He confessed how he started admiring Albon from his first karting race as a spectator and even put up a poster of him in his room.\n\n\"This was the time I was more of a Moto GP fan than Formula 1. So I was Valentino Rossi, like everything and he was number 46. So like straight I was like wow, he's Valentino.\", Norris said.\n\n\"But then I also noticed his helmet was in the font of the doctor. So I could tell he was also a Rossi fan. As soon as I knew he was a Rossi fan I was like wow, he's a cool guy. He was a guy I looked up to when I was starting,\" he confessed.\n\nSo, the respect for the Williams man stemmed from their mutual admiration for Valentino Rossi. Perhaps Rossi has had a greater impact on Norris's life. The lure towards the Moto GP legend's style, his striking racing gear, celebrations, helmet, etc ignited the passion for racing in the young Brit.\n\nThe 24-year-old even drew inspiration from the Italian for his racing helmet when he first began racing. In short, it was Rossi's aura that led to Lando Norris becoming the 114th Formula 1 Grand Prix winner.\n\nThe British driver met his hero during the British Motorcycle Grand Prix at Silverstone in 2019. The two met and became close enough to stay in touch. The seven-time Moto GP winner even sent Norris a congratulatory message after his Singapore GP podium.\n\nWonder if he'll receive a text again. Although this friendship is begging to be taken to the track but their busy schedules are hampering those plans.\n\nAfter Lando Norris met the Moto GP serial winner, the two kept in touch. They even plan to race each other despite Rossi retiring from the two-wheeled championship. This hope is kept alive as the 45-year-old switched to four wheels. Since 2022, Rossi has been part of the GT World Challenge Europe.\n\nRossi also confessed about wanting to race Norris, back in 2021. As quoted by Planet F1, he said, \"About racing together next year, for me it would be fantastic because Lando is so fast. I will race in cars and if I can do a race with Lando, for me it will be a great, great pleasure because it is very fast and we can enjoy for sure.\"\n\nThe tribute helmets and bucket hats are the McLaren man's way of showing appreciation. Whereas, Rossi is practicing racing with more wheels so he can challenge his young admirer. Sometimes, it feels that way before you do it. I quit my job in January 2020 and started the business.\"\n\nBut before she started Norris Design, the Springdale native's first venture into entrepreneurship was in high school. She and her sister started a business as swim instructors, providing backyard lessons for about six years. She and her sister also played volleyball at Arkansas Tech University in Russellville, and Norris earned a scholarship to play there after playing volleyball in high school.\n\nIn 2019, Norris graduated from Arkansas Tech University with a bachelor's degree in graphic design and a minor in business. After graduating, she wanted to earn some graphic design experience, so she joined a marketing agency in Springdale before opening Norris Design in 2020.\n\nNorris said she started her agency to meet a need, looking to help businesses with brand strategy and \"making stuff that didn't just look nice but serves a good purpose and made sense for the client.\" Along with brand strategy, her agency's services include logo design, content writing and marketing services such as social media, search engine optimization and website design.\n\nThe agency serves clients in Northwest Arkansas and nationwide across various sectors, including technology, healthcare, nonprofits and e-commerce. The agency has six staff.\n\nIn November, Norris and her staff launched BizNWA.com, a directory of area business resources. The volunteer project was developed after multiple clients asked about resources in the area. The website provides a one-stop shop for access to the resources.\n\nAn active volunteer, Norris also mentors the Fuel Accelerator program and is a board member and marketing chair for the nonprofit Women in Networking of Northwest Arkansas.\n\nA career highlight has been helping businesses to grow and reach their goals. {"uri": "8113419393", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "08:30:56", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T08:30:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T08:30:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.407843142747879, "url": "https://www.ok.co.uk/lifestyle/lando-norris-formula-one-life-32742895", "title": "Miami Grand Prix winner Lando Norris- model love, \u00a380m contract and \u00a320m mansion", "body": "Congratulations are in order for Lando Norris who secured the first win of his Formula One career while at the Miami Grand Prix on Sunday, 5 May. In what was his 110th F1 race, the 24 year old beat world champion Max Verstappen.\n\nAs he celebrated his first win, it's clear that Lando had been waiting a while for this moment to come to fruition. \"About time! What a race. It's been a long time coming,\" he said. \"Finally I've managed to do it.\"\n\nSo, as the F1 driver celebrates his victory, let's take a peek at his life away from the Paddock...\n\nBorn in Bristol, Lando is the son of stock market trader Adam Norris who came in at number 18 on the 2016 Bristol Rich List after amassing a personal fortune of \u00a3205 million.\n\nThe motor racer has two younger sisters, and an older brother and it's clear that his family have been cheering him on from the sidelines. Following his recent win, his doting dad spoke to Sky Sports about his son's victory.\n\n\"It's beautiful, it's beautiful. But I think the other dads... I've just had Lewis' dad give me a text and we've been through a lot. And it's interesting knowing as a parent how many hours you put in supporting them,\" he said.\n\nDespite becoming Fernando Alonso's teammate at the Daytona 24 Hours sports car race in 2018 when he was just 18 years old and racing in his first F1 event a year later, racing wasn't the star's first love.\n\n\"I started on horse riding, so I started on four legs. But then I moved to quad biking. I was a big fan. Then I really got into motocross,\" he told British GQ in 2022.\n\nBut since discovering his talent in racing, Lando's career has gone from strength to strength and in 2022 he committed to a four-year agreement with McLaren. The four-year contract is reportedly estimated to be worth \u00a380 million, according to Bloomberg.\n\nDuring his time in the spotlight, the racing driver has opened up about the pressures that come with working in Formula One and in 2021 he appeared on the This Morning sofa where he discussed all things mental health.\n\n\"I guess people, from when they just watch TV, don't realise many things that a driver goes through,\" he explained. \"And it's a bit of shame, but there are more programmes now where you get to see what the driver is like behind the scenes, and the amount of pressure and stress that they have to cope with.\n\n\"Especially at my age, coming into Formula One at 19, there's a lot of eyes on you. So, dealing with all these kinds of things, took its toll on me.\"\n\nAway from the F1 track Lando likes to keep busy and is the founder of \"entertainment, athlete, and apparel brand\" Quadrant. Co-owned by YouTuber WillNE, the brand sells clothes including hoodies, hats and shorts.\n\nAnd on the topic of YouTube, the McLaren driver has over one million subscribers on the site where he occasionally shares 'LandoLOGs' which provide an insight into his daily life. Meanwhile, a second YouTube channel of his called Lando Norris Plays has racked up 388,000 subscribers and sees him play different video games.\n\nIf that wasn't enough, over on TikTok he has two million followers and on Instagram he has over eight million.\n\nCareer aside, Lando reportedly has a \u00a320 million mansion in Surrey, according to the Daily Mail. However, in 2021 he revealed that he was moving to Monaco and that he was \"excited\" to see what the move had in store.\n\n\"Say hello to my new home! The place isn't finished yet but I'll be living here in Monaco when I'm not in the factory or at the track next year. I get the keys at the end of next month so will hopefully be moving in soon. Really excited for this next chapter!,\" he wrote in an Instagram post.\n\nThe F1 star was previously in a relationship with Portuguese model Luisinha Oliveira, though the couple called time on their romance in 2022. Taking to Instagram to announce the sad news, Lando paid tribute to his \"amazing and strong\" ex-girlfriend.\n\nAfter time and consideration, Luisa and myself have mutually decided to end our relationship but remain good friends,\" he said. \"I wish her the world and have so much respect for her and all she does as an amazing and strong woman with nothing but kindness.\"\n\nSince then Lando has been linked to actress and model Margarida Corceiro and the pair were seen at the Monte-Carlo Masters final last month.", "source": {"uri": "ok.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "ok"}, {"eng-9538217": {"articles": {"results": [{"uri": "8114420487", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "20:43:55", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T20:43:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T20:39:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://www.eagletribune.com/analysis-lando-norris-win-shows-mclaren-is-ready-to-return-to-global-motorsports-prominence/article_b2d8be9b-9556-5c33-870c-7a1c450ce397.html", "title": "Analysis: Lando Norris win shows McLaren is ready to return to global motorsports prominence", "body": "McLaren driver Lando Norris, of Britain, on monitor, is sprayed with champagne as he stands on the podium after winning the Formula One Miami Grand Prix auto race at the Miami International Autodrome, Sunday, May 5, 2024, in Miami Gardens, Fla.\n\nMIAMI GARDENS, Fla. (AP) -- Lando Norris says the online trolling never really bothered him as he went winless through his first five Formula 1 seasons, even when it got worse as one of the breakout stars for fans introduced to the sport through Netflix.\n\nIt was a long wait as Team McLaren got its program together and prepared cars capable of competing with Red Bull, Ferrari and Mercedes. Norris passed the time doom scrolling social media, searching for motivation from his haters.\n\nHis moment came Sunday in his 110th career start when he earned his first victory by beating three-time reigning F1 champion Max Verstappen at the Miami Grand Prix. Verstappen had won the first two races at Miami and Saturday's sprint race before he hit a cone early Sunday to give Norris his opportunity.\n\n\"I never didn't believe in what I could go out and do, so I am happy to put that to bed and prove a lot of these people wrong,\" Norris said. \"I go on Instagram and I like all the comments of people abusing me. I freaking love it. It makes me smile more than anything, especially \"Lando No-Wins.\" That's become the thing.\n\n\"For me to finally prove those people wrong and prove to people that didn't think I could go out and do it, it's put an even bigger smile on my face. So I thank all of them.\"\n\nHe turned up at the post-race news conference in a champagne-drenched firesuit. Verstappen and Lewis Hamilton led the congratulatory hugs for Norris, and Verstappen and third-place finisher Charles Leclerc sprayed champagne directly into Norris' face on the podium.\n\nHe had closed his eyes and turned his smiling face to the sky as \"God Save the King\" was played, and he cradled the winning trophy as if it was an infant. He crowd-surfed with his McLaren crew and when he saw boss Zak Brown headed his way, warned 'Don't break my ribs,' in anticipation of the bearhug.\n\n\"I'm shivering like hell because I wanted to keep all my champagne on me,\" Norris laughed, \"and now I'm freaking cold.\"\n\nMcLAREN'S WIN\n\nMcLaren needed this win, its first since 2022 (Daniel Ricciardo, and it came on a weekend in which the team introduced massive upgrades it was certain would make its cars more competitive. The 24-year-old Norris said he arrived Sunday believing he'd win.\n\nNorris had promised his ailing grandmother last week that a victory was on the horizon but allowed \"I didn't think it would be coming this soon.\"\n\nMcLaren this year now has scored wins in F1, Formula E and IndyCar, where Pato O'Ward last week was declared the winner of the season-opening race because Josef Newgarden was disqualified.\n\nThe next three IndyCar weekends are spent at Indianapolis Motor Speedway for the buildup to the May 26 Indianapolis 500. McLaren has to be feeling some pressure after a winless 2023 season and somewhat disastrous Indy 500.\n\nMONTH OF MAY\n\nThe McLaren organization is intertwined -- the IndyCar drivers were on social media celebrating Norris as soon as he crossed the finish line -- and the F1 victory is a boost at the perfect time of the season. McLaren is also going to Indy with NASCAR superstar Kyle Larson, who will become the fifth driver in history to attempt to complete 1,100 miles of racing in one day in the Indy 500 and NASCAR's Coca-Cola 600.\n\nThe hype surrounding Larson's attempt at \"The Double\" has helped McLaren return to its status as one of the most recognizable brands in motorsports.\n\nIt is all vindication for Brown, an American who started his motorsports career in a marketing role in Indianapolis and now runs one of the largest racing brands on the planet.\n\nBrown likes to stir the pot and ensure drama remains at the front of almost every race weekend, and he was at it again in Miami when he took a shot at Red Bull by implying famed car designer Adrian Newey was leaving the team because of the fallout from an investigation into improper conduct by team principal Christian Horner.\n\nBrown went so far as to say Newey was probably just the first to head for the exit door, an assumption he was making based on \"all the resumes\" flying around the paddock.\n\nHe doesn't let up in IndyCar, either, and rival team owner Chip Ganassi and Brown are not friendly. Brown signed Ganassi driver Alex Palou for 2023 and the two teams used a mediator to battle over the two-time IndyCar champion. It was decided Palou would join McLaren in 2024, but Palou balked last August and is now being sued by McLaren for more than $30 million.\n\nMcLaren last week fired David Malukas before he even made an IndyCar start for the team over injuries he suffered in a mountain bike crash ahead of the season, angering Malukas' millennial fanbase. That followed the unpopular team dismissals of James Hinchcliffe and Oliver Askew, both done after McLaren entered the series with controlling interest of an existing team.\n\nBrown unapologetically chases free agents with little regard to how many seats he actually has open. That's partly how this Palou mess began -- when Palou looked at the F1 landscape, he realized Norris wasn't going anywhere and McLaren would likely never have a seat for him in the series.\n\nIf he was going to stay in IndyCar, then Palou figured he'd stay with the team that helped him to two championships rather than move to winless, revolving-door McLaren. While the decision might ultimately have been the right one for Palou, Brown is digging McLaren out of a decade-long slump and the Norris win has the entire organization feeling unbeatable.\n\nAP F1: {"eng-9538217": {"articles": {"results": [{"uri": "8114453184", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "21:12:27", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T21:12:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T21:11:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "url": "https://www.gulf-times.com/article/681952/sports/nowins-no-more-as-norris-delivers-much-needed-f1-plot-twist", "title": "'NoWins' no more as Norris delivers much-needed F1 plot twist", "body": "Miami Gardens, United States: Formula One has built much of its recent success in the United States on the Netflix reality documentary series Drive to Survive but with Max Verstappen utterly dominating there was an acute need for a plot twist.\n\nThat arrived in Miami on Sunday, when Lando Norris, the 24-year-old McLaren driver, pulled off a surprise win over the Dutchman.\n\nVerstappen has won four of the six races so far this season and it would be unwise for anyone to see Norris's win as the sign of an imminent change in fortunes for the three-times world champion, but to maintain interest, F1 needed some rotation on the top of the podium.\n\nIt was certainly a feel-good story, Norris came into Miami having had a record 15 podium finishes without a win - with eight of those second-place finishes.\n\nNear-misses, such as at Sochi in 2021 when he led late but paid the price for failing to switch tyres in time during heavy rain, led to some taunting of Norris including the online nickname 'Lando NoWins'\n\nWhile he was all smiles after his victory, he was not going to miss the chance for a defiant reply to his critics.\n\n\"I am happy to put that to bed and prove a lot of these people wrong,\" he told his post-race press conference. \"I love it to go on Instagram and like all the comments from people abusing me, I freaking love it, makes me smile more than anything, especially 'Lando NoWins', that's become the thing.\" he added. \"For me to prove those people wrong and prove (to) the people who didn't think I could go out and do it, it's going to be an even bigger smile on my face today, so I thank all of them,\" he said.\n\nMcLaren had been without a Grand Prix win since Monza in 2021 and team principal Andrea Stella said they had finally given Norris the chance to win.\n\n\"The victory for Lando, he deserved it so much and we always said as soon as we give him the right material he's going to make it and he made it.\n\n\"I know what kind of work is behind it, it's so deserved for the McLaren team, I hope everyone enjoys this moment,\" he said.\n\nNorris insisted that he had always had faith in his ability to win a Grand Prix and asked if it was a weight of his shoulders to finally clinch one, couldn't deny the reality.\n\n\"As much as I want to say no, it's a yes! To get that first victory is always incredible. I've of course had my moments where I've been close, and I've never been able to convert it into the win,\" he said.\n\n\"But I wasn't worried. As much as a lot of people doubted that I was going to be able to put it together and win a race, I wasn't worried.\"", "source": {"uri": "gulf-times.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Gulf-Times"},
